We do not report peak t-scores in the table because the reported clusters reflect conjunctions of statistical contrast maps for which the constituent peak t-values might be located in different voxels. studies.title: Cognitive control in social situations: a role for the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex.
studies.abstract: Using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), we investigated brain activity elicited by a computer-animated child's actions that appeared consistent and inconsistent with a computer-animated adult's instructions. Participants observed a computer-animated adult verbally instructing a computer-animated child to touch one of two objects. The child performed correctly in half of the trials and incorrectly in the other half. We observed significantly greater activity when the child performed incorrectly compared to correctly in regions of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) that have been implicated in maintaining our intentions in working memory and implementing cognitive control. However, no such effects were found in regions of the posterior superior temporal sulcus (posterior STS) that have been posited to interpret other people's behavior. These findings extend the role of the DLPFC in cognitive control to evaluating the social outcomes of other people's behavior and provide important new constraints for theories of how the posterior STS contributes to social cognition.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study probing neural responses to others' social actions (evaluating compliance/noncompliance), clearly addressing social processing. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so cannot confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult (17–65) sample.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (final N=16, ages 18–29) using a task that explicitly examines perception/understanding of others (evaluating whether a child’s actions match an adult’s instructions). The paper reports group-level voxelwise whole-brain analyses (voxelwise ANOVAs with thresholds, reported peak coordinates and clusters in DLPFC, posterior STS, medial prefrontal and other regions) in addition to ROI analyses. Results are clearly presented for the healthy/control group. Thus all inclusion criteria are met (social-related fMRI task; healthy adult sample within 18–65; whole-brain, group-level task-evoked maps reported). No exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: Deciphering human motion to discriminate social interactions: a developmental neuroimaging study.
studies.abstract: Non-verbal communication plays a major role in social interaction understanding. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging, we explored the development of the neural networks involved in social interaction recognition based on human motion in children (8-11), adolescents (13-17), and adults (20-41). Participants watched point-light videos depicting two actors interacting or moving independently and were asked whether these agents were interacting or not. All groups successfully performed the discrimination task, but children had a lower performance and longer response times than the older groups. In all three groups, the posterior parts of the superior temporal sulci and middle temporal gyri, the inferior frontal gyri and the anterior temporal lobes showed greater activation when observing social interactions. In addition, adolescents and adults recruited the caudate nucleus and some frontal regions that are part of the mirror system. Adults showed greater activations in parietal and frontal regions (part of them belonging to the social brain) than adolescents.An increased number of regions that are part of the mirror system network or the social brain, as well as the caudate nucleus, were recruited with age. In conclusion, a shared set of brain regions enabling the discrimination of social interactions from neutral movements through human motion is already present in 8-year-old children. Developmental processes such as refinements in the social brain and mirror system would help grasping subtle cues in non-verbal aspects of social interactions.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study where healthy adult participants (ages 20–41) performed a social interaction discrimination task (point-light displays). Meets inclusion: social-related task, healthy adults 17–65 present. Not a review/meta-analysis.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an event-related task fMRI study of social interaction (SI) recognition using point-/stick-light displays—clearly a social-related process. The sample includes a healthy adult group (n=16, mean age 28.8 y, within 18–65) with results reported separately. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (SI > NM) for the adult group, with voxelwise statistics, cluster/FWE information, and regional activations described in the text/tables. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state only, and healthy adult whole-brain maps are reported). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Observing social interactions: the effect of gaze.
studies.abstract: Our social abilities depend on specialized brain systems that allow us to perform crucial operations such as interpreting the actions of others. This functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) study investigated whether human brain activity evoked by the observation of social interactions is modulated by gaze. During scanning participants observed social or individual actions performed by agents whose gaze could be either available or masked. Results demonstrated that the observation of social interactions evoked activity within a dorsal sector of the medial prefrontal cortex (MPFC), an area classically involved in social cognition. Importantly, activity within this area was modulated by whether the gaze of the agents performing the observed action was or was not available. The implications of these findings for a role played by the dorsal medial prefrontal cortex (dMPFC) in terms of inferential processes concerned with social interactions are considered.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining observation of social interactions and gaze—clearly a social-related task targeting social cognition. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health; include for full-text review to confirm that participants are healthy adults (17–65).
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=17, mean age 26). The task manipulated social vs. individual actions and gaze availability — a clear social-cognitive paradigm. Group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses are reported (second-level within-subjects ANOVA) with voxelwise results and coordinates (p<.001 uncorrected; maps/tables described), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from the healthy group. The sample falls within the 18–65 age range and results for the healthy participants are reported separately. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) are violated.

studies.title: Functional MRI reveals expert-novice differences during sport-related anticipation.
studies.abstract: We examined the effect of expertise on cortical activation during sports anticipation using functional MRI. In experiment 1, recreational players predicted badminton stroke direction and the pattern of active clusters was consistent with a proposed perception-of-action network. This pattern was not replicated in a stimulus-matched, action-unrelated control task. In experiment 2, players of three different skill levels anticipated stroke direction from clips occluded either 160 ms before or 80 ms after racquet-shuttle contact. Early-occluded sequences produced more activation than late-occluded sequences overall, in most cortical regions of interest, but experts showed an additional enhancement in medial, dorsolateral and ventrolateral frontal cortex. Anticipation in open-skill sports engages cortical areas integral to observing and understanding others' actions; such activity is enhanced in experts.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was conducted while healthy adult participants performed anticipation of others' actions in a sport context, which targets perception and understanding of others (a social processing construct). Participants appear to be healthy adults; study is original research, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient evidence to meet inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical, task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining perception and anticipation of another person’s actions (anticipation/action observation), which maps onto the review construct 'Perception and Understanding of Others.' The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxelwise analyses (t-contrasts, FWE-corrected), with figures and tables of peak coordinates and ROI analyses derived from independent whole-brain contrasts. Samples include adult participants (recreational to international players) with results reported for healthy groups. The study is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: The brain functional networks associated to human and animal suffering differ among omnivores, vegetarians and vegans.
studies.abstract: Empathy and affective appraisals for conspecifics are among the hallmarks of social interaction. Using functional MRI, we hypothesized that vegetarians and vegans, who made their feeding choice for ethical reasons, might show brain responses to conditions of suffering involving humans or animals different from omnivores. We recruited 20 omnivore subjects, 19 vegetarians, and 21 vegans. The groups were matched for sex and age. Brain activation was investigated using fMRI and an event-related design during observation of negative affective pictures of human beings and animals (showing mutilations, murdered people, human/animal threat, tortures, wounds, etc.). Participants saw negative-valence scenes related to humans and animals, alternating with natural landscapes. During human negative valence scenes, compared with omnivores, vegetarians and vegans had an increased recruitment of the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) and inferior frontal gyrus (IFG). More critically, during animal negative valence scenes, they had decreased amygdala activation and increased activation of the lingual gyri, the left cuneus, the posterior cingulate cortex and several areas mainly located in the frontal lobes, including the ACC, the IFG and the middle frontal gyrus. Nonetheless, also substantial differences between vegetarians and vegans have been found responding to negative scenes. Vegetarians showed a selective recruitment of the right inferior parietal lobule during human negative scenes, and a prevailing activation of the ACC during animal negative scenes. Conversely, during animal negative scenes an increased activation of the inferior prefrontal cortex was observed in vegans. These results suggest that empathy toward non conspecifics has different neural representation among individuals with different feeding habits, perhaps reflecting different motivational factors and beliefs.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining empathy/affective responses to human and animal suffering (social-related processing: perception/understanding of others). Groups are healthy omnivores, vegetarians, vegans. Meets inclusion (task-based fMRI of social processing); not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy toward humans and animals) in healthy adult participants (n=60, ages 18–60). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (human negative > neutral; animal negative > neutral) with second-level random-effects analyses and coordinates with FWE-corrected thresholds and conjunction/within-group maps. Healthy groups’ whole-brain results are clearly reported separately (within-group and between-group contrasts). The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and participants fall within the 18–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

activation_tables.table_caption: Within-group comparisons of human vs. animal negative valence picture view and vice versa in omnivore subjects, vegetarians and vegans (paired t test in each group, p<0.05 FWE-corrected).

studies.title: The busy social brain: evidence for automaticity and control in the neural systems supporting social cognition and action understanding.
studies.abstract: Much social-cognitive processing is believed to occur automatically; however, the relative automaticity of the brain systems underlying social cognition remains largely undetermined. We used functional MRI to test for automaticity in the functioning of two brain systems that research has indicated are important for understanding other people's behavior: the mirror neuron system and the mentalizing system. Participants remembered either easy phone numbers (low cognitive load) or difficult phone numbers (high cognitive load) while observing actions after adopting one of four comprehension goals. For all four goals, mirror neuron system activation showed relatively little evidence of modulation by load; in contrast, the association of mentalizing system activation with the goal of inferring the actor's mental state was extinguished by increased cognitive load. These results support a dual-process model of the brain systems underlying action understanding and social cognition; the mirror neuron system supports automatic behavior identification, and the mentalizing system supports controlled social causal attribution.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining social cognition (mirror neuron and mentalizing systems) during social-related tasks. Likely uses healthy adult participants; ages not specified in abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social cognition (action understanding, mentalizing, mirror-neuron processes) in healthy adults (final N reported; ages 18–32). The design uses task-evoked fMRI with group-level, random-effects voxelwise contrasts and reports cluster coordinates and tables of activations (e.g., Table 1) for the healthy sample. Although primary analyses were restricted to an a priori mask, the manuscript notes whole-brain results and provides group-level voxelwise statistical maps/coordinates (including conjunctions and F-contrasts) for the healthy group; results are not limited to ROI, connectivity, or clinical-only contrasts. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and reported group-level voxelwise task activation maps).

studies.title: Brain imaging investigation of the neural correlates of observing virtual social interactions.
studies.abstract: The ability to gauge social interactions is crucial in the assessment of others' intentions. Factors such as facial expressions and body language affect our decisions in personal and professional life alike (1). These "friend or foe" judgements are often based on first impressions, which in turn may affect our decisions to "approach or avoid". Previous studies investigating the neural correlates of social cognition tended to use static facial stimuli (2). Here, we illustrate an experimental design in which whole-body animated characters were used in conjunction with functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) recordings. Fifteen participants were presented with short movie-clips of guest-host interactions in a business setting, while fMRI data were recorded; at the end of each movie, participants also provided ratings of the host behaviour. This design mimics more closely real-life situations, and hence may contribute to better understanding of the neural mechanisms of social interactions in healthy behaviour, and to gaining insight into possible causes of deficits in social behaviour in such clinical conditions as social anxiety and autism (3).
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI data were collected while healthy adult participants (n=15) viewed and rated animated social interactions—this is a social-processing task involving perception/understanding of others. Study is empirical (not a review) and fits age/healthy participant criteria. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study using a social-related task (observing virtual social interactions). Participants are described as recruited based on age/health and Figure 1 reports group data from 15 participants, implying a healthy adult sample. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps (Figure 1) showing significant activity in social cognition regions (STS, mPFC, amygdala) time-locked to task events. The study therefore meets: (1) fMRI during a social task, (2) healthy adult group reported separately, and (3) whole-brain voxelwise group results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) are violated. Inclusion is warranted.

studies.title: Neural oscillations in human auditory cortex revealed by fast fMRI during auditory perception.
studies.abstract: Previous work pointed to the neural and functional significance of infraslow neural oscillations below 1 ​Hz that can be detected and precisely located with fast functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). While previous work demonstrated this significance for brain dynamics during very low-level sensory stimulation, we here provide the first evidence for the detectability and functional significance of infraslow oscillatory blood oxygenation level-dependent (BOLD) responses to auditory stimulation by the sociobiological relevant and more complex category of voices. Previous work pointed to a specific area of the mammalian auditory cortex (AC) that is sensitive to vocal signals as quantified by activation levels. Here we show, by using fast fMRI, that the human voice-sensitive AC prioritizes vocal signals not only in terms of activity level but also in terms of specific infraslow BOLD oscillations. We found unique sustained and transient oscillatory BOLD patterns in the AC for vocal signals. For transient oscillatory patterns, vocal signals showed faster peak oscillatory responses across all AC regions. Furthermore, we identified an exclusive sustained oscillatory component for vocal signals in the primary AC. Fast fMRI thus demonstrates the significance and richness of infraslow BOLD oscillations for neurocognitive mechanisms in social cognition as demonstrated here for the sociobiological relevance of voice processing.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study uses fast fMRI in human participants to examine neural responses to human voices, which constitutes social communication/perception. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient evidence of relevance to social-related processing.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (Experiment 1: n=13, ages 21–41; Experiment 2: n=18, ages 18–33). It investigates processing of vocal (socially relevant) versus non-vocal sounds, a social-communication related construct (perception/processing of conspecific voices). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and contrasts (vocal > non-vocal) with voxelwise thresholding (p<0.05 FDR) and coordinates/figures, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Analyses include within-group GLM contrasts (not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group-only results). Participants are within the 18–65 range and healthy. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Functional neuroanatomy of body checking in people with anorexia nervosa.
studies.abstract: The neural correlates of body checking perceptions in eating disorders have not yet been identified. This functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging study examined the neuroanatomy involved in altered perception and identification with body checking in female with anorexia nervosa (AN).
studies.journal: The International journal of eating disorders
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports fMRI of body-checking in anorexia nervosa patients and does not specify inclusion of a healthy control group or participant ages. Task may relate to self-perception (a social-related construct), but information is insufficient to confirm criteria — include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study used task-based fMRI probing social-related processing (imagining/mental mirroring of others performing body-checking actions; engages self- and other-related/social cognition networks). It reports whole-brain, group-level task activation maps and results for the healthy control group (HC), including coordinates and figures, not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. The HC group (n=15) is an age-matched healthy adult sample reported separately. Note minor age-range ambiguity (enrollment 17–34 years) but healthy-group whole-brain results are clearly presented; therefore inclusion is appropriate.

studies.title: Impaired social brain network for processing dynamic facial expressions in autism spectrum disorders.
studies.abstract: Impairment of social interaction via facial expressions represents a core clinical feature of autism spectrum disorders (ASD). However, the neural correlates of this dysfunction remain unidentified. Because this dysfunction is manifested in real-life situations, we hypothesized that the observation of dynamic, compared with static, facial expressions would reveal abnormal brain functioning in individuals with ASD.We presented dynamic and static facial expressions of fear and happiness to individuals with high-functioning ASD and to age- and sex-matched typically developing controls and recorded their brain activities using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI).
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI conducted during a social-related task (processing dynamic and static facial expressions). Study includes age- and sex-matched typically developing control group (healthy participants). Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study reports task-based fMRI of social processing (perception of others’ dynamic vs. static facial expressions). It includes a clearly reported healthy adult control group (n=13, age M=24.3) with results reported separately from the ASD group. Group-level whole-brain task contrasts for the control group (dynamic > static; and interaction contrasts) are presented with voxelwise statistics, corrected thresholds, and MNI coordinates (i.e., whole-brain random-effects maps), not limited to ROIs. Although the paper also reports connectivity/DCM and patient vs. control comparisons, it provides unmasked whole-brain activation maps for the healthy control group, satisfying all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Dissociation of Brain Activation in Autism and Schizotypal Personality Disorder During Social Judgments.
studies.abstract: There are overlaps between autism and schizophrenia but these are particularly pronounced, especially in social domains, for higher functioning individuals with autism spectrum disorders (ASD) or schizotypal personality disorder (SPD). It is not known whether these overlapping social deficits result from shared or distinct brain mechanisms. We therefore compared social cognition in ASD and SPD using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI).
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract describes an fMRI study of social cognition/social judgments, meeting the imaging and task relevance criteria. The abstract does not clearly report inclusion of a healthy control group aged 17–65, so full-text review is needed to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (approachability judgments), including a healthy adult control group. The paper reports within-group and between-group whole-brain task contrasts (social > gender and gender > baseline) and describes whole-brain voxelwise results for groups, with within-group analyses and statistical maps reported in the main text and supplementary materials (supplementary tables/figures). Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity analyses, and healthy-control group results are reported separately (within-group analyses and comparisons). Participants are adults and healthy controls are clearly defined. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing with whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps.

studies.title: Seeing is believing: neural mechanisms of action-perception are biased by team membership.
studies.abstract: Group identification can lead to a biased view of the world in favor of "in-group" members. Studying the brain processes that underlie such in-group biases is important for a wider understanding of the potential influence of social factors on basic perceptual processes. In this study, we used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to investigate how people perceive the actions of in-group and out-group members, and how their biased view in favor of own team members manifests itself in the brain. We divided participants into two teams and had them judge the relative speeds of hand actions performed by an in-group and an out-group member in a competitive situation. Participants judged hand actions performed by in-group members as being faster than those of out-group members, even when the two actions were performed at physically identical speeds. In an additional fMRI experiment, we showed that, contrary to common belief, such skewed impressions arise from a subtle bias in perception and associated brain activity rather than decision-making processes, and that this bias develops rapidly and involuntarily as a consequence of group affiliation. Our findings suggest that the neural mechanisms that underlie human perception are shaped by social context.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (perception of in-group vs out-group actions). It investigates social perception/neural mechanisms, fits inclusion criteria and is not a review. Sufficient detail in abstract to include for full-text data extraction.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task is social-related (group membership/in-group bias affecting action perception and judgments). (2) Sample comprises healthy adult participants (age range includes many 18–43-year-old adults; although a few 17-year-olds are present, the sample includes adults within 18–65). (3) Whole-brain, group-level task-evoked fMRI results are reported (voxelwise contrasts with cluster-level FWE correction; coordinates and tables reported). (4) Not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses; empirical fMRI data in healthy adults are presented. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore include for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Decoding the representation of learned social roles in the human brain.
studies.abstract: Humans as social beings are profoundly affected by exclusion. Short experiences with people differing in their degree of prosocial behaviour can induce reliable preferences for including partners, but the neural mechanisms of this learning remain unclear. Here, we asked participants to play a short social interaction game based on "cyber-ball" where one fictive partner included and another excluded the subject, thus defining social roles (includer - "good", excluder - "bad"). We then used multivariate pattern recognition on high-resolution functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data acquired before and after this game to test whether neural responses to the partners' and neutral control faces during a perceptual task reflect their learned social valence. Support vector classification scores revealed a learning-related increase in neural discrimination of social status in anterior insula and anterior cingulate regions, which was mainly driven by includer faces becoming distinguishable from excluder and control faces. Thus, face-evoked responses in anterior insula and anterior cingulate cortex contain fine-grained information shaped by prior social interactions that allow for categorisation of faces according to their learned social status. These lasting traces of social experience in cortical areas important for emotional and social processing could provide a substrate of how social inclusion shapes future behaviour and promotes cooperative interactions between individuals.
studies.journal: Cortex; a journal devoted to the study of the nervous system and behavior
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports fMRI with a social interaction (cyber-ball) assessing learned social roles/valence—fits social processing. Participant health and ages aren’t explicitly stated in the abstract, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65). No exclusion criteria met.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing (cyberball social inclusion/exclusion and face perception) in healthy adults (N=15, mean age ~24). It reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise results from an exploratory searchlight analysis (correlation-based MVPA) with family-wise-error-corrected clusters (STS coordinates reported), constituting a within-group, whole-brain task effect. Although much of the paper focuses on ROI MVPA, the presence of corrected whole-brain searchlight findings satisfies the requirement for whole-brain evidence. The sample is within the 18–65 range and results for the healthy group are clearly reported. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: Is the Medial Prefrontal Cortex Necessary for Theory of Mind?
studies.abstract: Successful social interaction relies on the ability to attribute mental states to other people. Previous functional neuroimaging studies have shown that this process, described as Theory of Mind (ToM) or mentalization, is reliably associated with activation of the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC). However, this study presents a novel and surprising finding that provides new insight into the role of the mPFC in mentalization tasks.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract addresses Theory of Mind/mentalization and refers to functional neuroimaging but does not explicitly state that an fMRI was conducted or report participant/sample details. Inclusion requires fMRI in healthy adults performing a social task; abstract information is insufficient, so include for full-text review to confirm methods and sample.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of Theory of Mind (social cognition) using validated Heider–Simmel animations (a social-related task). Sample comprises 20 healthy adults (age range 24–64, mean 45.6), within the 18–65 inclusion range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts from the healthy/control group (ToM > Random, ToM > Baseline, R > Baseline) with whole-brain statistical thresholds and figures/tables of activations. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and participants are within the target age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: What Makes Eye Contact Special? Neural Substrates of On-Line Mutual Eye-Gaze: A Hyperscanning fMRI Study.
studies.abstract: Automatic mimicry is a critical element of social interaction. A salient type of automatic mimicry is eye contact characterized by sharing of affective and mental states among individuals. We conducted a hyperscanning functional magnetic resonance imaging study involving on-line (LIVE) and delayed off-line (REPLAY) conditions to test our hypothesis that recurrent interaction through eye contact activates the limbic mirror system, including the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) and anterior insular cortex (AIC), both of which are critical for self-awareness. Sixteen pairs of human adults participated in the experiment. Given that an eye-blink represents an individual's attentional window toward the partner, we analyzed pairwise time-series data for eye-blinks. We used multivariate autoregression analysis to calculate the noise contribution ratio (NCR) as an index of how a participant's directional attention was influenced by that of their partner. NCR was greater in the LIVE than in the REPLAY condition, indicating mutual perceptual-motor interaction during real-time eye contact. Relative to the REPLAY condition, the LIVE condition was associated with greater activation in the left cerebellar hemisphere, vermis, and ACC, accompanied by enhanced functional connectivity between ACC and right AIC. Given the roles of the cerebellum in sensorimotor prediction and ACC in movement initiation, ACC-cerebellar activation may represent their involvement in modulating visual input related to the partner's movement, which may, in turn, involve the limbic mirror system. Our findings indicate that mutual interaction during eye contact is mediated by the cerebellum and limbic mirror system.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI hyperscanning study of live vs replay eye contact in adult pairs (healthy adults implied) investigating neural substrates of social interaction (eye contact). Meets criterion: functional MRI during a social-related task in healthy adults; not a review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study is an fMRI hyperscanning experiment of real-time mutual eye contact—a clearly social communication task. Participants are healthy adults (n≈30, mean age ~21.7), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (GLM contrasts LIVE > REPLAY) with cluster-level FWE correction and provides regional results (tables/figures), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although additional connectivity and interbrain synchronization analyses are included, the study also presents univariate whole-brain activation maps for the healthy sample, and results are not restricted to ROIs or to only connectivity/resting analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: Recruitment of both the mirror and the mentalizing networks when observing social interactions depicted by point-lights: a neuroimaging study.
studies.abstract: Understanding social interactions requires the ability to accurately interpret conspecifics' actions, sometimes only on the basis of subtle body language analysis. Here we address an important issue that has not yet received much attention in social neuroscience, that of an interaction between two agents. We attempted to isolate brain responses to two individuals interacting compared to two individuals acting independently.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Neuroimaging study investigating brain responses to observed social interactions; addresses social perception/understanding. Abstract implies healthy adult participants and an experimental task. Abstract lacks full methods detail, so include for full-text confirmation.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=14, mean age 29.4) using a social-related task (perception/understanding of others’ social interactions from point-light displays). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects task analyses (SI vs NSI contrast) with voxelwise significance (FDR-corrected p<0.05) and described activated clusters across the brain (pSTS, TPJ, MPFC, IFG, PM, IaPS, etc.). Results are not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and are clearly reported for the healthy/control group. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The activations presented survived to correction for multiple comparisons (FDR) across the whole brain at p<0.05. Only activations in excess of 10 voxels are listed. L/R: left and right hemispheres.

studies.title: An evaluation of traffic-awareness campaign videos: empathy induction is associated with brain function within superior temporal sulcus.
studies.abstract: Acting appropriately within social contexts requires an ability to appreciate others' mental and emotional states. Indeed, some campaign programs designed to reduce anti-social behaviour seek to elicit empathy for the victims. The effectiveness of these campaigns can be evaluated according to the degree to which they induce such responses, but by applying neuroscientific techniques this can be done at the behavioural and neurophysiological level. Neuroimaging studies aimed at identifying the neural mechanisms behind such socio-cognitive and -emotional processes frequently reveal the role of the superior temporal sulcus (STS). We applied this knowledge to assess the effectiveness of traffic-awareness campaign adverts to induce empathic expression. Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data were acquired from 20 healthy male volunteers as they watched these campaign videos consisting of a dramatic sequence of events and catastrophic endings, and control videos without such dramatic endings. Among other structures, a significantly greater neural response was observed within bilateral STS, particularly within the right hemisphere, during the observation of campaign relative to control videos. Furthermore, activation in these brain regions correlated with the subjects' empathic expression. Our results develop our understanding of the role of STS in social cognition. Moreover, our data demonstrate the utility of neuroscientific methods when evaluating the effectiveness of campaign videos in terms of their ability to elicit empathic responses. Our study also demonstrates the utility of these specific stimuli for future neuroscientific research.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was performed while healthy adult participants (20 male volunteers) viewed campaign videos designed to elicit empathy — a social-cognitive task involving perception/understanding of others. Participants are healthy adults and the study is primary research (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy/understanding of others) using video stimuli designed to induce socio-emotional responses. The sample consists of healthy adult participants (n=20 males, ages 20–28), meeting the age and healthy-group criteria. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked results (CV>NV contrast) with statistical maps and FWE-corrected clusters (p<0.05, extent threshold=5 voxels) and provides peak coordinates and figures; these constitute whole-brain evidence from the healthy/control group. Analyses are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group contrasts. Although the sample is all-male (noted as a limitation), it remains a healthy adult cohort reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Automatic and intentional brain responses during evaluation of face approachability: correlations with trait anxiety.
studies.abstract: The judgment of the approachability of others based on their facial appearance often precedes social interaction. Whether we ultimately approach or avoid others may depend on such judgments.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract describes brain responses during evaluation of face approachability, a social-perception task in humans. However, the abstract does not explicitly state that functional MRI was used. Because modality and participant details are insufficient, include for full-text review to confirm fMRI and healthy adult sample.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing (evaluation of face approachability — perception/understanding of others). Participants are healthy adults (adult sample reported), and analyses report group-level task-evoked activation contrasts (interaction between task and face valence) with whole-brain results identifying activations in left amygdala and frontal gyri and correlations with trait anxiety. Methods reference whole-brain SPM analyses and report voxelwise activation contrasts (not ROI-only, not resting-state, and not limited to between-group contrasts). Results are presented for the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only samples, or non-empirical paper) are met. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: Mindfulness training increases cooperative decision making in economic exchanges: Evidence from fMRI.
studies.abstract: Emotions have been shown to exert influences on decision making during economic exchanges. Here we investigate the underlying neural mechanisms of a training regimen which is hypothesized to promote emotional awareness, specifically mindfulness training (MT). We test the hypothesis that MT increases cooperative economic decision making using fMRI in a randomized longitudinal design involving 8weeks of either MT or active control training (CT). We find that MT results in an increased willingness to cooperate indexed by higher acceptance rates to unfair monetary offers in the Ultimatum Game. While controlling for acceptance rates of monetary offers between intervention groups, subjects in the MT and CT groups show differential brain activation patterns. Specifically, a subset of more cooperative MT subjects displays increased activation in the septal region, an area linked to social attachment, which may drive the increased willingness to express cooperative behavior in the MT cohort. Furthermore, MT resulted in attenuated activity in anterior insula compared with the CT group in response to unfair monetary offers post-training, which may suggest that MT enables greater ability to effectively regulate the anterior insula and thereby promotes social cooperation. Finally, functional connectivity analyses show a coupling between the septal region and posterior insula in the MT group, suggesting an integration of interoceptive inputs. Together, these results highlight that MT may be employed in contexts where emotional regulation is required to promote social cooperation.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was conducted while participants performed the Ultimatum Game, a social decision-making task assessing cooperation/response to others (social processing). The study involves healthy adult participants in a randomized longitudinal design (mindfulness vs control). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=51, ages within 18–65) using the Ultimatum Game, a social/economic exchange task probing social decision-making (perception/understanding of others, affiliation/prosocial behavior). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (conjunction, ANOVA, parametric regressions, whole-brain coordinates and FDR-corrected results) for the healthy participant groups (MT and CT), not limited to ROIs or connectivity only. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain, task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Creating buzz: the neural correlates of effective message propagation.
studies.abstract: Social interaction promotes the spread of values, attitudes, and behaviors. Here, we report on neural responses to ideas that are destined to spread. We scanned message communicators using functional MRI during their initial exposure to the to-be-communicated ideas. These message communicators then had the opportunity to spread the messages and their corresponding subjective evaluations to message recipients outside the scanner. Successful ideas were associated with neural responses in the communicators' mentalizing systems and reward systems when they first heard the messages, prior to spreading them. Similarly, individuals more able to spread their own views to others produced greater mentalizing-system activity during initial encoding. Unlike prior social-influence studies that focused on the individuals being influenced, this investigation focused on the brains of influencers. Successful social influence is reliably associated with an influencer-to-be's state of mind when first encoding ideas.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study scanning participants during exposure to messages about social influence; investigates social-related processes (mentalizing, reward) and influencer communication. Abstract does not state participant ages/health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social cognition/social communication in healthy adults (interns: N=19, mean age 20.55), examining mentalizing and reward networks during message-encoding and recommendation decisions. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects task-evoked analyses (threshold p < .005, k = 60) with coordinates and figures (Table 1, Fig. 1), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only results. Participants fall within the 18–65 range and results are reported for the healthy group. The task and reported outcomes clearly map onto social-related constructs (perspective taking/mentalizing, social communication). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: Effect of intentional bias on agency attribution of animated motion: an event-related fMRI study.
studies.abstract: Animated movements of simple geometric shapes can readily be interpreted as depicting social events in which animate agents are engaged in intentional activity. However, the brain regions associated with such intention have not been clearly elucidated. In this study, intentional bias was manipulated using shape and pattern animations while measuring associated brain activity using event-related functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). Twenty-five higher-intention involved and twenty-five lower-intention involved animations were presented to participants. Behavioral results showed that the degree of agency attribution of the mental state increased as intentional involvement increased. fMRI results revealed that the posterior superior temporal sulcus (STS), inferior temporal gyrus (ITG), inferior frontal gyrus (IFG), premotor, temporal pole, supramarginal gyrus, and superior parietal lobule (SPL) were activated while participants viewed the high-intention animations. In contrast, occipital, lingual, and middle frontal gyri were activated while the participants viewed the low-intention animations. These findings suggest that as agent attribution increases, the visual brain changes its functional role to the intentional brain and becomes a flexible network for processing information about social interaction.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Event-related fMRI was used while participants viewed animations manipulating intentionality (agency attribution)—a social perception/understanding task. Study reports neural correlates of attributing intention in (presumably) healthy adult participants (25 per condition). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (agency/intentionality attribution using Heider–Simmel–style animations). Sample includes healthy adult participants (n=12, mean age 25.2, within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (High>Low and Low>High) analyzed with SPM2 and thresholded at p<0.001 (uncorrected), with reported activation loci (STS, IFG, occipital regions, etc.). The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and reports unmasked healthy-group task activation maps/contrasts. No exclusion criteria are met, so the study should be included.

studies.title: Intact neural representations of affective meaning of touch but lack of embodied resonance in autism: a multi-voxel pattern analysis study.
studies.abstract: Humans can easily grasp the affective meaning of touch when observing social interactions. Several neural systems support this ability, including the theory of mind (ToM) network and the somatosensory system linked to embodied resonance, but it is unclear how these systems are affected in autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Individuals with ASD exhibit impairments in the use of nonverbal communication such as social and reciprocal touch. Despite the importance of touch in social communication and the reported touch aversion in ASD, surprisingly little is known about the neural systems underlying impairments in touch communication in ASD.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports an fMRI MVPA study of affective/social touch in autism but does not clearly state whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) participated or provide full task/sample details. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone—include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy participants and task specifics.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study uses task-based fMRI during a social-related task (observation of interpersonal touch) and explicitly investigates social cognition/affective processing. It includes a healthy adult neurotypical (NT) group reported separately (n=21). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task effects and provides mean group contrasts and MNI peak coordinates (referenced in main/supplementary files, e.g., Figure S2 and Table S2), not limited to ROI-only analyses. Thus it meets the meta-analysis criteria for task fMRI in healthy adults with whole-brain results.

studies.title: MDMA Increases Cooperation and Recruitment of Social Brain Areas When Playing Trustworthy Players in an Iterated Prisoner's Dilemma.
studies.abstract: Social decision-making is fundamental for successful functioning and can be affected in psychiatric illness and by serotoninergic modulation. The Prisoner's Dilemma is the archetypal paradigm to model cooperation and trust. However, the effect of serotonergic enhancement is poorly characterized, and its influence on the effect of variations in opponent behavior unknown. To address this, we conducted a study investigating how the serotonergic enhancer 3,4-methylenedioxy-methamphetamine (MDMA) modulates behavior and its neural correlates during an iterated Prisoner's Dilemma with both trustworthy and untrustworthy opponents. We administered 100 mg MDMA or placebo to 20 male participants in a double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study. While being scanned, participants played repeated rounds with opponents who differed in levels of cooperation. On each round, participants chose to compete or cooperate and were asked to rate their trust in the other player. Cooperation with trustworthy, but not untrustworthy, opponents was enhanced following MDMA but not placebo (respectively: odds ratio = 2.01; 95% CI, 1.42-2.84,
studies.journal: The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used while participants played an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma—a social decision-making task involving trust/cooperation. Study appears to involve healthy adult volunteers though ages/health not explicitly stated; include for full-text review to confirm participant health status and age range.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social decision-making (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy adult participants (N=20 males, age 21–37). The task is explicitly social (cooperation/trust), and the paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps: one-sample t tests for task phases (placebo session), flexible factorial and paired t tests examining treatment and opponent effects, thresholded at FWE cluster-corrected p<0.05. Results are reported for the healthy/control sample (within-subject design), with whole-brain activation tables and figures. All inclusion criteria are met (task fMRI, healthy adult sample, whole-brain group-level maps). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are provided).

studies.title: Age-related changes to the neural correlates of social evaluation.
studies.abstract: Recent work suggests the existence of a specialized neural system underlying social processing that may be relatively spared with age, unlike pervasive aging-related decline occurring in many cognitive domains. We investigated how neural mechanisms underlying social evaluation are engaged with age, and how age-related changes to socioemotional goals affect recruitment of regions within this network. In a functional MRI study, 15 young and 15 older adults formed behavior-based impressions of individuals. They also responded to a prompt that was interpersonally meaningful, social but interpersonally irrelevant, or non-social. Both age groups engaged regions implicated in mentalizing and impression formation when making social relative to non-social evaluations, including dorsal and ventral medial prefrontal cortices, precuneus, and temporoparietal junction. Older adults had increased activation over young in right temporal pole when making social relative to non-social evaluations, suggesting reliance on past experiences when evaluating others. Young adults had greater activation than old in posterior cingulate gyrus when making interpersonally irrelevant, compared to interpersonally meaningful, evaluations, potentially reflecting enhanced valuation of this information. The findings demonstrate the age-related preservation of the neural correlates underlying social evaluation, and suggest that functioning in these regions might be mediated by age-related changes in socioemotional goals.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study with healthy human participants performing social evaluation/impression-formation tasks (social vs non-social conditions). Includes young adult group (likely within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Therefore meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social evaluation/impression formation (social-meaningful and social-irrelevant vs non-social) using task-based BOLD imaging. It includes a healthy young adult group (ages 20–29) within the 18–65 inclusion range, with group-level analyses reported separately for age groups. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (social vs non-social; social-meaningful vs social-irrelevant), conjunctions, corrected cluster results, and peak coordinates—i.e., unmasked whole-brain activation maps rather than ROI-only or resting-state/connectivity-only analyses. Thus it satisfies the fMRI social task, healthy adult subgroup, and whole-brain evidence criteria; no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Sex differences in own and other body perception.
studies.abstract: Own body perception, and differentiating and comparing one's body to another person's body, are common cognitive functions that have relevance for self-identity and social interactions. In several psychiatric conditions, including anorexia nervosa, body dysmorphic disorder, gender dysphoria, and autism spectrum disorder, self and own body perception, as well as aspects of social communication are disturbed. Despite most of these conditions having skewed prevalence sex ratios, little is known about whether the neural basis of own body perception differs between the sexes. We addressed this question by investigating brain activation using functional magnetic resonance imaging during a Body Perception task in 15 male and 15 female healthy participants. Participants viewed their own body, bodies of same-sex, or opposite-sex other people, and rated the degree that they appeared like themselves. We found that men and women did not differ in the pattern of brain activation during own body perception compared to a scrambled control image. However, when viewing images of other bodies of same-sex or opposite-sex, men showed significantly stronger activations in attention-related and reward-related brain regions, whereas women engaged stronger activations in striatal, medial-prefrontal, and insular cortices, when viewing the own body compared to other images of the opposite sex. It is possible that other body images, particularly of the opposite sex, may be of greater salience for men, whereas images of own bodies may be more salient for women. These observations provide tentative neurobiological correlates to why women may be more vulnerable than men to conditions involving own body perception.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used fMRI during a Body Perception task probing perception/understanding of self and others (social-related processing). Sample comprised healthy adult participants (15 males, 15 females) within the target age range. Original empirical study, not a review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=30, mean age 26) that uses a social-related body perception task probing perception and understanding of self and others. The authors report whole-brain, voxelwise group-level task activation analyses (FEAT/FLAME) with thresholded Z-statistic maps and coordinate results for contrasts (e.g., own body > scrambled; same-sex and opposite-sex other bodies) clearly from the healthy/control sample. Analyses include within-group and between-sex comparisons and parametric whole-brain results. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and fits the review’s constructs (Perception/Understanding of Self and Others). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Common premotor regions for the perception and production of prosody and correlations with empathy and prosodic ability.
studies.abstract: Prosody, the melody and intonation of speech, involves the rhythm, rate, pitch and voice quality to relay linguistic and emotional information from one individual to another. A significant component of human social communication depends upon interpreting and responding to another person's prosodic tone as well as one's own ability to produce prosodic speech. However there has been little work on whether the perception and production of prosody share common neural processes, and if so, how these might correlate with individual differences in social ability.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Original research using fMRI examining perception and production of prosody and correlations with empathy—addresses social communication and perception of others in human participants. Not a review. Abstract does not state ages, but likely healthy adult sample; meets review objective. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of prosody perception and production, a form of social communication relevant to perception/understanding of others and empathy. Participants are healthy adults (n=19; ages 18–58). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., “happy‑neutral”, “question‑neutral”) analyzed with random-effects models and FDR/FWE thresholding and provides whole-brain results and coordinate lists and figures. The design is task-based (production and perception) rather than resting-state or connectivity-only. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole‑brain task fMRI of social-related processing.

studies.title: The Difference between Aesthetic Appreciation of Artistic and Popular Music: Evidence from an fMRI Study.
studies.abstract: To test the hypothesis that pleasure from artistic music is intellectual while that from popular music is physiological, this study investigated the different functional mechanisms between aesthetic appreciation of artistic and popular music using fMRI. 18 male non-musicians were scanned while they performed an aesthetic rating task for excerpts of artistic music, popular music and musical notes playing and singing (control). The rating scores of artistic and popular music excerpts were both significantly higher than that of control materials while the scores of them were not different. The fMRI results showed both artistic and popular conditions activated the VS and vmPFC, compared with control condition. When contrasted popular and artistic condition directly, we found popular music activated right putamen, while artistic music activated right mPFC. By parametric analysis, we found the activation of right putamen tracked the aesthetic ratings of popular music, whereas the BOLD signal in right mPFC tracked the aesthetic ratings of artistic music. These results indicate the reward induced by popular music is closer to a primary reward while that induced by artistic music is closer to a secondary reward. We also found artistic music activated ToM areas, including PCC/PC, arMFC and TPJ, when compared with popular music. And these areas also tracked aesthetic ratings of artistic music but not those of popular music. These results imply that the pleasure from former comes from cognitive empathy. In conclusion, this study gives clear neuronal evidences supporting the view that artistic music is of intelligence and social cognition involved while the popular music is of physiology.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing an aesthetic judgment task; authors report activation of Theory-of-Mind and social-cognition regions (PCC/PC, arMFC, TPJ) linked to artistic music appreciation, fitting ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ social processing.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=18, ages 18–24) that reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (Popular>Notes, Artistic>Notes, Popular>Artistic, Artistic>Popular) with voxelwise and cluster-level correction and coordinate tables. Although the task is aesthetic music appreciation rather than an explicit ToM task, the authors frame and demonstrate involvement of social-related processing (default mode/ToM and cognitive-empathy regions such as arMFC, PCC/PC, TPJ, hippocampus) and present whole-brain results for those contrasts in the healthy sample. Therefore it meets the sample, whole-brain reporting, and social-related processing relevance criteria (perception/understanding of others; cognitive empathy) for inclusion.

studies.title: Collective memory shapes the organization of individual memories in the medial prefrontal cortex.
studies.abstract: It has long been hypothesized that individual recollection fits collective memory. To look for a collective schema, we analysed the content of 30 years of media coverage of World War II on French national television. We recorded human brain activity using functional magnetic resonance imaging as participants recalled World War II displays at the Caen Memorial Museum following an initial tour. We focused on the medial prefrontal cortex, a key region for social cognition and memory schemas. The organization of individual memories captured using the distribution of the functional magnetic resonance imaging signal in the dorsal part of the medial prefrontal cortex was more accurately predicted by the structure of the collective schema than by various control models of contextual or semantic memory. Collective memory, which exists outside and beyond individuals, can also organize individual memories and constitutes a common mental model that connects people's memories across time and space.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was recorded while participants recalled World War II displays, a task probing collective/social memory and medial prefrontal social-cognitive processing. Abstract implies human participants likely healthy adults. Participant age/health not explicitly stated, so full text should be checked for eligibility; include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=24; ages 22–39) that uses a task-evoked paradigm (recall of pictured memorial items cued by captions) and directly investigates social-related constructs (collective memory, social schemas, narrative comprehension, representation of group viewpoints). The authors report group-level whole-brain analyses (surface-based searchlight with TFCE permutation correction) and ROI and whole-brain results linking dmPFC/vmPFC activity to collective/social representations. All inclusion criteria are met (healthy adult sample, task-based fMRI, and reported group-level whole-brain results). No exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: Mapping the information flow from one brain to another during gestural communication.
studies.abstract: Both the putative mirror neuron system (pMNS) and the ventral medial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC) are deemed important for social interaction: the pMNS because it supposedly "resonates" with the actions of others, the vmPFC because it is involved in mentalizing. Strictly speaking, the resonance property of the pMNS has never been investigated. Classical functional MRI experiments have only investigated whether pMNS regions augment their activity when an action is seen or executed. Resonance, however, entails more than only "going on and off together". Activity in the pMNS of an observer should continuously follow the more subtle changes over time in activity of the pMNS of the actor. Here we directly explore whether such resonance indeed occurs during continuous streams of actions. We let participants play the game of charades while we measured brain activity of both gesturer and guesser. We then applied a method to localize directed influences between the brains of the participants: between-brain Granger-causality mapping. Results show that a guesser's brain activity in regions involved in mentalizing and mirroring echoes the temporal structure of a gesturer's brain activity. This provides evidence for resonance theories and indicates a fine-grained temporal interplay between regions involved in motor planning and regions involved in thinking about the mental states of others. Furthermore, this method enables experiments to be more ecologically valid by providing the opportunity to leave social interaction unconstrained. This, in turn, would allow us to tap into the neural substrates of social deficits such as autism spectrum disorder.
studies.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study measuring brain activity during naturalistic social interaction (charades) between participants; addresses social communication and mirroring/mentalizing in humans. Not a review; likely healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of gestural social communication (charades) in healthy adult participants (n=18, mean age 27.5). The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses: traditional GLM-derived activations (used to define mirror ROIs) and whole-brain between-brain Granger-causality (bbGCM) maps thresholded at corrected significance. The task is clearly social-communication related, participants are within the 18–65 age range, and whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps are reported for the healthy group. It is not limited to ROI-only or resting-state/connectivity-only results. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Functional Subdomains within Scene-Selective Cortex: Parahippocampal Place Area, Retrosplenial Complex, and Occipital Place Area.
studies.abstract: Functional MRI studies suggest that at least three brain regions in human visual cortex-the parahippocampal place area (PPA), retrosplenial complex (RSC), and occipital place area (OPA; often called the transverse occipital sulcus)-represent large-scale information in natural scenes. Tuning of voxels within each region is often assumed to be functionally homogeneous. To test this assumption, we recorded blood oxygenation level-dependent responses during passive viewing of complex natural movies. We then used a voxelwise modeling framework to estimate voxelwise category tuning profiles within each scene-selective region. In all three regions, cluster analysis of the voxelwise tuning profiles reveals two functional subdomains that differ primarily in their responses to animals, man-made objects, social communication, and movement. Thus, the conventional functional definitions of the PPA, RSC, and OPA appear to be too coarse. One attractive hypothesis is that this consistent functional subdivision of scene-selective regions is a reflection of an underlying anatomical organization into two separate processing streams, one selectively biased toward static stimuli and one biased toward dynamic stimuli.
studies.journal: The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used fMRI during passive viewing of natural movies and reports voxel responses to ‘social communication’ categories, indicating social-related processing. Abstract lacks explicit participant age and detailed task description; include for full-text review to confirm participant characteristics and whether the paradigm fits inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Study collected fMRI data in healthy adult participants (n=6, ages ~26), used whole-brain voxelwise encoding models, and reports group-level voxelwise/ cortical-surface results (e.g., category tuning maps, PC projections, statistical tests) rather than only ROI-restricted analyses. Although the paradigm was passive viewing of natural movies rather than an explicit social task, the analyses explicitly quantify and test responses to social-related categories (e.g., social communication, humans, body parts, animals) and report significant group-level effects. The paper provides whole-brain voxelwise evidence of social-relevant category processing in healthy adults and thus meets the review’s inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Neural Modulation in Aversive Emotion Processing: An Independent Component Analysis Study.
studies.abstract: Emotional processing has an important role in social interaction. We report the findings about the Independent Component Analysis carried out on a fMRI set obtained with a paradigm of face emotional processing. The results showed that an independent component, mainly cerebellar-medial-frontal, had a positive modulation associated with fear processing. Also, another independent component, mainly parahippocampal-prefrontal, showed a negative modulation that could be associated with implicit reappraisal of emotional stimuli. Independent Component Analysis could serve as a method to understand complex cognitive processes and their underlying neural dynamics.
studies.journal: Computational and mathematical methods in medicine
studies.abstract_screening_reason: The study uses fMRI with a face emotional processing paradigm, which is a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and ages.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study uses task-based fMRI of a social-related paradigm (Face Matching Task assessing perception of others’ emotional faces). The sample is a healthy adult group (n=10, mean age 25 ±5.3), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain GLM task results (second-level one-sample t-tests; contrasts such as fear>neutral; coordinates and tables provided in Supplementary Material: Table S2, Figures S1–S3), satisfying the requirement for an unmasked healthy-group whole-brain task activation map. The paper also includes ICA results, but whole-brain task-evoked maps are clearly reported, and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, seed-only, resting-state-only, non-empirical) apply. Therefore it should be INCLUDED.

studies.title: Altered brain activity and the effect of personality traits in excessive smartphone use during facial emotion processing.
studies.abstract: Excessive smartphone use is a phenomenon related to maladaptive smartphone use, leading to negative consequences. This study set out with the aim of assessing the effects of excessive smartphone use on behavioral and neural responses during facial emotional processing. We examined 25 excessive smartphone users and 27 normal control users using functional MRI during facial emotion processing and investigated Behavioral Inhibition System/Behavioral Activation System (BIS/BAS). The excessive smartphone use group (SP) showed neural deactivation in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) and dorsal anterior cingulate cortex (dACC) during the presentation of an angry face and emotional transition compared to that of the normal control group (NC). Additionally, the SP revealed neural deactivation of the superior temporal sulcus and temporo-parietal junction related to social interaction during emotional transition compared to the NC. We found that BAS-Reward Responsiveness level was correlated with behavioral responses during repeated happy faces related to emotional reward in SP compared to NC. It can thus be suggested that excessive smartphone use is likely to fail on cognitive control during emotional processing, and this impairment might be influenced on emotional processing related to social interaction.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used during facial emotion processing, which is social-related (perception/understanding of others). Study includes a healthy control group of adults and is an original research article (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of facial emotion discrimination, a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). Sample includes healthy adult control group (ages 19–35) reported separately from the excessive smartphone group. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked results (cluster tables with FWE-corrected p-values and >100 voxels) including within-group contrasts for the normal control (NC) group (e.g., NC activations for AH vs HH), not limited to ROI-only analyses. Imaging methods and whole-brain statistical maps/coordinates are described. Age range and healthy control reporting meet inclusion criteria; the study is empirical with original task-based fMRI data. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Psychopathic traits and deception: functional magnetic resonance imaging study.
studies.abstract: There is relatively little existing information regarding the neural correlates of deception in individuals with psychopathic traits.
studies.journal: The British journal of psychiatry : the journal of mental science
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of deception, which involves social-cognitive processing. Abstract does not specify whether healthy adults (ages 17–65) were included or participant details. Insufficient information to determine eligibility—include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of deception (a social behavior involving understanding/manipulation of others) using a task-based design in a healthy adult sample (24 males, ages 19–60). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise task contrasts (lie vs truth) with whole-brain statistical maps/cluster results (thresholded maps reported in tables/figures) and also applies small-volume corrections for ROIs. Results for the healthy/control group are presented directly (main effects and correlations). Age range and participant health meet inclusion criteria, and the study is empirical with original task-evoked fMRI data. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, or non-healthy-only samples) are violated.
