studies.title: A common cortical metric for spatial, temporal, and social distance.
studies.abstract: Distance describes more than physical space: we speak of close friends and distant relatives, and of the near future and distant past. Did these ubiquitous spatial metaphors arise in language coincidentally or did they arise because they are rooted in a common neural computation? To address this question, we used statistical pattern recognition techniques to analyze human fMRI data. First, a machine learning algorithm was trained to discriminate patterns of fMRI responses based on relative egocentric distance within trials from one distance domain (e.g., photographs of objects relatively close to or far away from the viewer in spatial distance trials). Next, we tested whether the decision boundary generated from this training could distinguish brain responses according to relative egocentric distance within each of two separate distance domains (e.g., phrases referring to the immediate or more remote future within temporal distance trials; photographs of participants' friends or acquaintances within social distance trials). This procedure was repeated using all possible combinations of distance domains for training and testing the classifier. In all cases, above-chance decoding across distance domains was possible in the right inferior parietal lobule (IPL). Furthermore, the representational similarity structure within this brain area reflected participants' own judgments of spatial distance, temporal soon-ness, and social familiarity. Thus, the right IPL may contain a parsimonious encoding of proximity to self in spatial, temporal, and social frames of reference.
studies.journal: The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study that explicitly includes a social-distance task (photographs of friends vs acquaintances) probing social familiarity/proximity to self. This addresses social processing in humans and likely involves healthy adult participants, meeting inclusion criteria for full review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This fMRI study tested social processing (social distance trials using participants' friends vs acquaintances; names and photographs) in a task context relevant to perception/understanding of others. Sample: healthy adults (n=15, ages 20–28), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain searchlight MVPA and RSA analyses with statistical maps aligned to standard space and thresholded across participants (conjunction analyses, FDR-corrected clusters reported in tables/figures), which constitute voxelwise task-evoked, whole-brain results from the healthy group. Analyses are not ROI-only, nor are they resting-state or connectivity-only. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Cerebral differences in explicit and implicit emotional processing--an fMRI study.
studies.abstract: The processing of emotional facial expression is a major part of social communication and understanding. In addition to explicit processing, facial expressions are also processed rapidly and automatically in the absence of explicit awareness. We investigated 12 healthy subjects by presenting them with an implicit and explicit emotional paradigm. The subjects reacted significantly faster in implicit than in explicit trials but did not differ in their error ratio. For the implicit condition increased signals were observed in particular in the thalami, the hippocampi, the frontal inferior gyri and the right middle temporal region. The analysis of the explicit condition showed increased blood-oxygen-level-dependent signals especially in the caudate nucleus, the cingulum and the right prefrontal cortex. The direct comparison of these 2 different processes revealed increased activity for explicit trials in the inferior, superior and middle frontal gyri, the middle cingulum and left parietal regions. Additional signal increases were detected in occipital regions, the cerebellum, and the right angular and lingual gyrus. Our data partially confirm the hypothesis of different neural substrates for the processing of implicit and explicit emotional stimuli.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=12) performing implicit and explicit emotional facial-expression tasks, which are social communication/perception processes. Meets inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy adults). Not a review or meta-analysis.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult subjects (N=12) that investigates processing of emotional facial expressions — a social-communication/social-perception task relevant to the review objective. The abstract reports BOLD signal increases across multiple brain regions for implicit and explicit conditions and direct comparisons, indicating group-level whole-brain task-evoked activation results (not limited to ROIs). No exclusion criteria are triggered (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, includes healthy adults). Age range is not explicitly reported but participants are described as healthy subjects (adult sample). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI evidence in healthy adults, with minor uncertainty due to lack of explicit ages reported.

studies.title: Learning-induced plasticity in medial prefrontal cortex predicts preference malleability.
studies.abstract: Learning induces plasticity in neuronal networks. As neuronal populations contribute to multiple representations, we reasoned plasticity in one representation might influence others. We used human fMRI repetition suppression to show that plasticity induced by learning another individual's values impacts upon a value representation for oneself in medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC), a plasticity also evident behaviorally in a preference shift. We show this plasticity is driven by a striatal "prediction error," signaling the discrepancy between the other's choice and a subject's own preferences. Thus, our data highlight that mPFC encodes agent-independent representations of subjective value, such that prediction errors simultaneously update multiple agents' value representations. As the resulting change in representational similarity predicts interindividual differences in the malleability of subjective preferences, our findings shed mechanistic light on complex human processes such as the powerful influence of social interaction on beliefs and preferences.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Human fMRI study examining how learning about another person's values alters value representations and preferences (social influence). Involves social-related processing (perception/understanding of others) in humans; not a review. Likely healthy adult participants. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (fMRI sample n=29, mean age 25.6) investigating social-related processing (learning about others’ inter-temporal preferences, social influence, perception/understanding of others). The task required evaluating choices for self and others during fMRI and interleaved probe trials. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts and cluster-level FWE-corrected results (including coordinates and whole-brain contrasts testing repetition suppression and surprise signals in mPFC, striatum, pMFC), not limited to ROI-only analyses. No exclusion criteria apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion requirements for the review.

studies.title: Valuating other people's emotional face expression: a combined functional magnetic resonance imaging and electroencephalography study.
studies.abstract: Reading the facial expression of other people is a fundamental skill for social interaction. Human facial expressions of emotions are readily recognized but may also evoke the same experiential emotional state in the observer. We used event-related functional magnetic resonance imaging and multi-channel electroencephalography to determine in 14 right-handed healthy volunteers (29+/-6 years) which brain structures mediate the perception of such a shared experiential emotional state. Statistical parametric mapping showed that an area in the dorsal medial frontal cortex was specifically activated during the perception of emotions that reflected the seen happy and sad emotional face expressions. This area mapped to the pre-supplementary motor area which plays a central role in control of behavior. Low resolution brain electromagnetic tomography-based analysis of the encephalographic data revealed that the activation was detected 100 ms after face presentation onset lasting until 740 ms. Our observation substantiates recently emerging evidence suggesting that the subjective perception of an experiential emotional state-empathy-is mediated by the involvement of the dorsal medial frontal cortex.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Functional MRI was performed in 14 healthy adults (mean age 29±6) while they perceived others' emotional facial expressions—clearly a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study used task-based fMRI (event-related fMRI) during perception of others’ emotional facial expressions, a social cognitive task (perception/understanding of others/empathy). The sample comprises 14 healthy adult volunteers (mean age 29±6), within the 18–65 range. The abstract reports statistical parametric mapping results identifying activation in dorsal medial frontal cortex (pre-SMA) during emotion perception, indicating group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked analyses rather than ROI-only results. No exclusion criteria apply (not connectivity-only, not patient-only, and not non-empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing.

studies.title: Neural correlates of direct and reflected self-appraisals in adolescents and adults: when social perspective-taking informs self-perception.
studies.abstract: Classic theories of self-development suggest people define themselves in part through internalized perceptions of other people's beliefs about them, known as reflected self-appraisals. This study uses functional magnetic resonance imaging to compare the neural correlates of direct and reflected self-appraisals in adolescence (N = 12, ages 11-14 years) and adulthood (N = 12, ages 23-30 years). During direct self-reflection, adolescents demonstrated greater activity than adults in networks relevant to self-perception (medial prefrontal and parietal cortices) and social-cognition (dorsomedial prefrontal cortex, temporal-parietal junction, and posterior superior temporal sulcus), suggesting adolescent self-construals may rely more heavily on others' perspectives about the self. Activity in the medial fronto-parietal network was also enhanced when adolescents took the perspective of someone more relevant to a given domain.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of direct and reflected self-appraisals (social-related: perception/understanding of self) that includes a healthy adult group aged 23–30, meeting the inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This fMRI study includes a healthy adult group (N=12; ages 22.6–30.4) within the 18–65 range, uses task-based fMRI of social-related processing (direct and reflected self-appraisals: perception/understanding of self and others), and reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses and contrasts for the adults (e.g., one-sample t tests, conjunctions, and ANOVAs with whole-brain correction and reported coordinates/clusters). Results for the healthy adult group are presented separately and are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/rest analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Toward Task Connectomics: Examining Whole-Brain Task Modulated Connectivity in Different Task Domains.
studies.abstract: Human brain anatomical and resting-state functional connectivity have been comprehensively portrayed using MRI, which are termed anatomical and functional connectomes. A systematic examination of tasks modulated whole brain functional connectivity, which we term as task connectome, is still lacking. We analyzed 6 block-designed and 1 event-related designed functional MRI data, and examined whole-brain task modulated connectivity in various task domains, including emotion, reward, language, relation, social cognition, working memory, and inhibition. By using psychophysiological interaction between pairs of regions from the whole brain, we identified statistically significant task modulated connectivity in 4 tasks between their experimental and respective control conditions. Task modulated connectivity was found not only between regions that were activated during the task but also regions that were not activated or deactivated, suggesting a broader involvement of brain regions in a task than indicated by simple regional activations. Decreased functional connectivity was observed in all the 4 tasks and sometimes reduced connectivity was even between regions that were both activated during the task. This suggests that brain regions that are activated together do not necessarily work together. The current study demonstrates the comprehensive task connectomes of 4 tasks, and suggested complex relationships between regional activations and connectivity changes.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports task-based fMRI including a social cognition task domain. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so eligibility cannot be confirmed. Include for full-text review to verify presence of healthy adult participants (ages 17–65) and other eligibility details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study reports task fMRI in healthy adult samples (HCP: n≈93–97 per task, ages 22–36+; UCLA stop-signal: n=114, ages 21–50), all within the 18–65 range. It includes a social cognition task (social interaction vs. random movement) which clearly targets perception/understanding of others. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked activation analyses (voxel-wise GLMs and figures showing ROI-wise/voxelwise activations; Figure 1 and Supplementary materials), with effects described for the healthy/control participants. Although the paper emphasizes connectivity (PPI/BSC), it explicitly reports whole-brain activation maps and group-level contrasts for the healthy samples. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level task activations) and does not violate exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Differential brain responses to social exclusion by one's own versus opposite-gender peers.
studies.abstract: Human peer relations provide tangible benefits, including food and protection, as well as emotional benefits. While social exclusion poses a threat to all of these benefits, the psychological threat is particularly susceptible to modulation by the relation of the excluders to the excluded person. The current study used functional magnetic resonance imaging to explore the effects of manipulating the gender relation of participants to their excluders during an interactive ball-toss game. Ventral anterior cingulate cortex activation was higher during exclusion by same-gender peers, while right ventrolateral prefrontal cortex activation negatively correlated with self-reported distress in other-gender exclusion. Results imply that exclusion by one's own gender is fundamentally different from exclusion by the opposite gender, and suggest a regulatory role for ventrolateral prefrontal cortex in response to out-group exclusion. Individual differences in implicit gender attitudes modulated neural responses to exclusion. The importance of these findings to investigations of social cognition is discussed.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used functional MRI during an interactive social exclusion (ball-toss) task examining peer relations and neural responses in (presumably) healthy adult participants. This directly assesses social-related processing (affiliation/peer exclusion) and is not a review or meta-analysis, meeting inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (social exclusion/Cyberball) in healthy adult participants (final N=20, ages ~25). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects contrasts (e.g., social exclusion > fair play collapsed across gender; same- vs other-gender exclusion) with voxelwise results, cluster-correction, coordinate tables, and figures. Although ROI analyses are also presented, whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy adult group are clearly reported. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: Self-Other Mergence in the Frontal Cortex during Cooperation and Competition.
studies.abstract: To survive, humans must estimate their own ability and the abilities of others. We found that, although people estimated their abilities on the basis of their own performance in a rational manner, their estimates of themselves were partly merged with the performance of others. Reciprocally, their ability estimates for others also reflected their own, as well as the others', performance. Self-other mergence operated in a context-dependent manner: interacting with high or low performers, respectively, enhanced and diminished own ability estimates in cooperative contexts, but the opposite occurred in competitive contexts. Self-other mergence not only influenced subjective evaluations, it also affected how people subsequently objectively adjusted their performance. Perigenual anterior cingulate cortex tracked one's own performance. Dorsomedial frontal area 9 tracked others' performances, but also integrated contextual and self-related information. Self-other mergence increased with the strength of self and other representations in area 9, suggesting it carries interdependent representations of self and other.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports neural tracking in frontal cortex during social interactions (cooperation/competition) and self–other representations, consistent with an fMRI social-processing task in healthy adults. The abstract does not explicitly state imaging modality or participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing (cooperation/competition; self–other judgments) in healthy adults (final sample N=24, age 19–31). The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain voxelwise analyses (GLM whole-brain results identifying pgACC and area 9 and related effects) rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only findings. No clinical/special-group results are required and the healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly described. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

activation_tables.table_foot: Family-wise error cluster corrected, z > 2.5, p < 0.05.

studies.title: Attributing awareness to oneself and to others.
studies.abstract: This study tested the possible relationship between reported visual awareness ("I see a visual stimulus in front of me") and the social attribution of awareness to someone else ("That person is aware of an object next to him"). Subjects were tested in two steps. First, in an fMRI experiment, subjects were asked to attribute states of awareness to a cartoon face. Activity associated with this task was found bilaterally within the temporoparietal junction (TPJ) among other areas. Second, the TPJ was transiently disrupted using single-pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS). When the TMS was targeted to the same cortical sites that had become active during the social attribution task, the subjects showed symptoms of visual neglect in that their detection of visual stimuli was significantly affected. In control trials, when TMS was targeted to nearby cortical sites that had not become active during the social attribution task, no significant effect on visual detection was found. These results suggest that there may be at least some partial overlap in brain mechanisms that participate in the social attribution of sensory awareness to other people and in attributing sensory awareness to oneself.
studies.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports an fMRI experiment where subjects attributed awareness to a cartoon face—a social attribution task (perception/understanding of others). fMRI was conducted during the task in human participants (presumably healthy adults). No exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task is a social-related fMRI task (subjects judged another’s awareness—perception/understanding of others). (2) Sample includes healthy adult participants (group of 50 healthy adults, ages 18–49; fMRI group results are reported for this healthy group). (3) Whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task activation maps/contrasts are reported (H trials − E trials contrast across all 50 subjects, thresholded P<0.05 corrected; Talairach coordinates provided in Table 1 and figures). Study is empirical and not ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient-only. Therefore it qualifies for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.
studies.full_text_path: /home/zorro/repos/autonima-results/social-processing/ace_scrape/articles/html/Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America/24639542.html

studies.title: Dehumanizing the lowest of the low: neuroimaging responses to extreme out-groups.
studies.abstract: Traditionally, prejudice has been conceptualized as simple animosity. The stereotype content model (SCM) shows that some prejudice is worse. The SCM previously demonstrated separate stereotype dimensions of warmth (low-high) and competence (low-high), identifying four distinct out-group clusters. The SCM predicts that only extreme out-groups, groups that are both stereotypically hostile and stereotypically incompetent (low warmth, low competence), such as addicts and the homeless, will be dehumanized. Prior studies show that the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) is necessary for social cognition. Functional magnetic resonance imaging provided data for examining brain activations in 10 participants viewing 48 photographs of social groups and 12 participants viewing objects; each picture dependably represented one SCM quadrant. Analyses revealed mPFC activation to all social groups except extreme (low-low) out-groups, who especially activated insula and amygdala, a pattern consistent with disgust, the emotion predicted by the SCM. No objects, though rated with the same emotions, activated the mPFC. This neural evidence supports the prediction that extreme out-groups may be perceived as less than human, or dehumanized.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study measuring neural responses while participants viewed social-group photographs (social perception/understanding of others). Results report brain activations relevant to social cognition. Although ages/health status are not explicitly stated, the abstract clearly meets the social-related fMRI criterion; include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and health.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study is an empirical fMRI investigation of social cognition in healthy adult participants (Princeton undergraduates, mean age 19.5). It uses task-based fMRI during social-affective judgments (SCM emotions) and reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses with voxelwise contrasts and Talairach coordinates (e.g., mPFC, insula, amygdala activations, t-values, voxel counts). Results are reported for the healthy control/participant group (not limited to an ROI-only analysis), and the paper presents unmasked whole-brain task-evoked effects. No exclusion criteria apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: The missing link: mothers' neural response to infant cry related to infant attachment behaviors.
studies.abstract: This study addresses a gap in the attachment literature by investigating maternal neural response to cry related to infant attachment classifications and behaviors. Twenty-two primiparous mothers and their 18-month old infants completed the Strange Situation (SS) procedure to elicit attachment behaviors. During a separate functional MRI session, mothers were exposed to their own infant's cry sound, as well as an unfamiliar infant's cry and control sound. Maternal neural response to own infant cry related to both overall attachment security and specific infant behaviors. Mothers of less secure infants maintained greater activation to their cry in left parahippocampal and amygdala regions and the right posterior insula consistent with a negative schematic response bias. Mothers of infants exhibiting more avoidant or contact maintaining behaviors during the SS showed diminished response across left prefrontal, parietal, and cerebellar areas involved in attentional processing and cognitive control. Mothers of infants exhibiting more disorganized behavior showed reduced response in bilateral temporal and subcallosal areas relevant to social cognition and emotion regulation. No differences by attachment classification were found. Implications for attachment transmission models are discussed.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used fMRI while adult mothers listened to their own/unfamiliar infant cry—a social/attachment-related task. Participants are adult primiparous mothers with no indication of psychiatric/neurological disorders. Fits inclusion criteria (social processing in healthy adults, ages likely 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of maternal social/attachment processing (listening to own infant’s cry), which fits the social-related task domain (Affiliation/Attachment). Participants are healthy adults (mothers; mean age 24.1 years, within 18–65); although some had prior perinatal MDE or current SSRI use, none met criteria for a major depressive episode at the time of scanning and depressive symptom effects were tested/controlled. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (own cry > control/other contrasts) with cluster-level results and MNI coordinates (Table 1) using whole-brain FDR correction. Thus it provides the required whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps. Caveat: sample is a convenience/high-risk motherhood sample (includes past perinatal depression history and 3 medicated participants) and analyses are from the combined sample rather than a separate “healthy-only” subgroup, but the reported group-level whole-brain results meet inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Differential inter-subject correlation of brain activity when kinship is a variable in moral dilemma.
studies.abstract: Previous behavioural studies have shown that humans act more altruistically towards kin. Whether and how knowledge of genetic relatedness translates into differential neurocognitive evaluation of observed social interactions has remained an open question. Here, we investigated how the human brain is engaged when viewing a moral dilemma between genetic vs. non-genetic sisters. During functional magnetic resonance imaging, a movie was shown, depicting refusal of organ donation between two sisters, with subjects guided to believe the sisters were related either genetically or by adoption. Although 90% of the subjects self-reported that genetic relationship was not relevant, their brain activity told a different story. Comparing correlations of brain activity across all subject pairs between the two viewing conditions, we found significantly stronger inter-subject correlations in insula, cingulate, medial and lateral prefrontal, superior temporal, and superior parietal cortices, when the subjects believed that the sisters were genetically related. Cognitive functions previously associated with these areas include moral and emotional conflict regulation, decision making, and mentalizing, suggesting more similar engagement of such functions when observing refusal of altruism from a genetic sister. Our results show that mere knowledge of a genetic relationship between interacting persons robustly modulates social cognition of the perceiver.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study where participants viewed a moral/social interaction (kinship and altruism) — clearly a social-related task. Likely healthy adult subjects; abstract does not state ages, but no exclusion criteria (e.g., review or patient-only sample) are met. Abstract lacks explicit age/health details, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (moral dilemma/kinship and a moral-decision task). Participants: healthy adult sample (N=30; females aged 19–39), meeting the 18–65 requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses: inter-subject correlation (ISC) maps across the whole brain with FDR correction and cluster reporting, and a separate GLM whole-brain analysis of the moral-dilemma decision task (group-level contrasts, corrected, with tables of clusters/coordinates and neurovault link). Results are reported for the healthy sample (no mixed clinical groups). The study is neither ROI-only nor resting-state/connectivity-only and provides unmasked whole-brain task effects for the healthy group. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

studies.title: The neural correlates of emotional prosody comprehension: disentangling simple from complex emotion.
studies.abstract: Emotional prosody comprehension (EPC), the ability to interpret another person's feelings by listening to their tone of voice, is crucial for effective social communication. Previous studies assessing the neural correlates of EPC have found inconsistent results, particularly regarding the involvement of the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC). It remained unclear whether the involvement of the mPFC is linked to an increased demand in socio-cognitive components of EPC such as mental state attribution and if basic perceptual processing of EPC can be performed without the contribution of this region.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract investigates neural correlates of emotional prosody comprehension, a social-communication task involving perception/understanding of others. It implies neuroimaging of task-related processing. Participant health and explicit mention of fMRI are not provided, so include for full-text review to confirm methods and sample.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=19, ages 18–51) that investigates emotional prosody comprehension, a social-cognition process (perception/understanding of others’ emotions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise statistical contrasts (emotional vs neutral; complex vs simple emotions) analyzed with SPM8 and corrected for multiple comparisons, with coordinates and activation maps described. It is not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses, and the healthy adult group results are reported directly. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Functional parcellation of the human primary somatosensory cortex to natural touch.
studies.abstract: Despite the significance of human touch, brain responses to interpersonal manual touch have been rarely investigated. We used functional magnetic resonance imaging to study brain activity in eight healthy adults whose left hand was touched by two individuals, in separate runs and in 20-s blocks, either by holding, smoothing, or poking. Acceleration was measured from both the subject's and the touching person's hands for postimaging control of the stimuli. Independent component analysis of the functional magnetic resonance imaging data unraveled three functional networks involving the primary somatosensory cortex (SI). One network comprised the contralateral and another the ipsilateral Brodmann area 3. The third network included area 2 bilaterally, left-hemisphere middle temporal gyrus and dorsolateral prefrontal regions, ventral prefrontal cortices bilaterally, and middle cingulate cortex. The response shapes and polarities varied between the three networks. The contralateral area 3 differentiated the responses between the three types of touch stimuli, and the response magnitudes depended on the variability of the touch within each block. However, the responses of the other two networks were strikingly similar to all stimuli. The subjects' reports on the pleasantness of the touch did not correlate with the characteristics of the SI responses. These findings imply area-specific processing of the natural human touch in three networks including the SI cortex, with only area 2 connected to a functional network of brain areas that may support social interaction.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study in healthy adults using interpersonal (human) touch — a social stimulus—examining SI networks including areas tied to social interaction. Abstract lacks explicit ages but meets social-processing task criterion; include for full-text to confirm details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=8, ages 22–39) where natural interpersonal touch (another person touching the subject) was the experimental manipulation — a social-related stimulus relevant to social perception/communication. The authors report group-level whole-brain voxelwise spatial maps derived from group ICA (thresholded z-maps) that identify task-related components in the primary somatosensory cortex and wider networks, and they present corresponding group-level statistical comparisons of component time courses. The paper is not ROI-only, not purely resting-state/seed-connectivity, and the whole-brain task-related maps are clearly from the healthy/control sample. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

studies.title: How spontaneous brain activity and narcissistic features shape social interaction.
studies.abstract: There is an increasing interest in how ongoing spontaneous brain activity and personality provide a predisposition for the processing of environmental demands. It further has been suggested that the brain has an inherent sensitivity to the social environment. Here we tested in healthy volunteers if spontaneous brain activity contributes to a predisposition for social behavior and how this is modulated by narcissistic personality features associated with poor interpersonal functioning. Functional magnetic resonance imaging included a resting state and an experimental paradigm focusing on the anticipation of actively touching an animate (human hand) versus an inanimate target (mannequin hand). The experimental task induced a significant modulation of neural activity in left postcentral gyrus (PostCG), right culmen and, co-varying with narcissistic features, in right anterior insula (AI). Neural activity in anticipation of the animate target significantly correlated with spontaneous activity during the resting state indexed by the Power Law Exponent (PLE) in PostCG and AI. Finally, the correlation between spontaneous and task-induced activity in AI was mediated by narcissistic features. These findings provide novel evidence for a relationship between intrinsic brain activity and social behavior and show how personality could contribute to individual differences in our predisposition to approach the animate world.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used with an experimental task contrasting anticipation of touching an animate (human) versus inanimate target, which is social-related processing. Participants were healthy volunteers within target adult range. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study reports task-based fMRI of social-related processing (anticipation of touching an animate vs inanimate target). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=32, ages 21–33; task data in 21 participants but healthy adult group reported). The paper presents group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (paired-sample t-test: anticipation animate vs inanimate; whole-brain analyses with PNI covariates) with FDR-corrected statistical maps and reported coordinates/clusters. Although additional resting-state analyses (PLE, DFA) are included, the study provides unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task activation results rather than only ROI or connectivity analyses. Age range and healthy-group reporting meet inclusion criteria. Therefore it qualifies for inclusion.

studies.title: Potential for social involvement modulates activity within the mirror and the mentalizing systems.
studies.abstract: Processing biological motion is fundamental for everyday life activities, such as social interaction, motor learning and nonverbal communication. The ability to detect the nature of a motor pattern has been investigated by means of point-light displays (PLD), sets of moving light points reproducing human kinematics, easily recognizable as meaningful once in motion. Although PLD are rudimentary, the human brain can decipher their content including social intentions. Neuroimaging studies suggest that inferring the social meaning conveyed by PLD could rely on both the Mirror Neuron System (MNS) and the Mentalizing System (MS), but their specific role to this endeavor remains uncertain. We describe a functional magnetic resonance imaging experiment in which participants had to judge whether visually presented PLD and videoclips of human-like walkers (HL) were facing towards or away from them. Results show that coding for stimulus direction specifically engages the MNS when considering PLD moving away from the observer, while the nature of the stimulus reveals a dissociation between MNS -mainly involved in coding for PLD- and MS, recruited by HL moving away. These results suggest that the contribution of the two systems can be modulated by the nature of the observed stimulus and its potential for social involvement.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI experiment in healthy participants assessing social-related processing (inferring social intentions from biological motion/point-light displays and human-like walkers). Task targets perception/understanding of others; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI task study of social perception (perception/understanding of others via body motion and potential for social involvement) in healthy adults (N=16, mean age 22.8). The paper reports group-level task contrasts (main effects and interactions) and provides stereotaxic coordinates of BOLD peaks and statistical details in the text/tables from the healthy group. Although analyses focus on mirror-neuron and mentalizing masks, contrasts were computed at the second level and results are reported voxelwise (coordinate tables and thresholded statistical maps within masks), satisfying the requirement for group-level voxelwise task-evoked results from healthy participants. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-empirical, outside age range) apply. Therefore the study meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria as an fMRI task activation study of social processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Gender-selective neural populations: evidence from event-related fMRI repetition suppression.
studies.abstract: Accurate recognition of gender in another individual is integral to successful human social interaction and to mate selection. When we encounter another person, we are effortlessly able to identify their gender, most often through the information conveyed by their facial features. Faces comprise the most abundantly encountered cue used to classify human gender. Considering the importance of facial information in gender perception, relatively little is known about the mechanisms involved in perceiving gender through human facial cues. We used an event-related fMRI repetition suppression paradigm to explore the neural circuitry underlying gender perception from facial information. Participants viewed brief consecutive images consisting of either gender-same face pairings (two male faces or two female faces) or images of gender-different face pairings (a male face preceded or followed by a female face), while attending to facial attractiveness in both conditions. Using a region-of-interest approach, we found repetition suppression on gender-same trials within the left ventral temporal fusiform gyrus and in the right collateral sulcus. Whole-brain voxel-wise analyses revealed selectivity for face gender again in the right collateral sulcus, in addition to the left cuneus and the right lateral occipital gyrus. Our results indicate that in addition to the face-selective FFA, cortical areas that are not traditionally considered to be "face-selective" are involved in the perception of gender-based facial cues.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Event-related fMRI measuring perception of others' gender from faces constitutes social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). The abstract reports a human fMRI task and implies healthy adult participants; it is an original empirical study (not a review). Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health status.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an event-related fMRI task study of facial gender perception — a form of social perception (perception/understanding of others). Sample: healthy adults aged 19–42 (N=16 recruited, N=15 analyzed), within 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxel-wise analyses (gender-different > gender-same) with cluster-corrected thresholds and lists activated clusters/coordinates (right collateral sulcus, left precuneus, right lateral occipital gyrus, etc.). Thus it provides healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked maps. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, not non-empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Targeting dynamic facial processing mechanisms in superior temporal sulcus using a novel fMRI neurofeedback target.
studies.abstract: The superior temporal sulcus (STS) encompasses a complex set of regions involved in a wide range of cognitive functions. To understand its functional properties, neuromodulation approaches such brain stimulation or neurofeedback can be used. We investigated whether the posterior STS (pSTS), a core region in the face perception and imagery network, could be specifically identified based on the presence of dynamic facial expressions (and not just on simple motion or static face signals), and probed with neurofeedback. Recognition of facial expressions is critically impaired in autism spectrum disorder, making this region a relevant target for future clinical neurofeedback studies. We used a stringent localizer approach based on the contrast of dynamic facial expressions against static neutral faces plus moving dots. The target region had to be specifically responsive to dynamic facial expressions instead of mere motion and/or the presence of a static face. The localizer was successful in selecting this region across subjects. Neurofeedback was then performed, using this region as a target, with two novel feedback rules (mean or derivative-based, using visual or auditory interfaces). Our results provide evidence that a facial expression-selective cluster in pSTS can be identified and may represent a suitable target for neurofeedback approaches, aiming at social and emotional cognition. These findings highlight the presence of a highly selective region in STS encoding dynamic aspects of facial expressions. Future studies should elucidate its role as a mechanistic target for neurofeedback strategies in clinical disorders of social cognition such as autism.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study uses dynamic facial-expression vs static-face/motion localizer and performs neurofeedback targeting pSTS — a social perception task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65).
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study reports task-based fMRI targeting dynamic facial expression processing (social perception of others) and uses a dynamic face-expression localizer contrast (dynamic facial expressions > static neutral faces + moving dots), which is a social-related task. The paper explicitly states the localizer successfully identified a pSTS cluster across subjects and uses group-level random-effects analyses (RFX), indicating whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task contrasts rather than only ROI or connectivity results. Participants are typical subjects (healthy adult sample used for neurofeedback), and results are reported for the healthy group. The study therefore meets: (1) social-related fMRI task, (2) healthy adult sample, and (3) whole-brain group-level task activation map reporting. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, non-empirical) apply. Consequently, it should be included for the review.

studies.title: Increased neural responses to empathy for pain might explain how acute stress increases prosociality.
studies.abstract: Recent behavioral investigations suggest that acute stress can increase prosocial behavior. Here, we investigated whether increased empathy represents a potential mechanism for this finding. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging, we assessed the effects of acute stress on neural responses related to automatic and regulatory components of empathy for pain as well as subsequent prosocial behavior. Stress increased activation in brain areas associated with the automatic sharing of others' pain, such as the anterior insula, the anterior midcingulate cortex, and the primary somatosensory cortex. In addition, we found increased prosocial behavior under stress. Furthermore, activation in the anterior midcingulate cortex mediated the effects of stress on prosocial behavior. However, stressed participants also displayed stronger and inappropriate other-related responses in situations which required them to take the perspective of another person, and to regulate their automatic affective responses. Thus, while acute stress may increase prosocial behavior by intensifying the sharing of others' emotions, this comes at the cost of reduced cognitive appraisal abilities. Depending on the contextual constraints, stress may therefore affect empathy in ways that are either beneficial or detrimental.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study reports fMRI during an empathy-for-pain task (social cognition: perception/understanding of others) in presumably healthy adult participants, directly addressing social-related processing. Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria for task-based fMRI in social domain.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of empathy for pain (a social-cognitive task) in healthy adult participants (n=67 analyzed; ages 18–40). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results (e.g., STRESS>CONTROL contrasts for INJECTION>QTIP and BIOPSY>QTIP) with whole-brain FWE correction and MNI coordinates, clearly described in the text and supplementary material. Although many reported contrasts are between two healthy groups (stress vs control), both groups consist of healthy adults and the analyses are group-level, voxelwise, whole-brain statistical maps suitable for inclusion in the meta-analysis of social processing in healthy adults. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria (fMRI social task; healthy adult sample; whole-brain group-level voxelwise results).

studies.title: Social evaluations under conflict: negative judgments of conflicting information are easier than positive judgments.
studies.abstract: In the current study, we used functional magnetic resonance imaging to investigate how the brain facilitates social judgments despite evaluatively conflicting information. Participants learned consistent (positive or negative) and ambivalent (positive and negative) person information and were then asked to provide binary judgments of these targets in situations that either resolved conflict by prioritizing a subset of information or not. Self-report, decision time and brain data confirm that integrating contextual information into our evaluations of objects or people allows for nuanced (social) evaluations. The same mixed trait information elicited or failed to elicit evaluative conflict dependent on the situation. Crucially, we provide data suggesting that negative judgments are easier and may be considered the 'default' action when experiencing evaluative conflict: weaker activation in dorsolateral prefrontal cortex during trials of evaluative conflict was related to a greater likelihood of unfavorable judgments, and greater activation was related to more favorable judgments. Since negative outcome consequences are arguably more detrimental and salient, this finding supports the idea that additional regulation and a more active selection process are necessary to override an initial negative response to evaluatively conflicting information.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used while participants performed social judgments about people (perception/understanding of others). Participants appear to be healthy adults. This is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) and fits the review objective of social-related processing in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social evaluation (social cognition/perception) in healthy adults (N=20, ages 18–29). The task is a social judgment task (forced-choice evaluations of target persons) and analyses report group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results (multilevel whole-brain MLM, reported clusters with MNI coordinates, DLPFC and dACC activations). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly described. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Oxytocin promotes facial emotion recognition and amygdala reactivity in adults with asperger syndrome.
studies.abstract: The neuropeptide oxytocin has recently been shown to enhance eye gaze and emotion recognition in healthy men. Here, we report a randomized double-blind, placebo-controlled trial that examined the neural and behavioral effects of a single dose of intranasal oxytocin on emotion recognition in individuals with Asperger syndrome (AS), a clinical condition characterized by impaired eye gaze and facial emotion recognition. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging, we examined whether oxytocin would enhance emotion recognition from facial sections of the eye vs the mouth region and modulate regional activity in brain areas associated with face perception in both adults with AS, and a neurotypical control group. Intranasal administration of the neuropeptide oxytocin improved performance in a facial emotion recognition task in individuals with AS. This was linked to increased left amygdala reactivity in response to facial stimuli and increased activity in the neural network involved in social cognition. Our data suggest that the amygdala, together with functionally associated cortical areas mediate the positive effect of oxytocin on social cognitive functioning in AS.
studies.journal: Neuropsychopharmacology : official publication of the American College of Neuropsychopharmacology
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Randomized, placebo-controlled fMRI study of facial emotion recognition (a social cognition task) in adults; includes a neurotypical healthy control group (adult participants) alongside an Asperger group. Meets inclusion criteria (fMRI during social task; healthy adults included) and is not a review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study reports fMRI during a social task (facial emotion recognition) in healthy adults (n=14 controls, ages within 18–65) and provides whole-brain, group-level within-group contrasts for the healthy control group (e.g., NTOXT>PLA whole-brain results with reported clusters and coordinates in the text/Table 2). The paper also reports task design, preprocessing, and exploratory whole-brain analyses (uncorrected p<0.001, k>10) and separate results for the healthy group, meeting the requirement for a healthy-group, voxelwise task-evoked map. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Predicting the brain activation pattern associated with the propositional content of a sentence: Modeling neural representations of events and states.
studies.abstract: Even though much has recently been learned about the neural representation of individual concepts and categories, neuroimaging research is only beginning to reveal how more complex thoughts, such as event and state descriptions, are neurally represented. We present a predictive computational theory of the neural representations of individual events and states as they are described in 240 sentences. Regression models were trained to determine the mapping between 42 neurally plausible semantic features (NPSFs) and thematic roles of the concepts of a proposition and the fMRI activation patterns of various cortical regions that process different types of information. Given a semantic characterization of the content of a sentence that is new to the model, the model can reliably predict the resulting neural signature, or, given an observed neural signature of a new sentence, the model can predict its semantic content. The models were also reliably generalizable across participants. This computational model provides an account of the brain representation of a complex yet fundamental unit of thought, namely, the conceptual content of a proposition. In addition to characterizing a sentence representation at the level of the semantic and thematic features of its component concepts, factor analysis was used to develop a higher level characterization of a sentence, specifying the general type of event representation that the sentence evokes (e.g., a social interaction versus a change of physical state) and the voxel locations most strongly associated with each of the factors. Hum Brain Mapp 38:4865-4881, 2017. © 2017 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study linking sentence meanings to neural activation; sentences include event types such as social interactions (e.g., social interaction vs change of physical state), indicating social-related processing. Abstract implies healthy participants and generalizable results but does not state ages; insufficient participant detail to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and that the task explicitly probes social processing.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task: event/state sentence reading including numerous sentences describing social interactions; authors explicitly identify a ‘people and social interactions’ semantic factor and report associated brain regions. This constitutes social-related processing (perception/understanding of others/social interactions). (2) Sample: seven healthy adult participants (ages 20–35), satisfying the 18–65 healthy adult requirement. (3) Whole-brain evidence: authors performed whole-brain fMRI, report group-level analyses (group-averaged images, factor analysis-derived voxel clusters and brain locations; Figure 4A and Supporting Information Table S3 provide voxel/cluster mappings), i.e., group-level, voxelwise task-evoked results for the healthy sample. (4) Not excluded: results are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient groups; this is original task-based fMRI data in healthy adults. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED in the review of social-related fMRI processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: The role of the amygdala in naturalistic mentalising in typical development and in autism spectrum disorder.
studies.abstract: The substantial discrepancy between mentalising in experimental settings v. real-life social interactions hinders the understanding of the neural basis of real-life social cognition and of social impairments in psychiatric disorders.
studies.journal: The British journal of psychiatry : the journal of mental science

studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (naturalistic theory-of-mind/mentalising task). A healthy control group (controls: n=22; fMRI subset n=20; ages 19–46) is reported separately from the autism group. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level within-group task contrast (ToM > physical inference) for the control group with cluster-corrected voxelwise results (tables and figures of activations), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-only, and participants fall in the 18–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: Pruning or tuning? Maturational profiles of face specialization during typical development.
studies.abstract: Face processing undergoes significant developmental change with age. Two kinds of developmental changes in face specialization were examined in this study: specialized maturation, or the continued tuning of a region to faces but little change in the tuning to other categories; and competitive interactions, or the continued tuning to faces accompanied by decreased tuning to nonfaces (i.e., pruning).
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract focuses on developmental changes in face specialization and does not specify participant ages or explicitly state an fMRI scan during a social-related task. It’s unclear whether a healthy adult (17–65) group was included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from the abstract alone — include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI task study of face perception (passive face/object/texture viewing), which falls under social-related processing (Perception and Understanding of Others). The sample includes a healthy adult group (n=51, ages 18–42) reported separately. The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts for the adult/control group (e.g., Face>Object, Face>Fixation; FLAME mixed-effects group analyses with cluster correction) presented in figures and tables. The study is empirical, not connectivity-only, and provides unmasked whole-brain activation results for the healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: The anterior cingulate cortex: monitoring the outcomes of others' decisions.
studies.abstract: The ability to attribute mental states to others and understand the basis of their decisions is essential for human social interaction. A controversial theory states that this is achieved by simulating another's information processing in one's own neural circuits. The anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) is known to play an important role in the registration of discrepancies between the predicted and actual outcomes of decisions (prediction errors).When positive and negative feedback fails altogether, the failure may also signal errors in the prediction that the outcome of that decision would be informative and guide future decisions. Does the ACC signal that an outcome is unexpectedly uninformative? When an outcome directed to others is uninformative, do we understand their mental states by simulating them in the circuits of the ACC in our own brain? The aim of our study was to test for these two possibilities in the human brain with event-related fMRI. We tested whether the ACC processes errors in the prediction of informative feedback and whether the ACC is also activated when scanned subjects process the same outcomes of another's decisions. We show that each is processed by a separate subregion of the ACC.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Event-related fMRI in human participants investigating processing of others' decisions and attribution of mental states (perception/understanding of others), a social cognition task. Likely healthy scanned subjects; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an event-related fMRI study of social cognition (monitoring another’s decisions) in healthy adults (n=12, mean age 21). The experiment reports group-level, random-effects voxelwise analyses (SPM ANOVA) with reported coordinates and figures for task-evoked effects in the ACC, and these results are clearly from the healthy/control group. Although small-volume correction (ACC mask) was applied for multiple-comparisons, whole-brain voxelwise analyses and group-level contrasts were performed and reported (coordinates and SPM results), satisfying the whole-brain evidence criterion. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not resting-state, participants within 18–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Stop looking angry and smile, please: start and stop of the very same facial expression differentially activate threat- and reward-related brain networks.
studies.abstract: Static pictures of emotional facial expressions have been found to activate brain structures involved in the processing of emotional stimuli. However, in everyday live, emotional expressions are changing rapidly, and the processing of the onset vs the offset of the very same emotional expression might rely on different brain networks, presumably leading to different behavioral and physiological reactions (e.g. approach or avoidance). Using functional magnetic resonance imaging, this was examined by presenting video clips depicting onsets and offsets of happy and angry facial expressions. Subjective valence and threat ratings clearly depended on the direction of change. Blood oxygen level dependent responses indicate both reward- and threat-related activations for the offset of angry expressions. Comparing onsets and offsets, angry offsets were associated with stronger ventral striatum activation than angry onsets. Additionally, the offset of happy and the onset of angry expressions showed strong common activity in the lateral orbitofrontal cortex bilaterally, the left amygdala and the left insula, whereas the onset of happy and the offset of angry expressions induced significant activation in the left dorsal striatum. In sum, the results confirm different activity in motivation-related brain areas in response to the onset and offset of the same emotional expression and highlight the importance of temporal characteristics of facial expressions for social communication.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of dynamic facial expressions (onset/offset), clearly addressing social communication processing. Abstract indicates task-based BOLD responses in emotion/motivation networks. Participant health/ages not specified—insufficient for exclusion—so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and ages.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing (dynamic facial-expression perception) in healthy adult participants (ages ~22, N=18 for fMRI), meeting the sample criterion. The authors performed voxelwise second-level group analyses in SPM (ANOVA) and report group-level task-evoked activation peaks with stereotaxic coordinates and statistical parametric maps (conjunctions and interaction contrasts), not limited to connectivity or patient-vs-control contrasts. Although many reported effects were assessed with ROI masks / small-volume correction, group-level voxelwise task contrasts and coordinates are provided for healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not resting-state, not only ROI/seed connectivity, and participants are within 18–65). Therefore the paper qualifies for inclusion.

studies.title: Neuroanatomical substrates involved in unrelated false facial recognition.
studies.abstract: Identifying faces is a process central for social interaction and a relevant factor in eyewitness theory. False recognition is a critical mistake during an eyewitness's identification scenario because it can lead to a wrongful conviction. Previous studies have described neural areas related to false facial recognition using the standard Deese/Roediger-McDermott (DRM) paradigm, triggering related false recognition. Nonetheless, misidentification of faces without trying to elicit false memories (unrelated false recognition) in a police lineup could involve different cognitive processes, and distinct neural areas. To delve into the neural circuitry of unrelated false recognition, we evaluated the memory and response confidence of participants while watching faces photographs in an fMRI task. Functional activations of unrelated false recognition were identified by contrasting the activation on this condition vs. the activations related to recognition (hits) and correct rejections. The results identified the right precentral and cingulate gyri as areas with distinctive activations during false recognition events suggesting a conflict resulting in a dysfunction during memory retrieval. High confidence suggested that about 50% of misidentifications may be related to an unconscious process. These findings add to our understanding of the construction of facial memories and its biological basis, and the fallibility of the eyewitness testimony.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI conducted during a face-recognition task (social perception/understanding of others), meeting the review’s social-processing and task-based fMRI criteria. Abstract does not explicitly report participant ages or health status; likely healthy adults but not confirmed. Include for full-text review to verify participant demographics and eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=18, ages 19–36) using a face memory/recognition task — a social cognition paradigm (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task contrasts (false recognition vs. recognition/correct rejection) with Random Effects analysis, cluster correction, and Talairach coordinates for activated regions (right precentral and cingulate gyri). Results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses, and participants fall within the 18–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Oxytocin Modulates Amygdala Reactivity to Masked Fearful Eyes.
studies.abstract: The amygdala reveals enhanced reactivity to fearful eye whites, even when they are backwardly masked by a neutral face and therefore processed with limited visual awareness. In our fMRI study, we investigated whether this effect is indeed associated with fear detection within the eyes of the neutral face mask, or more generally, with reactivity to any salient increase in eye white area. In addition, we examined whether a single dose of intranasal oxytocin would modulate amygdala responses to masked fearful eye whites via a double-blind, placebo-controlled pharmacological protocol. We found that increased amygdala responses to salient changes within a face's eye region occurred specifically for masked fearful eyes but not for similar increases in white area as induced by nonsocial control stimuli. Administration of oxytocin attenuated amygdala responses to masked fearful eye whites. Our results suggest that the amygdala is particularly tuned to potential threat signals from the eye region. The dampening effects of oxytocin on early amygdala reactivity may reflect reduced vigilance for facial threat cues at a preconscious level. Future studies may investigate whether this early modulation accounts for the beneficial effects of oxytocin on social cognition in anxiety-related disorders, as suggested by previous studies.
studies.journal: Neuropsychopharmacology : official publication of the American College of Neuropsychopharmacology
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining amygdala responses to masked fearful eyes (social-perception of others’ affect) during an experimental task; meets review objective. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status/ages, so include for full-text review to confirm demographics.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing (masked fearful vs happy eye whites) in healthy adults (male participants, mean age ~24). The study reports group-level task-evoked analyses and explicitly conducted exploratory whole-brain analyses (reported clusters in right pulvinar, ACC, orbitofrontal cortex, Supplementary Tables S1–S3) in the healthy/placebo and oxytocin groups. Whole-brain, voxelwise results with coordinates and cluster sizes are presented and described for the healthy groups, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The design and sample fall within the inclusion age range (18–65). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy sample) are violated.

studies.title: Hyperfunctioning of the right posterior superior temporal sulcus in response to neutral facial expressions presents an endophenotype of schizophrenia.
studies.abstract: Deficits in social cognition have been proposed as a marker of schizophrenia. Growing evidence suggests especially hyperfunctioning of the right posterior superior temporal sulcus (pSTS) in response to neutral social stimuli reflecting the neural correlates of social-cognitive impairments in schizophrenia. We characterized healthy participants according to schizotypy (n = 74) and the single-nucleotide polymorphism rs1344706 in ZNF804A (n = 73), as they represent risk variants for schizophrenia from the perspectives of personality traits and genetics, respectively. A social-cognitive fMRI task was applied to investigate the association of right pSTS hyperfunctioning in response to neutral face stimuli with schizotypy and rs1344706. Higher right pSTS activation in response to neutral facial expressions was found in individuals with increased positive (trend) and disorganization symptoms, as well as in carriers of the risk allele of rs1344706. In addition, a positive association between right-left pSTS connectivity and disorganization symptoms during neutral face processing was revealed. Although these findings warrant replication, we suggest that right pSTS hyperfunctioning in response to neutral facial expressions presents an endophenotype of schizophrenia. We assume that right pSTS hyperfunctioning is a vulnerability to perceive neutral social stimuli as emotionally or intentionally salient, probably contributing to the emergence of symptoms of schizophrenia.
studies.journal: Neuropsychopharmacology : official publication of the American College of Neuropsychopharmacology
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used an fMRI social-cognitive task (neutral facial expressions) in healthy participants (n=74) investigating social processing (pSTS responses). It is empirical (not a review) and includes healthy adult participants, meeting inclusion criteria. Age range not stated in abstract, but participant group is clearly healthy adults—include for full-text to confirm ages if needed.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social cognition in a sample of healthy adult participants (N=74) using a social-related task (neutral face processing, emotion recognition, affective ToM). The manuscript reports group-level whole-brain task activation analyses (one-sample t-tests and contrasts) with FWE-corrected thresholds and presents whole-brain results (figures and supplementary tables). While ROI and connectivity analyses are also reported, whole-brain healthy-group task effects are clearly described and meet the review’s requirement for unmasked, within-group activation maps. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and healthy adults are analyzed separately). Age range is not explicitly stated in the excerpt, but participants are described as healthy adults; there is no indication they fall outside 18–65. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Personality traits predict brain activation and connectivity when witnessing a violent conflict.
studies.abstract: As observers we excel in decoding the emotional signals telling us that a social interaction is turning violent. The neural substrate and its modulation by personality traits remain ill understood. We performed an fMRI experiment in which participants watched videos displaying a violent conflict between two people. Observers' attention was directed to either the aggressor or the victim. Focusing on the aggressor (vs. focusing on the victim) activated the superior temporal sulcus (STS), extra-striate body area (EBA), occipital poles and centro-medial amygdala (CMA). Stronger instantaneous connectivity occurred between these and the EBA, insula, and the red nucleus. When focusing on the victim, basolateral amygdala (BLA) activation was related to trait empathy and showed increased connectivity with the insula and red nucleus. STS activation was associated with trait aggression and increased connectivity with the hypothalamus. The findings reveal that focusing on the aggressor of a violent conflict triggers more activation in categorical (EBA) and emotion (CMA, STS) areas. This is associated with increased instantaneous connectivity among emotion areas (CMA-insula) and between categorical and emotion (EBA-STS) areas. When the focus is on the victim, personality traits (aggression/empathy) modulate activity in emotion areas (respectively STS and postcentral gyrus/ BLA), along with connectivity in the emotional diencephalon (hypothalamus) and early visual areas (occipital pole).
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Original fMRI study in humans where participants watched violent social interactions (social perception/understanding of others). Involves healthy adult observers and examines neural responses modulated by personality traits. Not a review/meta-analysis.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing: participants viewed dyadic violent interactions (social perception of others/affiliation/emotion). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=15 males; mean age 23.6), within 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results (e.g., all conditions vs baseline, and focus-on-aggressor vs focus-on-victim contrasts) with statistical thresholds and cluster correction (p-values, FDR/Monte Carlo), and describes activation and coordinate-based findings across multiple brain regions. Although sample is modest and predominantly male, results for the healthy group are reported directly. The study therefore satisfies all inclusion criteria and does not meet any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, reports healthy-group whole-brain activations).

studies.title: Tracking emotions in the brain - Revisiting the Empathic Accuracy Task.
studies.abstract: Many empathy tasks lack ecological validity due to their use of simplistic stimuli and static analytical approaches. Empathic accuracy tasks overcome these limitations by using autobiographical emotional video clips. Usually, a single measure of empathic accuracy is computed by correlating the participants' continuous ratings of the narrator's emotional state with the narrator's own ratings. In this study, we validated a modified empathic accuracy task. A valence-independent rating of the narrator's emotional intensity was added to provide comparability between videos portraying different primary emotions and to explore changes in neural activity related to variations in emotional intensity over time. We also added a new neutral control condition to investigate general emotional processing. In the scanner, 34 healthy participants watched 6 video clips of people talking about an autobiographical event (2 sad, 2 happy and 2 neutral clips) while continuously rating the narrator's emotional intensity. Fluctuation in perceived emotional intensity correlated with activity in brain regions previously implicated in cognitive empathy (bilateral superior temporal sulcus, temporoparietal junction, and temporal pole) and affective empathy (right anterior insula and inferior frontal gyrus). When emotional video clips were compared to neutral video clips, we observed higher activity in similar brain regions. Empathic accuracy, on the other hand, was only positively related to activation in regions that have been implicated in cognitive empathy. Our modified empathic accuracy task provides a new method for studying the underlying components and dynamic processes involved in empathy. While the task elicited both cognitive and affective empathy, successful tracking of others' emotions relied predominantly on the cognitive components of empathy. The fMRI data analysis techniques developed here may prove valuable in characterising the neural basis of empathic difficulties observed across a range of psychiatric conditions.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study with 34 healthy participants performing an empathic accuracy task (social cognitive processing — perception/understanding of others) during scanning. Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation of ages and other details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (empathy/mentalising) in healthy adults (final sample n=34, ages 20–30). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., emotional > neutral) and voxelwise correlations (EA modulation, time-series correlations with intensity), analyzed with SPM12/FSL and TFCE FWE correction, with peak activations and cluster tables. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and healthy-group whole-brain results are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria are violated.
