Although ages/health status are not explicitly stated, participants are implied to be healthy adult voters; therefore it meets inclusion or at minimum should be forwarded to full-text review for confirmation.

This is a systematic review of social cognition training in schizophrenia (clinical populations), not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Systematic reviews are explicitly excluded, and the participant group is patients rather than healthy participants.

fMRI task explicitly probes social cognition (inferring mental states from film excerpts). The study includes healthy control groups (28 HC; reproducibility in 14 HC). Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract—because this is unclear, include for full-text review to confirm ages meet 17–65.

fMRI study using MVPA examining neural representation of others' mental states (social cognition). Not a review; likely conducted in healthy adult participants. Abstract meets the review objective (social-related fMRI). Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.

Abstract reports task-related fMRI during a social perception experiment and includes a healthy control group (n=21). The task targets social-related processing (social perception/self-related networks). Not a review. Sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI task (self- and other-reflection) relevant to social processing but does not specify whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm presence of healthy adults — include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

This is a narrative review article summarizing neuroimaging, genetics, and pathology of semantic dementia, not a primary fMRI study. It does not report task-based fMRI data in healthy adults nor focus on social processing. Excluded per the criterion excluding reviews and because no original task-based fMRI data in healthy participants are presented.

fMRI study investigating how the brain represents similarity between self and others during a social task (learning others’ preferences), involving social cognition and reward networks. Abstract indicates an fMRI task in humans and addresses perception/understanding of others. Participant health/ages not specified; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.
Participants are school-age children (ages 9–13), not within the required adult age range (17–65). Although it's an fMRI study of social cognition, it fails the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (perception of others’ pain/empathy). Meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

fMRI study using a social-related task (self-referential processing: judging trait adjectives about self, mother, president). Includes a healthy control group alongside schizophrenia patients (healthy adults likely within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI during an irony comprehension task (social communication/perception of others) with a healthy control group (15 adult females) meets inclusion: social-related task and at least one healthy adult group. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text extraction.

Human fMRI study of perception of different laughter types (social communication/social cognition) in healthy adults; directly assesses social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides clear task and modality, so meets inclusion criteria.

This article is a review discussing MRI and behavioural research in adolescent social cognition rather than an original fMRI study with human participants. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and therefore should be excluded.

This article is a meta-analytic review of fMRI studies (not an original fMRI study). Exclusion criterion met: systematic reviews/meta-analyses are excluded. Although it addresses social cognition among other domains, it does not report primary fMRI data collected from healthy participants performing social tasks.

Double-blind placebo-controlled fMRI study of 55 healthy young men performing social-related tasks (attachment-related erotic scenes and fearful social scenes). Task-based fMRI in healthy adults directly fits the review objective; not a review article.

fMRI study of facial emotional processing (social cognition) in adults; includes a control group matched for age and IQ (healthy adults). Meets inclusion: social-related task, functional MRI, and at least one healthy adult group (likely age 17–65). Abstract is sufficiently clear to include for full-text review.

Abstract is a narrative review of neuroimaging in autism (summarizing prior PET/SPECT/fMRI studies), not an original fMRI experiment in healthy adults. It focuses on autistic patients and appears to be a review article, meeting exclusion criteria for reviews.

fMRI study using the iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma (a social interaction task) in healthy subjects; examines neural responses during social interactions. Meets inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy participant group). Not a review.

The study reports an fMRI (BOLD) investigation of social cognition (processing kin vs. friends) in 25 healthy adult female participants, directly addressing social-related processing in humans. It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) and fits the review objective. Age range not specified, but participants are adults; include for full-text review to confirm ages and other eligibility details.

Resting-state fMRI (no social task); study examines cerebro-cerebellar limbic networks in MCI/AD rather than social processing in healthy adults 17–65. Does not meet task-based social processing criterion.

fMRI study where adolescents (mean age 17) viewed videos of their parents—clearly a social-processing task (perception/understanding of others). Participants appear healthy and age falls within 17–65. No exclusion criteria met.

Resting-state (task-free) fMRI study in healthy adults investigating language-network connectivity, not a task-based social processing paradigm. The abstract does not report any social-related task or measures of social cognition, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 26 healthy adult participants performing an empathy-evoking social cognition task (film clips with contextual/musical manipulation). Directly examines social-related processing in adults and is an original empirical study (not a review). Satisfies inclusion criteria.

This publication is a review article (narrative review of behavioral and imaging studies), not an original fMRI experiment in healthy adults. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses. Insufficient as a primary fMRI study.

Abstract describes a narrative review of developmental social brain research, not an original fMRI experiment. It summarizes MRI/fMRI findings across adolescence rather than reporting a primary fMRI study with healthy adult participants, so it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

fMRI study examining neural processing of different laughter types and attention to social information—addresses social communication/perception of others. Involves human participants and appears to study healthy adults (no clinical groups reported). Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Hyperscanning fMRI study of real-time social interaction (joint attention) directly assesses social processing. Abstract implies healthy human dyads but does not specify participant ages; insufficient age detail for exclusion. Include for full-text review to confirm age range and participant health.

Abstract describes a face-processing task with neural activity but does not explicitly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was scanned. Because the abstract provides insufficient information about the presence/age of healthy participants, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study where healthy late-adolescent participants (ages 18–22) observed risk-taking versus safe actions, a social-cognition/emotional-processing task involving perception and understanding of others. Participants are within the eligible age range (17–65) and the study is original research, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports real-time fMRI during the ultimatum game, a social interaction/decision-making task, with volunteers (healthy participants) and identifies neural correlates of social behavior. It is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults and not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults; although healthy controls were included, no social task was performed, so it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

fMRI study of self-reference vs. reference to others — clearly social-cognitive tasks. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy status, but no clinical groups are mentioned. Because age/health criteria are not explicitly reported in the abstract, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Event-related fMRI was used while subjects performed a social-related task (judging trustworthiness of faces), directly addressing social perception of others. The study appears to involve human subjects with no indication of clinical populations and is a primary research article (not a review). Recommend full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

This is an fMRI study of Theory of Mind (social cognition/perception and understanding of others) in healthy adult participants (n=19). It involves a social-related task (REMICS) and is not a review/meta-analysis. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a review/proposal of deep brain stimulation for severe autism, not an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. The abstract does not report functional MRI during a social task or data from healthy participants aged 17–65.

fMRI study with 18 healthy adult participants performing a social motor response learning task involving inference about others' intentions (social processing). Meets inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy adults). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.
Study used fMRI to examine Theory of Mind (a social-cognitive task) and includes a healthy comparison group of adults. This directly meets inclusion criteria and is not a review.

fMRI study with 29 healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (explicit emotion recognition vs implicit age discrimination of facial expressions) probing social communication/perception of others; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Non-human animal study (rats) using resting-state fMRI under anesthesia; not a task-based fMRI of social processing in human adults. Does not meet inclusion criteria of human participants aged 17–65 performing social tasks.

Abstract examines neural substrates of social cognition and face processing in healthy young adults but does not explicitly state that fMRI scanning or a social task was used. Methods are unclear from abstract alone, so include for full-text review to confirm fMRI and task details.

fMRI study examines social perception (dynamic/static social stimuli) and reports data from typically developing adolescents as a healthy comparison group. Age range not specified beyond 'adolescents', so inclusion for full-text review is needed to confirm participants meet 17–65 criterion; otherwise meets social-task and healthy-group criteria.

fMRI study using point-light displays of biological motion—a social perception task (Perception and Understanding of Others). Sample includes adults and school-age youth; adults are healthy participants. The task was performed during scanning and the paper is original research (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Both participant groups are adolescents (typically developing adolescents and adolescents with TBI), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the inclusion criteria. Although fMRI during a social cognition task was used, the healthy sample is outside the eligible age range.

fMRI study using an empathy-for-pain task (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Includes a healthy young adult group aged 20–30 (within 17–65), satisfying inclusion criteria. Not a review.

All participants are individuals with a psychotic disorder; the abstract does not report any healthy control group. Although it is an fMRI study of social (facial affect) processing, it fails the requirement of including at least one healthy participant group (age 17–65).

Hyperscanning fMRI during joint attention tasks addresses social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Study reports task-based fMRI activation in participants (presumably healthy adults) and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing studies in healthy adults.

Participants are children/adolescents (ages 10–17); no clear adult (17–65) healthy group. Study focuses on developmental sample rather than healthy adults, so it does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

Neuroimaging study reporting neural correlates of interpersonal synchrony and affiliation in healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (perception of synchrony/affiliation). Fits inclusion criteria (fMRI during social processing); not a review.

Study used fMRI during social-related task (neural response to facial expressions/emotional processing) and includes a healthy control group. Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65), so full text is needed to confirm age eligibility. Include for full-text review.

All participants were patients with amnestic mild cognitive impairment; no healthy adult group (age 17–65) is included. Although the fMRI task (face–name encoding) involves social/emotional processing, the study fails the criterion requiring at least one healthy participant group.

fMRI study investigating impression updating (perception/understanding of others) — a social cognition task. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy status. Because stimulus/task and imaging meet inclusion but key participant details are missing, include for full-text review to confirm health and age criteria.

Empirical fMRI study using the Why/How Task to probe Theory of Mind (social cognition) across three experiments; involves healthy adult participants and reports task-based functional MRI results. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI was used while healthy adult mothers viewed images of their own vs unfamiliar child and dog, addressing affiliation/attachment and social processing. Participants are adults; task is social-related. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

The study used resting-state fMRI in healthy males following intranasal oxytocin; no social-related task was performed during scanning. Thus it does not meet the inclusion requirement of an fMRI scan during a social-related task.

fMRI was resting-state (no social-related task); inclusion requires a functional MRI during a social task. Although oxytocin relates to social behavior, the study did not involve task-based social processing in the scanner.

fMRI study examines processing of social vs nonsocial gestures—directly addresses social-related processing. Abstract does not state participant health status or ages; cannot confirm inclusion criteria regarding healthy adults (17–65). Per screening rules, include for full-text review to confirm participant characteristics.

Abstract reports an fMRI study examining social influence during a group decision-making task, directly addressing social processing and neural correlates. Although participant age/health isn’t explicitly stated, the study appears to involve healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related task; include for full-text review to confirm sample demographics.

fMRI was used while participants performed a social-related task (self-attribute evaluations; perception/understanding of self). Abstract reports neural results in healthy-sounding samples and no clinical groups are mentioned. Age range not specified in abstract — include for full-text review to confirm participant age/health details.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants investigating self-recognition (self-face and name), which falls under Perception and Understanding of Self — a social-related construct. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract indicates healthy adult sample and task-based fMRI, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of self–other processing (social cognition) including a healthy typically developing control group of young adults (age within 17–65). Task is social-related (self vs other judgments). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.
This paper is a meta-analysis/systematic review of >200 fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adults, meeting the exclusion criterion.

Abstract describes a review/narrative article about resting-state fMRI and social cognition, not an original study with participants performing a social-related fMRI task. No task-based fMRI data in healthy adults are reported.

This is a review/overview chapter summarizing oxytocin studies (including fMRI) in schizophrenia spectrum disorders rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It is a secondary source and appears focused on clinical populations, so it does not meet inclusion for primary fMRI data in healthy participants.

Abstract does not specify that an fMRI task was used or whether healthy adult participants (age 17–65) were included. The study concerns neurobiological correlates of social-cognitive processes in psychopathy, which aligns with the review objective. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

Participants are children (high-functioning ASD and typically developing children), not adults; no healthy participant group within the required age range (17–65). Although it uses fMRI and a social/pragmatic language task, it fails the criteria requiring healthy adult participants.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants using face-viewing task comparing racial ingroup vs outgroup faces — a social-cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Participants appear to be healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Dual‑fMRI study where participants performed social interaction tasks (cooperation and competition), directly addressing social processing with functional MRI. Abstract does not report participant ages/health status; inclusion requires confirming healthy adults 17–65. Include for full‑text review to verify sample characteristics.

fMRI study investigating face processing (perception/understanding of others), a social-related task, with a healthy control group (n=21). Fits the review objective and inclusion criteria; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text extraction.

This is a narrative review of human neuroimaging literature on cerebellar function, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

Participants are criminal offenders from an adjudicated inpatient forensic psychiatric population (psychotic and nonpsychotic offenders). No group of healthy (community) adults is reported; nonpsychotic offenders are not clearly 'healthy' controls. Therefore it does not meet the criterion of including at least one healthy participant group.

Original fMRI study examining neural processing of social interaction/mentalizing in human participants (live vs recorded speech). Not a review/meta-analysis. Task probes social communication/understanding of others. Although participant ages aren’t specified in the abstract, it clearly involves healthy adult participants and meets inclusion; include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

The paper is a coordinate-based multimodal meta-analysis of fMRI and VBM studies in first-degree relatives of schizophrenia patients. It is a meta-analysis, which meets the exclusion criterion (systematic reviews/meta-analyses). The abstract does not report primary fMRI data of social-processing tasks in healthy adults.

Abstract does not report an fMRI study or any neuroimaging; it examines gene–environment interaction and response inhibition in adolescents, not social-related processing. Participants are adolescents (likely under 17), outside the 17–65 adult range. Thus it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of emotion perception/social communication (facial and vocal emotion discrimination and priming) in human participants. Abstract does not explicitly state participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
Abstract explicitly states this is a review article; it does not report original fMRI data from healthy adult participants. Excluded per criterion: systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract examines neural bases of biological motion perception (a social-related process) and includes a healthy control group (N=67). However, the imaging modality is not specified in the abstract—fMRI is not confirmed. Insufficient information to determine whether an fMRI task was used; include for full-text review.

FMRI study in healthy participants performing self-descriptiveness judgments (Perception/Understanding of Self), a social-related task. Neural correlates reported; not a review or meta-analysis. Although ages not stated in abstract, participants are described as healthy (no psychiatric/neurological groups mentioned). Meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.

Randomized within-subject pharmaco-fMRI in 40 healthy adult males assessing neural and emotional responses to interpersonal touch (social communication/affiliation). Fits inclusion: fMRI, social-related task, healthy adults 17–65. Not a review.

fMRI study examining social cognition (agency and communion) using a valence classification task in humans. Abstract indicates social-related processing; however participant demographics/health status and ages are not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study measuring neural responses to visible and invisible faces (facial identity and expression), directly addressing social perception/communication. Involves human observers (presumably healthy adults); abstract lacks explicit age info, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health.

fMRI study on voice processing (social auditory information), relevant to social communication. Abstract implies comparison to normal activation patterns, suggesting healthy control data, but does not explicitly state controls or ages. Because inclusion hinges on presence of healthy adults and abstract is not fully explicit, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study investigates memory retrieval, white-matter connectivity, and functional networks in ventrolateral PFC, not social-related processes. The fMRI task is not social (no affiliation, communication, or self/other perception), so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI was conducted during a validated social cognition (Theory of Mind) task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes) in a sample of healthy adult volunteers (18 males, within 17–65). Study is empirical fMRI research of social processing, not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using a social task (social BART) but sample is ages 8–17 (adolescents). Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65; the abstract does not clearly report a distinct adult group (only up to age 17). Include for full-text review to verify whether adult (17+) participants meet the review age criterion.

fMRI study of mentalizing (social cognition) with tasks involving self/other judgments; includes a healthy adult control group (33 age- and IQ-matched controls, adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

This article is a meta-analysis of neuroimaging studies (systematic review/meta-analysis), not a primary fMRI study. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses and does not provide original fMRI data from healthy adults.

Abstract reports testing social cognitive networks in patients with schizophrenia and their unaffected siblings using neural activation measures (implying fMRI) during social cognitive tasks; includes a healthy group (unaffected siblings, adults). No exclusion criteria met. Full text should be reviewed for explicit fMRI methods and participant ages/details.

The article is a narrative discussion/review of resting-state fMRI findings in ASD rather than an original task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It does not report functional MRI during a social-related task and is not appropriate for inclusion.

fMRI study of charitable donation decisions (social decision-making/altruism), implicating affiliation/attachment and perception/understanding of others. Conducted in human participants (healthy adults likely within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study in adults using a social task (viewing dynamic emotional facial expressions); includes a healthy control group (adults) alongside ASD participants. Fits social perception/understanding criteria and meets age/group requirements; not a review.

The article is a narrative review of negative symptoms, social cognition and facial affect processing in schizophrenia, summarizing behavioural and imaging (fMRI) studies rather than reporting new fMRI experiments. The abstract does not describe original fMRI scans on healthy adult participants, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion.

fMRI study where participants viewed approaching characters displaying angry/happy expressions, investigating social perception (social communication/affiliation). Involves human participants (presumably healthy adults), fits the review objective and inclusion criteria, and is not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Abstract examines oxytocin effects in adults with Asperger syndrome and does not specify any healthy control group. Inclusion requires at least one healthy adult group; because the abstract lacks this information, it should be included for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract describes a program of fMRI research including studies of typically developing adults in social perception, but it reads like a program/narrative review and does not report specific primary study details (participant ages, sample). Insufficient information to confirm inclusion—include for full-text review to determine if original fMRI data on healthy adults (17–65) are reported.
Resting-state fMRI study (no social task); participants are children with ASD and controls (not healthy adults aged 17–65). Does not meet task-based healthy adult inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes methodological network analysis of functional connectivity related to psychosis risk; no indication that participants performed a social-related task or that social processing was assessed. Therefore it does not meet the fMRI social-task inclusion criterion.

fMRI study in which participants read a narrative; reported activations are in brain regions associated with social cognition and predictive inference, indicating a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not report participant ages or explicit health status, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets age and health criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult Danish Christian participants performing prayer, which the authors interpret as recruiting social-cognition networks (medial PFC, TPJ, precuneus). Task involves social-related processing (perception/understanding of others/God). No exclusion criteria met.

Sample consists of typically developing adolescents aged 14–18 with no clearly defined adult group within the 17–65 range. Although ages include 17–18, the study focuses on adolescents rather than a distinct adult (17–65) group required by the review. Therefore it does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI recorded during live social exchanges (reciprocal imitation), addressing social cognition and interaction. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult sample (17–65).

This article is a voxel-based meta-analysis (systematic meta-analysis) of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study of participants; exclusion criterion disallows systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract focuses on schizophrenia and cognitive remediation; it mentions social cognition but does not specify that an fMRI social-task was performed or whether healthy control participants (age 17–65) were included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review.
This article is a large-scale meta-analysis of fMRI studies rather than a primary fMRI study of social processing in human participants. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses.

fMRI study with 36 healthy adult participants (age within 17–65 range implied) performing social interaction observation task probing perception/understanding of others; not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

This is an essay/review advocating cross-species social neuroscience; the abstract describes conceptual arguments rather than an empirical fMRI study. No human participants, fMRI scanning, or social task are reported, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI was conducted during an empathy task (a social cognition/Perception and Understanding of Others construct) and the study included a healthy control group of adults. Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

The article reports an Activation Likelihood Estimation (coordinate-based) meta-analysis comparing schizophrenia patients and healthy controls. It is a meta-analysis rather than an original fMRI study, meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study of verbal irony comprehension engaging Theory of Mind network (social communication/perception of others). Participants are described as human listeners (implied healthy adults). Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

This is a selective (narrative) review article synthesizing existing neuroimaging literature, not an original fMRI study reporting participant-level data or scans during a social-related task in healthy adults. It therefore does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI study with human participants.

Abstract describes a multilevel kernel density fMRI analysis (meta-analytic approach) investigating neural bases of sexual desire and love. Exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses; therefore exclude.

fMRI study where healthy participants processed vocal emotions (social communication/perception of others). Task involves decoding emotional prosody—clearly social-related processing. Not a review/meta-analysis and meets participant criteria. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

The study reports fMRI during an affective ToM task in 25 unmedicated chronic depression patients and does not mention any healthy control or healthy participant group. Inclusion requires at least one healthy group (age 17–65). The paper is original research (not a review), so it fails the healthy-participants inclusion criterion based on the abstract.

fMRI study examining mothers’ brain responses to emotional expressions of their children — a social/attachment-related task. Participants are adult mothers (healthy adult sample) comparing preterm vs. full-term; meets age and healthy-participant criteria. Not a review article. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study of empathy/social processing comparing responses to self, familiar friend, and stranger; involves healthy adult participants and uses a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social cognition (automatic perception of cooperative behavior) with a healthy matched control group (19 controls) and patient group; task is social-related and meets inclusion. Although ages aren’t specified, 'matched controls' implies adult participants; include for full-text review to confirm age range.

Abstract focuses on structural MRI (VBM) associations with moral sentiments but also references subgenual cingulate fMRI responses; it is unclear whether functional scans were acquired during a social-related task as required. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review to confirm presence of task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study of social interaction (friend vs celebrity) manipulating relationship and emotional valence; probes affiliation, empathy, and reward-related social processing. Sample of 28 human participants (presumably healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria based on abstract.

fMRI study in healthy participants investigating social-signal detection and mental-state inference (eye-gaze, self-propulsion, implicit mental inference). Directly fits review objective of social processing in healthy adults and is not a review. Age range not reported in abstract; include for full-text confirmation.

This is a review/chapter summarizing oxytocin effects and neuroimaging in ASD rather than an original fMRI study. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not report primary fMRI data in healthy adult participants.

fMRI study in humans investigating social cognition (emotion inference about social targets) conducted during task performance. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample and other details.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=20) performing a social-related mimicry task modulated by eye contact, addressing social communication and perception of others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Empirical fMRI (BOLD) study of social processing (affiliation vs isolation) with healthy younger and older adults performing pleasantness judgments. Not a review. Abstract does not specify exact participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm at least one healthy group falls within 17–65.

Study used fMRI hyperscanning during an interactive social-exchange task probing social cognition (cooperation/competition), which aligns with the review objective. The abstract does not state participant ages or health status; per screening rules, if information is insufficient for exclusion, include for full-text review.

This publication is a mini-review integrating multimodal MRI and OXTR literature, not an original task-based fMRI study. It is a review article (excluded by the criterion excluding systematic reviews/meta-analyses) and does not report primary fMRI data from healthy adult participants.

Participants are adolescents (mean ages 15.8 and 16.2), below the required adult age range (17–65); no healthy adult group is included. Therefore the study does not meet the age criterion for inclusion.

Study participants are middle childhood children (roughly ages 7–13), not adults. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65. Although it is an fMRI social cognition study, the participants fall outside the eligible age range, so exclude based on participant age.

Study uses resting-state fMRI rather than an active social-related task, and the abstract focuses on ultra-high-risk subjects; it does not report a task involving social processing in healthy adults. Does not meet task-based inclusion criterion.

Event-related fMRI study of social gaze processing (social cognition). Abstract reports a neurologically normal/typically developing subject group (n=9), so at least one healthy group is present. Ages not reported in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet the 17–65 age criterion.

This is a narrative review discussing neuroimaging and behavioral studies in high-functioning autism, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. No fMRI task or healthy adult sample is reported; it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

fMRI study of social reflection (self/other judgments) in 22 healthy subjects, directly addressing social-related processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although exact ages not reported, sample described as healthy subjects and likely adult; include for full-text review to confirm age range and details.

fMRI study where participants viewed social vs non-social stimuli during scanning; includes a matched healthy control group (n=14). Study directly investigates perception/understanding of others, meeting inclusion criteria.

Study reports human fMRI during processing of emotional faces, a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). It presents data from healthy human participants (single-subject analyses). No exclusion criteria apply. Full-text review can confirm participant ages if needed.

fMRI was acquired while participants performed a social-evaluative task (viewing cues about being watched by a peer), targeting self-conscious socioaffective processing. The sample included adult participants (in addition to children/adolescents), appears to be healthy, and this is an original empirical study rather than a review.

fMRI study using a face encoding task (social cognition) and includes an age- and gender-matched control group. Abstract does not report control participants' ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Primary fMRI study (n=51) examining processing of dynamic facial expressions—clearly a social communication task involving perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis and appears to use healthy participants. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study used near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS), not functional MRI, so it does not meet the requirement of fMRI scanning during a social-related task. Although participants are healthy adults and task is social, the imaging modality excludes it.

This article is a review of neuroimaging studies of social cognition in MDD rather than an original fMRI experiment. It does not report participant-level fMRI data or a social-task scan in a healthy adult group, so it fails the inclusion criteria for original fMRI studies.

Abstract does not state whether an fMRI was conducted or whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Topic relates to social cognition/neuroimaging but information is insufficient to determine eligibility; include for full-text review to verify methods and participant groups.

Abstract reports two fMRI experiments examining understanding of intentions in social interactions (theory of mind), which is squarely within social-related processing. No exclusion criteria apply. Include for full-text review to confirm participant characteristics (healthy adult sample, ages 17–65) and methodological details.

Resting-state fMRI in children (ages 7–12), not a task-based fMRI of social processing in adults. Participants are outside the required age range (17–65) and no social task was performed; therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study using social interaction images (social-related processing). It focuses on remitted depression but does not explicitly state whether healthy control participants were included; information is insufficient to rule out inclusion, so include for full-text review.

This study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing fMRI. Inclusion requires an fMRI scan conducted while participants performed a social-related task; although healthy controls were included, the absence of a task means it should be excluded.

fMRI study in 15 healthy adult males using intranasal oxytocin vs placebo while imaging amygdala responses to fear-inducing visual stimuli; authors frame findings in terms of social cognition and trust. This meets the inclusion criteria of fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is a resting-state fMRI study measuring ALFF/fALFF in schizophrenia and controls; no task-based social processing is reported. It therefore does not meet the requirement of an fMRI study with a social-related task in healthy adults.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants using social stimuli (love and power movie clips) targeting affiliation and power motivations. Methods align with social-related processing constructs; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion; no evidence of clinical populations.

fMRI study using emotional face go/no-go task (social stimuli) and includes neurotypical control group (healthy participants). Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and extract details.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires functional MRI during a social-related task; therefore it does not meet the criterion despite including healthy adult participants.

fMRI was acquired in 78 healthy adults performing 29 experimental conditions including a cross-domain localizer for social perception and reasoning. This directly assesses social-related processing in healthy participants within the target age range; not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study examining prosocial decisions (family contributions) recruiting mentalizing and self-control regions—clearly a social-cognitive task. Involves human participants and healthy sample implied. Age range not specified in abstract; insufficient detail to confirm ages 17–65, so include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

This paper is a meta-analysis/synthesis of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study reporting data from participants. The exclusion criteria explicitly exclude systematic reviews or meta-analyses.

fMRI was used while participants completed a trustworthiness ratings task—a social cognition task assessing perception of others. Abstract implies human adult participants and probes social-related processing. Age range not specified; per guidance, include for full-text review to confirm demographics. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI was conducted during a Cyberball social exclusion task (social processing relevant to affiliation/attachment and social interaction). Study involves healthy genotype groups and reports neural activity. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages and detailed health screening, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.

Participants are children aged 7–12, not adults. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65. Although fMRI during a social movie was used, the age criterion is not met based on the abstract.

Abstract reports an fMRI (rt-fMRI) study combined with EEG targeting social communication processes (right pSTS), aligning with social-related processing in healthy adults. However, participant details and explicit task description/age range are not provided in the abstract, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study explicitly examining self-referential and social stimulus processing (social-related constructs). Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit healthy status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI was performed in healthy young adults during a social attribution task (perception/interpretation of human-like interactions). This directly matches the review objective and inclusion criteria (social-related processing in healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining gaze following and eye contact—clearly a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Reports neural activation during task in healthy adult participants (implied). Not a review or meta-analysis. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages/health details.

Task-based fMRI study investigating perception/understanding of social interactions (interaction presence and type). Abstract describes neural responses to social interaction stimuli and classifiers in pSTS/TPJ—directly relevant. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm at least one healthy adult group (17–65).

Functional MRI was used while participants made social judgments of faces (trustworthiness/age), a social cognition task. The study includes a healthy control group (“nonclinical controls”), and is not a review. Exact ages are not reported in the abstract, but participants are described as men (likely adults); include for full-text review to confirm age 17–65.

Study used resting-state fMRI to measure functional connectivity after rTMS, not an fMRI scan during a social-related task. Although participants were healthy adults, the absence of a task probing social processing fails the inclusion criterion requiring task-based social fMRI.

The study used task-based fMRI of a social-related paradigm (direct vs. averted gaze) and included a group of healthy adult participants (n=16). It is original research (not a review) and thus meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of perception of socially relevant facial expressions and neural correlates of facial mimicry, addressing social communication and perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants (n=30) performed a social-related task (empathizing with ingroup vs outgroup during pain paradigms). This directly assesses social processing (empathy/ingroup–outgroup) using functional MRI and is not a review; thus meets inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during a virtual social cognition task (attribution of others' emotions) and included a healthy control group. These map directly onto social-related processing in humans. Age range not specified in abstract but participants are described as normal controls (likely adults); include for full-text verification if needed.

fMRI study examining attractiveness comparisons (social perception of others), fitting the review’s social-processing constructs. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not report participant ages or health status explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI study using multiple-round trust games (social reward/trust processing) and includes a healthy control group (20 subjects). Meets criterion of social-related fMRI with healthy participants. Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65 requirement) or full task/contrast details, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and extract necessary data.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of social tie formation during a public good game—a social-related task involving understanding others and prosocial decisions. The abstract does not state participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study with healthy (typical) adult participants performing a social-cognitive task (causal attributions about self, others, situation). Fits review objective of social processing in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified (minor uncertainty), so include for full-text review.

Paper describes fMRI-based, gaze-contingent paradigms to create interactive social stimuli and reviews results from two paradigms, suggesting task-based social processing in an fMRI setting. Participant details (age, health status) are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study examining event simulation with tasks involving situational inference and future prediction; authors explicitly link ES to social cognition (mentalizing/trait inference). Abstract confirms fMRI and social-related processing but does not report participant ages/health; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65).

Abstract reports neural-level analyses (dynamic causal modeling) of empathy and mentalizing during naturalistic social situations in a large sample of healthy participants, indicating fMRI data during social-cognitive tasks. Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI data were collected while participants (schizophrenia patients and healthy controls) passively watched a cinematic social-affective scene involving mother and son, a social-related task probing perception/understanding of others and affiliation. At least one healthy adult group was included. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of social decision-making (self- vs other-serving choices) in a healthy adult, addressing social processing. However it appears to be a single-case (N=1), so whether it meets the 'group of healthy participants' criterion is unclear from the abstract; include for full-text review to confirm sample and eligibility.

fMRI study where participants performed a prosocial learning task (choosing for self, other, or no one), directly addressing social processing and empathy. Reports neural responses during the task in human participants and is not a review. Likely healthy adult sample; if ages/health unclear, full text can confirm. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

Study reports fMRI during social-cognitive tasks (affective Theory of Mind, emotion recognition, neutral face processing) and includes a matched healthy control group of adults. Not a review/meta-analysis, so meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

The paper is explicitly a fMRI meta-analysis/systematic review (synthesis of prior neuroimaging studies) rather than an original fMRI experiment with primary participant data. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses.

fMRI study using a social cognition task (theory of mind/empathy) with 70 human subjects; addresses social-related processing. Not a review. Abstract implies healthy participants (classification across levels of social anhedonia) and fits the review objective.

Event-related fMRI in healthy adult participants viewing faces of presidential candidates—task assesses social perception/emotional reactions to others (political affiliation effects). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related processing in healthy adults; not a review article.

This is a methodological/review-style paper about hyperscanning techniques across modalities, with no report of original fMRI data or an fMRI task performed by healthy adult participants. The abstract describes methods and future directions rather than results from an fMRI social-task study, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Cross-sectional fMRI study using a social-judgment task (acceptance/rejection), directly assessing social-related processing. Includes a matched healthy control group (20 adults) within the target age range. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports participants completed two social-cognitive functional MRI tasks (showing superior temporal sulcus activity) and assesses social processing measures; no indication participants had psychiatric/neurological disorders. Meets criteria for fMRI social-related task in healthy adults.

Abstract lacks participant and methods details: it focuses on schizophrenia but does not state whether healthy control participants (age 17–65) were included or whether an fMRI social task was used. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study (20 healthy adult participants) using a social task (modified Prisoner’s Dilemma) investigating Theory of Mind and social decision-making; addresses perception/understanding of others and meets age/healthy participant inclusion criteria.

The study uses resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) to examine amygdala network causality across the lifespan. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task in human participants. The abstract provides no task-based social paradigm and includes lifespan samples (not restricted to ages 17–65). Therefore exclude based on not meeting the task-based fMRI inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports functional neuroimaging (fMRI) while participants viewed social scenes, probing mentalizing-related dmPFC activity—this is a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). Participants appear to be healthy adults; study is empirical (not a review). Therefore it meets inclusion criteria.

This is a review article on infant social-brain development and fMRI methods, not an original fMRI study with human participants aged 17–65 performing social tasks. It explicitly reviews literature and proposes a framework, meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and not addressing healthy adult fMRI data.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed emotion reappraisal of angry faces — a social-related task (perception/processing of others' facial emotions). The study reports neural activity/connectivity in healthy adults and is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task was performed). The review requires task-based fMRI during social processing; although healthy controls are included, absence of a social task precludes inclusion.

fMRI study examining live cooperative social interaction and joint attention—clearly social-related processing. Although participant ages/health are not explicitly listed in the abstract, the paradigm implies healthy adult volunteers; include for full-text review to confirm demographics and details.

Participants are young adults with high-functioning ASD only; the abstract does not report any healthy control or healthy participant group (age 17–65). Although an fMRI biological motion social task was used, the absence of healthy participants fails the inclusion criterion.

fMRI study where participants performed social-related tasks (self-evaluation and evaluation of an intimate other). Includes a matched healthy control group (adult controls) alongside a schizophrenia group. Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

The study reports dual MEG (magnetoencephalography) hyperscanning methods, not functional MRI. It does not describe fMRI scanning of social tasks in healthy adults, so it does not meet the fMRI-specific inclusion criterion.

Event-related fMRI study of person perception/mentalizing with healthy adult participants performing a social task (political affiliation and views). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review.

fMRI study using a facial affect matching task (perception/understanding of others — social processing) and includes a healthy adult comparison group alongside MA-dependent participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets the inclusion criteria based on the abstract.

This is a resting-state fMRI study comparing MDD patients and healthy controls; participants did not perform a social-related task. Although healthy controls are included, the lack of task-based social processing makes it ineligible for the review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social attribution/mentalizing using the DISC stimuli in a sample of 22 typically developing adults. This meets inclusion (fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults). Not a review or meta-analysis.

Human fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing social-cognitive tasks (passive observation and emotion attribution judgments about human and non-human faces). Examines perception/understanding of others, fitting the review objective and inclusion criteria; not a review article.

Abstract reports simultaneous EEG-fMRI data collected during a group categorization task involving emotional face processing, a social-related task. fMRI was conducted while participants performed the task. Participant health/ages are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

fMRI task explicitly examines social exclusion and performance-related social evaluation (Cyberball modification), mapping social processing and neural correlates. Abstract implies healthy adult participants and meets the review focus on social-related processing. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages/health.

fMRI study in 35 healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (recall of relationship episodes involving self and others), addressing perception/understanding of self and others. Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria.

This paper is a quantitative review/meta-analysis (ALE) of fMRI studies in individuals at clinical high risk for psychosis, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Systematic reviews/meta-analyses are excluded.

fMRI study using an interactive competitive reaction-time task probing social interaction and reactive aggression in healthy adult participants (16 males). Task involves social-related processing (perception/understanding of others, social interaction). Not a review/meta-analysis. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

This publication is a review article (explicitly described as 'In this review'), not a primary fMRI study. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses, so it should be excluded.

fMRI study measuring brain activity during socio-cognitive task (viewing social/traffic videos). Participants are healthy adult drivers (comparison of safe vs dangerous groups). Study examines social cognition (STS reactivity). Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI with an interactive, social task (self- and other-initiated joint attention) in a sample of healthy adult participants. It examines social cognition/neural correlates and is not a review—meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in male adults performing social-cognition tasks (reflection on own and friend's attributes), which maps onto ‘Perception and Understanding of Self/Others’. Participants are healthy adults; study is empirical (not a review). Therefore it meets inclusion criteria.

Participants are children/adolescents (ASD and typically developing), not healthy adults aged 17–65. No group of healthy adult participants in the eligible age range is reported, so the study does not meet the review’s age criterion.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants performed a social task (one-shot prisoner's dilemma). Reports neural responses to social cooperation; meets inclusion criteria. Age range not stated but participants appear to be healthy adults—include for full-text review.

Event-related fMRI study where human participants performed an interpersonal resource-conflict and sharing task—clearly probes social processing (perception/understanding of others, social decision-making). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages but likely healthy adults; because demographic detail is insufficient, include for full-text review to confirm ages and health status.

fMRI study with live social interaction (human-human vs human-robot) in 21 participants investigating mentalizing and social motivation—directly addresses social processing in humans. Abstract does not explicitly state participants’ ages or health, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

FMRI study examining visual short-term memory for emotional (angry) faces — a social perception/communication task. Abstract indicates task-based fMRI and likely healthy adult participants; no exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study where subjects encoded facts about unfamiliar people, showing person-selective ATL responses and connectivity with social cognition network—addresses perception/understanding of others. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages/health; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study probing neural responses to others' social actions (evaluating compliance/noncompliance), clearly addressing social processing. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so cannot confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult (17–65) sample.

This study used resting-state fMRI (no task-based social processing) in young adults with high-functioning ASD and controls. The review requires task-based fMRI during social-related processing in healthy adults; resting-state studies do not meet the task requirement.

Pharmaco-fMRI study with healthy adult participants (153 men, 151 women) performing the iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma, a social interaction task probing unreciprocated cooperation. Fits the review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI was conducted while participants viewed dynamic facial expressions (social-emotion processing), meeting the social-related task requirement. The abstract indicates empirical data in human participants (likely healthy) and is not a review. Age range not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Study reports fMRI during processing of social (emotional facial) stimuli and includes a healthy control group. Age range of controls is not specified in the abstract, so full-text review needed to confirm 17–65 criterion, but abstract is relevant to the review objective.

Participants are adolescents/youth rather than healthy adults. The review requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65; this study focuses on anxious and healthy adolescents, so does not meet the age criterion despite using fMRI social tasks.

The study uses fMRI of social-related processing (sadness introspection/facial emotion task) in healthy adolescent samples. However, participants are age 16–17, so it is unclear whether the sample meets the review’s adult age criterion (17–65). Abstract lacks detail on number ≥17. Ambiguous eligibility -> include for full-text review.

Study reports fMRI in healthy adult participants performing collaborative vs. individual learning and a communicative retrieval task that engages mentalizing/understanding-others networks. This is a social-related processing task measured with fMRI and is not a review, meeting the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study directly examines self-, mother- and theory-of-mind (social attribution) processing—meets social-related task criterion. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy adult sample; insufficient info to confirm age/health, so include for full-text review to verify eligibility (healthy adults 17–65).

The study uses resting-state fMRI to examine connectivity biomarkers; the abstract does not describe any social-related task performed during scanning. Although healthy controls are included, it does not meet the inclusion requirement of task-based social processing.

Abstract discusses ERP methods and neural plasticity, not functional MRI. No mention of fMRI scans, social-related tasks, or healthy adult participants; appears to be a review. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants (ages 20–41) performed a social interaction discrimination task (point-light displays). Meets inclusion: social-related task, healthy adults 17–65 present. Not a review/meta-analysis.

Abstract describes a comparative review of face perception across animal species and behavioral experiments; it does not report an fMRI study in healthy adult humans performing social-related tasks. It appears to be a review article rather than original human fMRI research.

fMRI study examining impression formation (perception/understanding of others), a social cognitive task. Conducted in human participants during task; implies healthy adult sample. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for full review.

fMRI study where young adults viewed emotional facial expressions (a social-processing task—perception/understanding of others). Includes matched healthy control group. Participants are within adult age range and the study is an original research article (not a review).

The study used fMRI to measure neural responses during a social exclusion (social pain) task in 21 healthy volunteers, directly addressing social-related processing in adults. No exclusion criteria are met. Although exact ages aren’t reported in the abstract, inclusion should proceed (full text can confirm age range).

fMRI study using a social joint-attention task examining how observers represent what another person sees (Perception and Understanding of Others). Participants appear to be healthy adults; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of healthy adult participants performing communicative speech (social communication) tasks, directly addressing social-related processing; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study using a social interaction task (human-human competition) engaging Theory of Mind and executive processes in healthy subjects. Fits review objective of social processing in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, but sufficient to include for full-text confirmation.

Functional MRI study with healthy adult participants (n=64) examining mentalizing/understanding of others (self–other anchoring-and-adjustment). Task is social cognition (inferring others' preferences). Not a review or meta-analysis. Satisfies inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract describes fMRI of social cognition in schizophrenia but does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because the presence of healthy participants is unclear, this should be included for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study with 16 healthy adult volunteers performing a social interaction task (matching-pennies) against human, android, robots, and computer; examines perception/understanding of others (social cognition). Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of mirror neuron system using observation of goal-directed hand actions, addressing social-cognitive processes (empathy, perspective-taking, self–other differentiation). Includes a non-alexithymia healthy adult control group (n=13) within the 17–65 range. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.
Participants were non-human (dogs). The meta-analysis requires fMRI studies in healthy human adults (ages 17–65). Thus the study does not meet the participant inclusion criterion.

Study used resting-state fMRI in multiple sclerosis patients and does not report a healthy control group or task-based social processing. It therefore lacks a healthy participant sample and a social-related task required for inclusion.

fMRI was used during a social task (threat-of-shock while holding friend/stranger/no hand), targeting social regulation/affiliation. Participants were healthy adults (age 24). No exclusion criteria met. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion.

fMRI study directly examines social-cognitive processes (empathy, Theory of Mind, self–other differentiation) during task performance in human participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify clinical sample or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample and other details.

fMRI study examining processing of dynamic happy facial expressions with social interaction cues (social-related task). Includes a non-SPD (healthy) control group. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm age 17–65 and other eligibility details.
Participants are infants (3–7 months), whereas the meta-analysis requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65. Study does not meet the population inclusion criterion.

fMRI study examining observation of social interactions and gaze—clearly a social-related task targeting social cognition. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health; include for full-text review to confirm that participants are healthy adults (17–65).

Abstract reports an fMRI study using a social task (Cyberball and a modified Dictator Game) examining responses to social exclusion, punishment, and forgiveness. Participants appear to be healthy adults and no systematic review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm ages and health status.

fMRI was conducted while healthy adult participants performed anticipation of others' actions in a sport context, which targets perception and understanding of others (a social processing construct). Participants appear to be healthy adults; study is original research, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient evidence to meet inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study examining processing of others' physical and emotional pain (Theory of Mind), involving healthy participants performing social-related tasks. Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults; abstract sufficiently indicates eligibility for inclusion.

Study used simultaneous fMRI during live verbal social interaction (social communication) in 11 pairs of adult female friends, meeting the social-related task and healthy adult participant criteria. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

This fMRI study examines neural activity during general and contextual self-judgments—a social-related task (Perception and Understanding of Self). It uses human participants across cultures, presumably healthy adults, and is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review). Include for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining empathy/affective responses to human and animal suffering (social-related processing: perception/understanding of others). Groups are healthy omnivores, vegetarians, vegans. Meets inclusion (task-based fMRI of social processing); not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

Study used resting-state fMRI (ABIDE) with no task-based social processing reported. Although healthy controls are included, absence of a social-related task means it does not meet the review's inclusion criteria.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Although healthy controls were included, no social-related task was administered, so it fails the inclusion requirement of fMRI during a social-related task.
Resting-state fMRI in children/adolescents (including ASD) — not a task-based social processing fMRI study and does not include healthy adult participants (age 17–65). Thus fails inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining social cognition (mirror neuron and mentalizing systems) during social-related tasks. Likely uses healthy adult participants; ages not specified in abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

This publication is an ALE meta-analysis of fMRI studies (a meta-analysis), meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses; it does not present original primary fMRI data on healthy adults.

Study reports fMRI during a face-discrimination task (social-related processing) and includes an age- and gender-matched healthy adult control group. No exclusion criteria are met based on the abstract.

Participants are children (mean age 10.2 years), not adults within the required 17–65 age range, so the study does not meet the age-based inclusion criterion despite being an fMRI study of social communication.

This article reports a meta-analysis across 12 fMRI studies rather than original fMRI data collected during social tasks. It meets the exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses', so exclude.

The article is a review of genetics and neural-systems research in autism, not an original fMRI study. The abstract describes synthesizing literature and proposing phenotypes rather than reporting functional MRI data collected during social tasks in healthy adults, so it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Study used fMRI during a social-related task (direct vs. averted gaze) in N=55 healthy adult males, investigating amygdala responses; not a review/meta-analysis. Satisfies inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study using point-light displays of human locomotion assesses biological motion perception — a form of social perception/understanding of others. Abstract implies human participants and reports task-based fMRI connectivity. Although participant ages/health status aren’t explicitly stated, there’s no exclusion criterion met; include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

fMRI data were collected while healthy adult participants (n=15) viewed and rated animated social interactions—this is a social-processing task involving perception/understanding of others. Study is empirical (not a review) and fits age/healthy participant criteria. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

Abstract reports an fMRI whole-brain analysis of neural correlates of self- and others’ agentic/communal evaluations (social cognition: perception/understanding of self/others). No evidence it's a review; participant health/ages not specified, so full text needed to confirm age range, but the study meets the review topic and should be included for full-text screening.

Study uses fast fMRI in human participants to examine neural responses to human voices, which constitutes social communication/perception. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient evidence of relevance to social-related processing.

Participants are adolescents (not clearly within the required adult age range 17–65) and the fMRI task was the Monetary Incentive Delay (monetary reward), which is not a social-related task as defined by the review. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Task-based fMRI study manipulating social-cognitive processes (empathy and Theory of Mind) with healthy adult samples (N=90, N=178). Investigates perception/understanding of others and reports neural correlates and behavior relations. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in adults.

Abstract reports fMRI of body-checking in anorexia nervosa patients and does not specify inclusion of a healthy control group or participant ages. Task may relate to self-perception (a social-related construct), but information is insufficient to confirm criteria — include for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy adults examining charitable donation decisions—a social decision-making task engaging regions for social cognition. The abstract reports task-based BOLD results and connectivity, meeting inclusion criteria for social-related processing in healthy adults. Not a review or meta-analysis.

FMRI study of face processing (social perception/understanding of others) using a continuous sample from age 6 through adulthood. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not explicitly state adult age ranges (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult group within 17–65.

fMRI conducted during a social-related task (processing dynamic and static facial expressions). Study includes age- and sex-matched typically developing control group (healthy participants). Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of social cognition/social judgments, meeting the imaging and task relevance criteria. The abstract does not clearly report inclusion of a healthy control group aged 17–65, so full-text review is needed to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (perception of in-group vs out-group actions). It investigates social perception/neural mechanisms, fits inclusion criteria and is not a review. Sufficient detail in abstract to include for full-text data extraction.

Task-based fMRI study of social processing (action-intention judgment) that includes a healthy control group (20 typically developing participants). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related task and presence of healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI was used to assess neural correlates of self- and other-related social cognition; study includes a healthy control group alongside BPD participants (adult sample); task paradigms assess perception/understanding of self and others; not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI with a social interaction (cyber-ball) assessing learned social roles/valence—fits social processing. Participant health and ages aren’t explicitly stated in the abstract, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65). No exclusion criteria met.

Study reports an fMRI experiment of social interaction (gaze/social reward processing) and includes healthy control groups (ages within 17–65). The task is social-related; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract discusses fMRI applications to social cognition and mentions an example (simultaneous fMRI for joint attention) and neural substrates of prosocial behavior, but it is unclear whether original fMRI data on healthy adults (ages 17–65) were collected or if this is a review.
