Insufficient information to determine eligibility from the abstract alone — include for full-text review.

fMRI study of emotion recognition (social cognition/perception of others) that includes a healthy control group alongside schizophrenia patients, meeting the review’s criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

Participants are children with benign childhood epilepsy (BCECTS), not healthy adults aged 17–65. The study focuses on pediatric clinical population, so it does not meet the age/healthy adult inclusion criteria.

Participants are adult incarcerated offenders (clinical/forensic sample) with no indication of a healthy control group. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy adults age 17–65, so this study does not meet criteria based on the abstract.

The study used fMRI during a face emotion discrimination task (social-related processing). It compared community participants high vs. low in social anhedonia (presumably healthy adults) and is not a review. This meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adult samples.

fMRI study of social cognition in human participants comparing close (romantic partner) vs non-close others; reports neural activations (OFC, ACC). No indication of psychiatric/neurological samples. Age not specified but likely healthy adults—include for full-text review.

Resting-state fMRI study with intranasal oxytocin; no task-based social processing was performed. Although participants were healthy adults, inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task, which is not met.

Abstract reports an fMRI BOLD response during an eyes task (a social cognition/Theory of Mind task). It addresses social processing. Participant details (ages, presence of a healthy control group) are not specified; therefore inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm that at least one healthy adult group (17–65) was scanned.

This is a resting-state fMRI study with no task-based social processing paradigm. The meta-analysis requires task-based fMRI during social-related tasks in healthy adults; although healthy controls are included, the absence of a social task means it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI study directly examining neural processing of social vs nonsocial gestures using naturalistic stimuli, matching review objective. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study manipulating social gaze vs nonsocial cues during action control, addressing social perception/cognition. Although participant demographics are not specified, the task involves social-related processing in human subjects and no exclusion criteria apply. Include for full-text review to confirm participant age/health.

Participants are adolescents aged 9–17. The review requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65; this study contains no adult-only group. Although it uses fMRI with a social task, the sample age range excludes it from the review.

fMRI study with 34 healthy adult participants examining DMPFC responses to social interactions during naturalistic movie viewing—addresses perception/understanding of others; not a review or meta-analysis.

Original study used fMRI during a social-cognition task (responses to stigmatized individuals) in healthy young and older adults. It investigates perception/understanding of others and includes a young adult group likely within the 17–65 age range, meeting inclusion criteria.

Human fMRI study of empathic decision-making (social processing: empathy, self- vs other-simulation) in healthy adults; task involved making choices for self vs others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy participants.

fMRI study of healthy participants performing a social-related task (observing third-person social interactions/biological motion). Targets perception/understanding of others; adult sample implied; not a review. Abstract gives sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria for full data extraction.

Dyadic fMRI of live eye contact examines social interaction and social-cognitive networks, meeting the review’s focus on social-related processing. Abstract does not state participant ages or health status; insufficient detail for definitive exclusion, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and task specifics.

Abstract describes primary fMRI research using simultaneous scanning ('Hyperscan') during a social interaction (a deception game) between human participants. This addresses social processing and is not a review; likely healthy adult subjects. Meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.

Participants are adolescents (ages 12–15) rather than adults; the meta-analysis requires healthy participants aged 17–65. Although an fMRI social task was used, the sample falls outside the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study of empathy/perspective-taking in 18 healthy participants addresses social processing (perception/understanding of self and others), matching the review objective. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm they fall within 17–65.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires an fMRI scan during a social-related task; resting-state connectivity does not meet this criterion. Abstract also focuses on schizophrenia patients (unclear healthy task group).

fMRI study investigating political attitudes (social cognition/perception of others) while participants completed IAT with faces/names—meets modality and social-task criteria. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly confirm healthy adult sample; include for full-text review to verify participants are aged 17–65 and healthy.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rs-fMRI) following cTBS, not an fMRI scan while participants performed a social-related task. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring task-based social processing during the scan.

fMRI study with 22 healthy adults assessing perception of CT-targeted affective (social) touch; investigates brain regions involved in social perception/cognition (mPFC, STS, insula, amygdala). Fits inclusion criteria for social-related processing in healthy adults and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

Resting-state fMRI (no social task) and participants are male adolescents rather than healthy adults (17–65). Although a healthy control group is present, the study does not report task-based social processing in healthy adults, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adults presenting observation of non-painful touch, a social-perception task (perception/understanding of others) linked to empathy. Experimental fMRI data reported; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract addresses Theory of Mind/mentalization and refers to functional neuroimaging but does not explicitly state that an fMRI was conducted or report participant/sample details. Inclusion requires fMRI in healthy adults performing a social task; abstract information is insufficient, so include for full-text review to confirm methods and sample.

The study sampled adolescents (children/adolescents) rather than healthy adults; no healthy participant group aged 17–65 is reported. Although it uses fMRI on social processing, it fails the age criterion for inclusion.

fMRI study of affective theory of mind (social cognition) in healthy adult participants (22 enrolled, 21 analyzed). Task involves social-emotional judgments about others’ emotions, meeting the review’s social processing criterion. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Participants are children (age range 7–12). Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65, which is not met. Although an fMRI social task was used, the sample age excludes the study.

fMRI study using an interactive Domino task that probes mentalizing/social cognition; includes a healthy control group of adults aged 18–34 (within 17–65). Study directly examines social-related processing in healthy participants and is not a review.

fMRI was used to investigate social understanding (processing social information) and the study includes a matched healthy control group of adults (23 controls). Participants are adults (high-functioning ASD and controls), meeting age criterion. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports a functional MRI study in normal adult volunteers performing a social-related task (viewing videos of positive and negative social encounters) assessing brain activation. Participants are healthy adults; it is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review, and fits the inclusion criteria.

The study uses fMRI of social perspective-taking but the healthy participant group are adolescents (ages 12–19). No healthy adult group within the required 17–65 age range is present, so it does not meet inclusion age criteria.

Abstract reports analysis of large-scale brain network/community structure during rest and unspecified task states; it does not mention social-related tasks, social cognition, or related constructs in healthy adults, so it is not relevant to the review.

fMRI hyperscanning study of live vs replay eye contact in adult pairs (healthy adults implied) investigating neural substrates of social interaction (eye contact). Meets criterion: functional MRI during a social-related task in healthy adults; not a review.
fMRI was used while healthy adult participants (women, ages within 17–65) performed a social perception task (judging social relationships from animations). Study is primary research, not a review.

fMRI study examining perception of nonverbal emotional social signals (voice and face) and its relation to trait emotional intelligence in individual subjects. This addresses social-related processing in humans and is empirical (not a review). Participant health/age not explicitly stated but context implies healthy adult subjects; criteria met for inclusion based on available abstract.

fMRI study probing mirror neuron responses and emotion processing related to social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Abstract implies healthy participants and does not meet any exclusion criteria. Age range not specified—include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.
This record is a systematic review/meta-analysis protocol, not a primary fMRI study of social processing in humans; it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study with 25 healthy adult participants examining facial color processing, which relates to social communication and perception of others. Task involved viewing faces (social stimuli). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria met.
Study sample comprises children and adolescents (developmental sample); no healthy adult group aged 17–65 is reported, so it does not meet the age criterion for inclusion.

fMRI study examines processing of emotional facial expressions (social communication/perception) in humans. Although abstract also includes monkeys, it reports human fMRI responses and addresses social-related processing. Participant ages/health not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample.
Participants are non-human (seven domestic dogs). The review requires fMRI studies in healthy human adults (age 17–65), so this study does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI in a sample of 13 PTSD patients with pre/post therapy scans and does not mention any healthy control group. Meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy adults (17–65). Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

The article is a review of seven structural/functional MRI studies in ADHD samples rather than a primary fMRI study of healthy adults. It is a review paper and focuses on clinical (ADHD) participants, so it does not meet inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing studies in healthy adults.

Event-related fMRI using the false belief paradigm assessed understanding others' mental states (social cognition) in healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria of fMRI during a social-related task; no exclusion criteria evident. Age range not specified—include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/details.

The study reports fMRI in schizophrenia participants only (two patient groups: AT+SCT and CG) with no healthy adult control/group described. Although the task is social (facial emotion recognition), it fails the inclusion requirement of at least one healthy participant group (age 17–65).

This is an original fMRI study investigating social-affective processing (mimicry modulation by emotion and group membership), addressing social cognition/affiliation in human participants. It is not a review and fits the review objective. Participant health status and age range not specified but study appears to involve healthy adults; abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

Participants are preadolescents (age 11); inclusion requires adults aged 17–65. Although fMRI social evaluation task was used, the sample age falls outside the eligible range, so the study should be excluded.

Functional MRI was used to examine affiliative (social/attachment) processing in human participants, directly addressing the review objective. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state that participants were healthy (17–65), so there is insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria—warranting inclusion for full-text review.

fMRI study of social-cognitive processes (evaluative judgments of guilt and embarrassment / Theory of Mind) conducted in 19 healthy volunteers during task performance. This meets the review’s inclusion of social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and other eligibility details.

fMRI was performed while healthy adult men completed a social-processing task (gender judgments of faces varying in gaze) and additional social cognition tests (fear recognition, theory of mind). Participants are healthy adults from the general population and the study examines social-related neural processing, meeting inclusion criteria.

Neuroimaging study investigating brain responses to observed social interactions; addresses social perception/understanding. Abstract implies healthy adult participants and an experimental task. Abstract lacks full methods detail, so include for full-text confirmation.

Participants were exclusively outpatient schizophrenia patients; no healthy control or healthy participant group (age 17–65) is reported. Thus the study does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one group of healthy adults.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task) to assess ASD diagnostic biomarkers; it does not involve a task-based social processing paradigm. Fails inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI social-related task.

Abstract reports an fMRI study examining self-experience and self-other relationship (social cognition) and includes a healthy control group. However it is unclear whether scans were task-based social processing or intrinsic/resting-state connectivity and participant ages are not given. Insufficient detail to confirm task-based social paradigm—include for full-text review.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than participants performing a social-related task during scanning. Although it examines face memory and social networks in healthy adults, it does not meet the task-based fMRI inclusion criterion.

Abstract does not specify use of fMRI or participant ages/groups; it concerns social imitation in autism, which may include healthy controls and social processing tasks. Because key inclusion criteria (fMRI in healthy adults) cannot be confirmed from the abstract, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study examining processing of others' trustworthiness (social cognition) in healthy younger and older adults. Abstract does not state ages but task is social-related and involves healthy participants; insufficient age detail to exclude, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages meet 17–65 criterion.

fMRI study using attributional decision tasks probing self-responsibility and self-serving bias (social cognition). Abstract describes findings in 'normal subjects', indicating healthy adult participants. Fits inclusion: functional MRI during a social-related task with healthy participants; not a review.

fMRI study manipulating sociality during an n-back task, reporting activation in social cognition and face-processing regions. Involves human participants and addresses social processing. Abstract lacks explicit age range but meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study with healthy participants investigating gestures during speech (social communication), directly addressing social-related processing. Abstract lacks participant age details but otherwise meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm demographics and details.

Participants are described as youth/pediatric and 'unaffected youth at familial risk'—not healthy adults aged 17–65. The study focuses on at-risk pediatric population, so it does not meet the age/participant criteria for inclusion.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a socially relevant task (competitive interaction observing angry vs neutral facial expressions). Addresses social perception and aggression; not a review; meets age/participant and task-related inclusion criteria.

fMRI was performed while healthy adult participants (20 male volunteers) viewed campaign videos designed to elicit empathy — a social-cognitive task involving perception/understanding of others. Participants are healthy adults and the study is primary research (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

The study uses fMRI of social/face processing but involves a child with autism and child comparison participants; no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is included. Inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy adult group is not met.
fMRI study used face perception with emotional/neutral stimuli (a social cognition task) and included a healthy control group; meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

Abstract describes brain responses during evaluation of face approachability, a social-perception task in humans. However, the abstract does not explicitly state that functional MRI was used. Because modality and participant details are insufficient, include for full-text review to confirm fMRI and healthy adult sample.

fMRI study (n=20) examining face–voice integration, a social perceptual/communication task involving perception of others. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not state ages; include for full-text review to confirm participant age/health details.

Empirical fMRI study (N=26) in healthy adults performing a social learning task (evaluating others' generosity) with a non-social control; investigates social-related processing and reports neural prediction-error signals. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes a review of neuroimaging (fMRI/PET) studies rather than reporting an original fMRI experiment in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and lacks participant/method details needed for inclusion.

Original fMRI study using a social task (making a listener laugh) probing self/other processing, mPFC, ventral striatum and auditory cortex. Abstract describes healthy adult-like participants (no clinical sample mentioned). Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing in humans; not a review.

Abstract does not specify whether healthy adult controls (age 17–65) participated or details of an fMRI social task. Likely an fMRI connectivity study in Asperger’s, but information is insufficient to confirm inclusion criteria. Include for full-text review to determine presence of healthy adult group and social task.

fMRI study examining neural processing of social reputation (positive/negative) during a social task in male and female participants. This investigates social-related processing in healthy adult subjects and is not a review/meta-analysis, meeting inclusion criteria.

The study used resting-state fMRI (ALFF and RSFC) rather than a task-based social processing fMRI. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task; resting-state studies do not meet this criterion.

Abstract reports neuronal correlates of social cognition (affective theory of mind) and brain activation in amygdala/STS, implying neuroimaging during social tasks; however it does not explicitly state presence of healthy control group or specify fMRI. Information is insufficient to be certain, so include for full-text review to confirm methods and sample composition.

fMRI was conducted while healthy young adults labeled brief emotional facial expressions—a social cognitive task (perception/understanding of others). Participants are healthy and within the adult range. Study is empirical, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing in healthy adults.

The study used resting-state fMRI (fALFF) to relate spontaneous brain activity to psychometric measures; fMRI was not conducted while participants performed a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during social processing, so this abstract does not meet the eligibility criteria.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed the Ultimatum Game, a social decision-making task assessing cooperation/response to others (social processing). The study involves healthy adult participants in a randomized longitudinal design (mindfulness vs control). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text review.

Study examines early adolescents (male and female adolescents) using fMRI; no evidence of any participant group within the required adult age range (17–65). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion age criterion for the review.

Participants are children. The abstract repeatedly refers to 'children' (siblings, control children, and a sample of children with autism), so no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is included. Although fMRI and social task are present, the age criterion is not met.

fMRI study using a social contingency task probing self-relevant social reward processing; includes a healthy, age-matched neurotypical adult control group (24 TD adults, within adult age range). Fits social processing constructs and meets inclusion criteria.
Resting-state fMRI (no social task) in adolescent males, including ASD and neurotypical groups. Not a task-based fMRI study of healthy adults (age 17–65), so excluded.

fMRI study scanning participants during exposure to messages about social influence; investigates social-related processes (mentalizing, reward) and influencer communication. Abstract does not state participant ages/health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI used during social-related tasks (emotion and age judgments of faces). Study includes a healthy community control group, and is not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify ages, but presence of healthy adult controls meets inclusion; full-text can confirm age range if needed.

fMRI study using a social task (direct vs averted gaze) with a healthy control group (n=16). Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and extract details.

Participants are boys aged 11–16 (adolescents). The review requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65. Although the study uses fMRI and a social task, no healthy adult group is included, so it does not meet the age-based inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of eye-gaze and face identity perception—social communication/Perception-of-Others domain. Likely involves healthy human participants but ages not specified. No exclusion criteria met; include for full-text to confirm participant ages/health.
Study used fMRI in children aged 7–10 only; inclusion requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65. Therefore it does not meet the age criterion for inclusion.

fMRI study investigating audiovisual integration of non-verbal emotional signals—a social-communication/perception task. Abstract indicates task-based fMRI and typical healthy adult sample implied but does not specify ages/health. Insufficient participant details for final determination, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants performing a task involving humor appreciation (social communication). Whole-brain BOLD responses reported and correlations with trait cheerfulness—meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining neural correlates of promotion/prevention goals (self-regulation, personal goal pursuit) — a form of social-cognitive processing related to perception/understanding of self. Sixteen adult participants underwent fMRI; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for full-text review.

fMRI study examines brain responses while viewing emotional faces (social perception/understanding of others), fitting the review objective. The abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages; insufficient information to confirm criteria, so include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample (17–65).

The study uses fMRI to examine perception of biological motion—a social cognitive task—matching the review topic. However, the abstract does not specify whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because this key eligibility detail is missing, include for full-text review to determine whether healthy participants were studied.

Event-related fMRI was used while participants viewed animations manipulating intentionality (agency attribution)—a social perception/understanding task. Study reports neural correlates of attributing intention in (presumably) healthy adult participants (25 per condition). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining processing of communicative vs noncommunicative human vocalizations (social communication). Appears to involve human participants and addresses social communication in the STS. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for healthy adult fMRI studies.

Task-based fMRI study assessing theory of mind (social cognition) in healthy younger and older adults. The study reports task-based fMRI during a social-related theory-of-mind task, meeting the review objective. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although exact ages aren't specified, inclusion requires at least one healthy group aged 17–65; ‘younger adults’ likely meet this range. Hence include for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI MVPA study of affective/social touch in autism but does not clearly state whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) participated or provide full task/sample details. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone—include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy participants and task specifics.

fMRI was used while participants played an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma—a social decision-making task involving trust/cooperation. Study appears to involve healthy adult volunteers though ages/health not explicitly stated; include for full-text review to confirm participant health status and age range.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed a standardized facial emotion recognition task (social communication/perception). Participants were healthy adults (high vs low alexithymia groups). This directly meets the review’s social-processing and healthy adult fMRI inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria apply.

Abstract describes altered social-cognition networks in ASD but does not specify whether fMRI was task-based (social processing) or resting-state; likely includes a healthy control group but ages are not reported. Insufficient information to determine inclusion, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study with healthy human participants performing social evaluation/impression-formation tasks (social vs non-social conditions). Includes young adult group (likely within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Therefore meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of gaze processing (a social-related task) that includes a typically developing healthy comparison group. Abstract does not specify ages (only ‘adolescents and adults’), so eligibility re: 17–65 cannot be confirmed from abstract alone — include for full-text review to verify age range and other details.

Participants are children (NVLD, ASD, and typically developing children), not within the required adult age range (17–65). The abstract also does not indicate an fMRI social task (appears to assess network connectivity), so it fails inclusion criteria.

The study uses resting-state fMRI combined with intraoperative cortical stimulation to map the mentalizing network, not an fMRI scan during a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI in humans (age 17–65); resting-state and likely patient intraoperative context do not meet criteria.

fMRI study examining empathy (perception/understanding of others' pain) that includes healthy control participants. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm age range and other eligibility details.

This paper is a review article summarizing findings (pharmacological fMRI and imaging genetics) rather than reporting an original fMRI experiment with participants performing social tasks. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

This article is a systematic review of neuroscience studies (including fMRI) in autism rather than an original fMRI study of human participants. It meets the exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses', so it should be excluded from the meta-analysis of primary fMRI studies in healthy adults.

Narrative review article summarizing decades of affect neuropsychology and fMRI findings, not an original fMRI study with primary data in healthy adults. Meets exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

This paper is a systematic review of fMRI and DTI studies in ASD (a review/meta-analysis), which meets the exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses.' No original fMRI data in healthy adults is reported in the abstract.
Participants are infants aged 4–7 months, not healthy adults aged 17–65 as required by the review; therefore the study does not meet the participant age criterion for inclusion.

Study used fMRI during a Body Perception task probing perception/understanding of self and others (social-related processing). Sample comprised healthy adult participants (15 males, 15 females) within the target age range. Original empirical study, not a review.

Single-case report of an 8-year-old with massive bilateral frontal damage (clinical pediatric case), not a sample of healthy adults aged 17–65. Although imaging (fMRI) was used, the study does not report fMRI of healthy adult participants performing a social-related task. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI was used during reflection on personal attributes of self and mother, which is a social-cognitive task (perception/understanding of self and others). Sample comprised Chinese adults (healthy) within the adult age range. Study is empirical fMRI research, not a review, and meets the inclusion criteria.

Participants are adolescents (ages 12–18); the study does not include a group of healthy adults aged 17–65 as required by the review objective. Therefore it does not meet the population inclusion criterion.

fMRI study examining neural substrates of impression formation (a social cognition task) in human participants; consistent with social processing constructs and likely healthy adult sample; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

Original research using fMRI examining perception and production of prosody and correlations with empathy—addresses social communication and perception of others in human participants. Not a review. Abstract does not state ages, but likely healthy adult sample; meets review objective. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

This article is a quantitative meta-analysis of 48 fMRI studies (a systematic review/meta-analysis). The exclusion criteria explicitly exclude systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so exclude despite relevant topic (pragmatic social communication).

Task-based functional MRI during a social interaction task (modified prisoner's dilemma) with a healthy control group (n=20) is reported; study is not a review. Abstract does not state participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and extract details.

Abstract reports human fMRI findings on social cognition (simulation of others' valuation and action prediction errors) but is presented as a review and lacks participant age/group details. Insufficient information to confirm eligibility, so include for full-text review to verify that functional MRI was conducted in healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI study where participants performed social tasks (cooperation vs. competition) involving monitoring others’ actions and social cognition. No indication it is a review/meta-analysis; appears to involve human subjects likely healthy adults. Age/health not specified in abstract—include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

The article is explicitly a systematic review of neuroimaging studies (not an original fMRI study of participants). It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses, so it should be excluded.

fMRI study examining processing of goal-directed actions and intention detection (perception/understanding of others), which fits social-related processing. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (17–65), so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and task details.

Abstract does not specify that an fMRI scan was conducted during a social-related task nor that a healthy adult (17–65) control group was included. Topic concerns social processing (maternal response), but methodological details are insufficient in the abstract—include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study measuring brain activity during perception of emotional (fearful vs neutral) gestures — a social-related task. Includes both autism and control (healthy) participants; not a review. Fits inclusion of at least one healthy adult group for social processing fMRI.

fMRI study examining self-referential processing during intergroup competition (social cognition). Appears to involve healthy adult participants, though ages/details aren’t specified in the abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and eligibility.

Narrative review (not an original task-based fMRI study) focusing on adolescent brain development rather than task-based social processing in healthy adults (age 17–65). Meets exclusion criterion for reviews; exclude.

fMRI study probing social-related processing (attending to meaning vs physical properties; mPFC/TPJ activations relevant to social cognition). Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state participants were healthy adults, so eligibility (age 17–65, healthy) cannot be confirmed from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

fMRI study measuring brain responses during a naturalistic social task (watching a sitcom) assessing social perception/mentalizing; includes a healthy control participant group alongside ASD group; not a review. Abstract provides enough info to meet inclusion or at minimum warrants full-text review.

Abstract indicates investigation of neural correlates of mentalizing (a social cognition process) in adults but does not specify that fMRI was used during a social task nor state participant health/age. Information is insufficient to determine eligibility from the abstract alone, so include for full-text review to confirm methods and sample.

fMRI study of pragmatic/social communication (integration of speaker characteristics with sentence content) in adults; includes a matched healthy control group (adults within 17–65 range). Not a review. Thus meets criteria for social-related fMRI research in healthy adults.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants using videos of actors to assess recognition of 'vitality forms'—a social perceptual process (perception/understanding of others). Fits inclusion (social-related fMRI in healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail.

This is a literature review article, not an original fMRI study. It focuses on motor lateralization in autism rather than fMRI of social-related tasks in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews.

Non-human primate study (monkeys); not conducted in healthy human participants aged 17–65. Although about face/body processing (social cognition-related), the abstract describes animal fMRI and microstimulation, so it does not meet the human-participant inclusion criterion.

Abstract links neuroimaging to social cognition/emotional intelligence but does not specify whether an fMRI social-task was used or report participant health/age. Insufficient info to rule out inclusion—include for full-text review.

fMRI study using an interpersonal pleasant-touch paradigm assessing social reward/social-context processing. Includes a matched healthy control group of adult non-users (meets requirement of at least one healthy group). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing an aesthetic judgment task; authors report activation of Theory-of-Mind and social-cognition regions (PCC/PC, arMFC, TPJ) linked to artistic music appreciation, fitting ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ social processing.

Abstract mentions oxytocin modulation of amygdala reactivity but does not specify that an fMRI social-related task was used or participant demographics. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to determine task type and sample (healthy adults).

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no task), so participants did not perform a social-related task during scanning. Although healthy controls are included, the study fails the requirement for task-based social processing.

fMRI was recorded while participants recalled World War II displays, a task probing collective/social memory and medial prefrontal social-cognitive processing. Abstract implies human participants likely healthy adults. Participant age/health not explicitly stated, so full text should be checked for eligibility; include for full-text review.

fMRI study measuring brain activity during naturalistic social interaction (charades) between participants; addresses social communication and mirroring/mentalizing in humans. Not a review; likely healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while participants made social judgements (empathy and forgivability), which are social-cognitive tasks. Ten volunteers participated (presumed healthy adults). Study fits review objective and inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria are met.

Abstract focuses on cognitive deficits in schizophrenia and multimodal neuroimaging; it does not state that an fMRI social task was used nor that healthy adults performed social-related processing. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

Study used fMRI during passive viewing of natural movies and reports voxel responses to ‘social communication’ categories, indicating social-related processing. Abstract lacks explicit participant age and detailed task description; include for full-text review to confirm participant characteristics and whether the paradigm fits inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI in 26 healthy adult participants examining perception of others' pain and social context/agency (empathy, perception of others). This is a social-related task (understanding others) and meets participant criteria; not a review.

This is a review article of mirror neuron findings and an introduction to a special issue, not a primary fMRI study. The abstract does not report original functional MRI data in healthy adults. Exclude per exclusion criterion (reviews/meta-analyses).

The study uses fMRI with a face emotional processing paradigm, which is a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and ages.

Abstract reports fMRI in a sample of 14 females with borderline personality disorder and focuses on ACEs and BPD symptomatology; no healthy control group (age 17–65) is mentioned. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group.

The abstract describes a review of studies on social cognition in bipolar disorder rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It is a review article (excluded per exclusion criteria) and lacks primary fMRI data on healthy participants.

fMRI was used during facial emotion processing, which is social-related (perception/understanding of others). Study includes a healthy control group of adults and is an original research article (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

Study uses fMRI during social evaluations and includes a healthy comparison group. However participants are described as adolescents and exact ages are not provided, so adult-age eligibility (17–65) cannot be confirmed from the abstract. Include for full-text review to verify age range and extract relevant data.

Study involves pediatric/adolescent participants (youth at familial risk and patients with bipolar disorder); no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is reported. Does not meet the requirement of at least one healthy adult group.

fMRI study investigating spontaneous retrieval of affective person knowledge during face perception—a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Participants appear to be healthy adults (no clinical groups reported). Not a review/meta-analysis. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study of social-emotional simulation (imagining another’s painful experience) with a healthy control group (24 adults). Task targets social-related processing; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of deception, which involves social-cognitive processing. Abstract does not specify whether healthy adults (ages 17–65) were included or participant details. Insufficient information to determine eligibility—include for full-text review.

Study examines development of the action observation network in early adolescence; participants are adolescents rather than healthy adults. Abstract gives no indication of a participant group aged 17–65, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy adult group.

Study reports an fMRI scan during a social threat reactivity task (socially threatening images), addressing social-related neural processing; includes a healthy control group of adult women (age-matched controls), meeting the criterion of at least one healthy participant group. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

Event-related fMRI study where healthy volunteers performed self, familiar, and unknown face judgments—task probes perception/understanding of self (social cognition). Meets inclusion of fMRI social-related task in healthy participants. Abstract lacks participant ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm age and other details.

fMRI study of healthy adult volunteers (N=40) performing a social-related task (viewing masked/unmasked facial emotions; affiliation-relevant emotions). Meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

This is an overview/review of magnetoencephalography (MEG), not an fMRI study. The abstract describes MEG methods and applications broadly, with no report of an fMRI experiment or social-related task in healthy adults. It is also a review-type article, meeting exclusion criteria.

Study uses structural and functional MRI connectivity from ABIDE I to classify ASD vs controls; the abstract does not describe any task-based fMRI or social-related task or social processing paradigm. Does not meet inclusion criterion requiring fMRI during a social-related task.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed a scanner-adapted Multifaceted Empathy Test (a social cognition/empathy task). The study includes a healthy control group (age-/gender-matched controls) alongside a BPD group, meeting participant criteria. Not a review.

The study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=20) investigating social-related processing (empathy: cognitive vs emotional responses) during receipt of empathic vs unempathic comments, with reported neural correlates. This directly fits the review objective and inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria (e.g., review/meta-analysis) apply.

fMRI study comparing neural responses to familiar vs unfamiliar faces (social processing: perception/understanding of others). Includes age‑matched control group of healthy participants alongside the patient. Not a review. Sufficiently meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

fMRI study examining neural responses to social influence (bystander effect) during an in-scanner task involving witnessing an emergency—addresses social processing (perception/understanding of others, social influence). Involves human participants (presumably healthy adults) and is an original empirical study, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

This study is an activation likelihood estimation meta-analysis (a meta-analysis), which meets the exclusion criterion excluding systematic reviews or meta-analyses. Therefore it should be excluded based on the abstract alone.

fMRI study of social communication (viewing, imitating, producing facial expressions and social hand gestures) in humans; addresses social-related processing and uses fMRI. Abstract does not explicitly state participant ages or health status, so include for full-text verification of healthy adult (17–65) sample.

Event-related fMRI study of evaluative judgments involving self-referential processing and theory of mind (social-related). Includes healthy age- and gender-matched control subjects (young adults within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social cognition (individuating vs categorical social judgments) in humans, meets review objective. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health status; not enough detail to confirm inclusion fully, so include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample (17–65).

Study used fMRI during a facial imitate/observe task (social processing) and includes people without severe mental illness (healthy controls). Fits inclusion of fMRI social task in adult healthy participants.

fMRI social task but sample comprises early adolescent girls (adolescents), i.e., participants under age 17. Does not meet inclusion age range (17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Exclude based on age.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of honesty-related neural signals that predict trust during social interactions, meeting the social-related task requirement. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Two fMRI experiments in human participants investigating theory-of-mind/mentalizing (social cognition) and representational content of social brain regions. Study involves functional neuroimaging during social-related tasks in healthy adults and is not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study examining perception/understanding of self vs others' body parts (social cognition). Not a review. Abstract implies human participants and uses fMRI during a social-related task. Participant ages/groups not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.
Participants are children (typically developing and ASD), not adults aged 17–65. Although the task (face processing) is social, the study population does not meet the healthy adult age criterion.

fMRI study of emotional prosody (a social communication task) reporting both ASD and healthy control participants. Includes social-related processing during fMRI and a healthy group; include for full-text review to confirm age range and details.

fMRI study investigating impression formation of people (social cognition) versus objects in healthy adult participants; directly addresses social-related processing. Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI study of social perception that includes a healthy comparison group. Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65 requirement), so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.

fMRI study of social decision-making from faces (social/affective judgments). Compares males, females, and individuals with ASD, implying a healthy control group; not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text verification of participant ages and details.

Abstract explicitly states this is a review of the neurobiology of social phobia; it does not report primary fMRI data or methods involving human participants. It discusses fMRI as a future technology rather than presenting an fMRI study. Therefore it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

Empirical fMRI study using a social cognition task (Movie for the Assessment of Social Cognition) investigating Theory of Mind networks in naturalistic conditions. Abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract lacks key information: it does not state that an fMRI was performed, whether the task involved social processing, or whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. The topic (reward in autism) could involve social reward processing, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study in healthy 'normal volunteers' examining social processing (identification and attribution of others' emotions), directly relevant to perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not state participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm age range and other eligibility details.

fMRI study where participants considered sharing news articles; neural activity linked to self-related processing and taking others’ perspectives (social cognition). Participants appear to be healthy adults and no exclusion criteria apply. Study directly examines social-related processing, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study with human participants performing action observation/execution tasks after sensorimotor training; measures mirror-system responses in premotor and parietal cortex. This addresses perception/understanding of others (social processing) in healthy adults and is not a review.

Abstract focuses on oxytocin effects in adults with autism but does not report whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included or whether fMRI was during a social task versus resting-state. Insufficient information to exclude; include for full-text review to determine task type and participant groups.

fMRI study with 78 healthy adult participants performing a task (reading narratives) that probes social-cognitive processing of protected values (engages mPFC, TPJ, posterior medial cortex). Fits 'Perception and Understanding of Others' social-related constructs and includes healthy adults; not a review.
All participants are adolescents (ages 11.1–15.5); the review requires at least one healthy adult group aged 17–65. The abstract provides no adult sample, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining social-related processing (implicit personal space/affiliation) using social vs non-social stimuli; double-blind placebo-controlled design implies healthy adult participants; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social fMRI in healthy adults.

This is a conceptual primer/review about brain-imaging principles, not an original fMRI study. The abstract contains no evidence of an fMRI experiment or participants performing a social-related task; thus it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study administering one-shot, anonymous prisoner's dilemma (a social decision-making task) examining neural correlates of social cognition. Participants appear to be healthy adults; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI was conducted while participants used Compassion-meditation and Reappraisal to modulate responses to film clips of people in distress, a social-related task involving affiliation/understanding others. Sample consists of human adult practitioners (healthy group). Study is empirical fMRI, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI study investigating social communication (L2 communicative speech) in healthy adult participants (N=30). Task is explicitly social/communicative and neural correlates reported; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

This paper is a narrative review of neuroimaging findings in autism rather than an original fMRI study with participants performing social tasks. It is a review article (excluded per criterion: systematic reviews/meta-analyses) and does not report primary fMRI data in healthy adults.

Participants are two young children with autism spectrum disorder; no group of healthy adult participants (age 17–65) is included. Therefore the study does not meet the criterion requiring at least one healthy adult group.

Abstract examines facial emotion processing comparing first-episode psychosis and healthy subjects—a social processing task that includes healthy participants. However, it does not explicitly state that functional MRI was used nor participants' ages; include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and age range.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social-communication task (evaluating feeling of being addressed); reports neural activations related to social processing. Not a review. Fits inclusion criteria.

The study uses resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. The inclusion criteria require fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults; absence of a social task means it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

Original fMRI study in human participants assessing perception of affective vocalisations (social communication). Task involves social-related processing (emotion discrimination); imaging performed in superior temporal lobe. No indication of clinical populations; fits healthy adult sample. Not a review/meta-analysis.

Participants are adolescents (study focuses on depressed and healthy adolescents), not healthy adults aged 17–65 as required by the review objective. Although an fMRI social task (Cyberball) was used and a healthy group is present, the population age range does not match, so exclude.

Functional MRI study examining neural responses to nonverbal social stimuli (biological vs scrambled motion) tied to social-network complexity, addressing social perception/communication. Conducted in humans with no clinical groups mentioned, fitting inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports fMRI measurement of amygdala responsiveness to social-phobia-related verbal stimuli (a social-related task) and includes a matched healthy control group (110 controls). Not a review. Although exact participant ages are not stated, the study clearly involves human adult participants and meets the review’s key criteria; include for full-text verification.

fMRI experiment examining social cognition (person perception and person knowledge) with participants performing social-related tasks. Abstract does not state participant age or health status; therefore include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults 17–65.

fMRI study of self-other referential processing (perception/understanding of self) in 20 women — a social-related task in healthy participants. Not a review. Age range not specified but participants appear to be adult; meets inclusion criteria for full-text review.

Functional MRI study examining attributions about social situations (perception/understanding of others) in human participants, directly addressing the review objective. Abstract does not report participant ages/health status, so include for full-text verification; not a review.

Abstract is a narrative overview but specifically mentions the author’s early fMRI studies of social emotions in humans. The abstract lacks methods, participant ages, and whether healthy adults were scanned. Insufficient detail to confirm eligibility; include for full-text review to verify primary fMRI data in healthy 17–65-year-olds.

This is a structural MRI volumetric study of the fusiform gyrus in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome and healthy controls, not a task-based functional MRI study of social processing. No fMRI social-related task in healthy adults is reported, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study where human participants performed an emotional classification task involving facial and vocal emotions—fits social communication/perception of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although participant ages/health not explicitly stated, study likely used healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm sample details.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants investigating self-referential (social) processing (conceptual and agentic self) during task-based scans; directly addresses perception/understanding of self. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

This is an editorial/introduction to a special issue, not an original empirical fMRI study. The abstract describes the issue and other articles but reports no fMRI methods, participants, or social-task data; therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion of a functional MRI study in humans.

fMRI study investigating social expectancy violations (warmth and competence) while participants viewed people and behavioral information—clearly a social-processing task in humans. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract implies typical healthy adult perceivers; include for full-text to confirm participant ages/health if needed.

Participants are children (ages 7–13) including autism and typically developing groups; no healthy adult (17–65) group tested. Thus does not meet inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy adult group.

Study participants are children (ASD and typically developing), not healthy adults aged 17–65 as required. Although it involves task-evoked and resting fMRI and social behavior measures, the age criterion is not met, so exclude based on population.
Abstract describes a review of neuroimaging literature (narrative/systematic review), not an original fMRI study. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews/meta-analyses—exclude.

fMRI study of social cue processing (fearful faces with gaze) and includes a matched healthy adult control group (26 adults). Task assesses social perception/communication; fits inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in adults.

Abstract describes fMRI-relevant social decision-making (ultimatum game) and investigates neuronal networks related to social cooperation. Age range and explicit confirmation of healthy adult participants (17–65) are not specified, and imaging modality is implied but not detailed—insufficient information to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and fMRI methods.

fMRI study examining theory-of-mind/social exchange processing (social-related task). Abstract indicates neuroimaging of social cognition and activation of ToM areas. Participant health/ages not explicitly stated; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65).

Abstract describes an fMRI task involving implicit facial emotion processing (a social-related task) but does not state whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Not a review. Insufficient information to confirm healthy participant group—include for full-text review to verify participant groups and ages.

Healthy adult participants (n=35) underwent fMRI while reading and regulating idiographic negative self-beliefs—task targets perception/understanding of self (a listed social-related construct). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI in 23 healthy adults performing a visually based social judgment task (evaluating social dominance in faces), clearly a social-cognitive task (Perception and Understanding of Others). Participants are healthy adults within the target age range and the study is empirical (not a review). Thus it meets the inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI in patients with bipolar disorder undergoing EPO treatment and improvement in recognition of happy faces, but does not mention any healthy control group. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy participants (age 17–65). Based on the abstract, this criterion is not met.

fMRI study with healthy participants performing a social-cognition task (third-party punishment/mentalizing and punishment decisions). It directly investigates social processing and reports neural connectivity; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient evidence of eligibility for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study investigating attentional orienting to gaze (a social cue) and arrow cues; addresses social perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly that participants are healthy, so include for full-text review to confirm sample characteristics and eligibility.

Participants are described as a chronic traumatic brain injury population with no mention of a healthy control group. Inclusion requires at least one healthy adult group (age 17–65); criterion not met.

This is a narrative review of mirror neuron dysfunction in autism, not an original fMRI study reporting data from healthy adult participants. The study focuses on ASD populations and summarizes evidence from multiple modalities; it does not meet inclusion criteria requiring fMRI during social tasks in healthy adults.

Task-based fMRI included social processing (social cognition) alongside other tasks in a large sample from the Human Connectome Project (healthy adults). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy participants.

Primary empirical fMRI study examining prosocial (altruistic) choice and neural encoding of social attributes, addressing social-related processing. Not a review/meta-analysis and likely conducted in healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria for social-processing fMRI studies.
Participants are described as adolescent girls (minors), not adults aged 17–65 required by the inclusion criteria; therefore the study does not meet the age criterion for inclusion.

Original fMRI study investigating person perception and mentalizing (social cognition) using human/robot avatars and belief manipulations in healthy adults. Task probes perception/understanding of others; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of mental-state decoding (Reading the Mind in the Eyes), a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others), conducted in healthy adult participants (native Japanese and white American). Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits the review objective and inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 30 healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (direct vs. averted gaze) assessing neural measures of social processing (TPJ connectivity) and action control. Meets inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adults). Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports a functional MRI study probing social-related processing (perception of others walking together) and reports activation of social brain areas. It matches the review objective. However, participant age/health status are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI study of healthy adult subjects observing toolmaking that explicitly investigates social-cognition processes (motor resonance, mentalizing, recognition of intentions). Not a review. Abstract lacks explicit ages but clearly meets the review objective; full text can confirm participant ages/health.

Abstract describes an overview/narrative review of molecular neuroimaging and neuroeconomics, not an original fMRI study with human participants performing a social task. Exclusion criterion met: systematic review/meta-analysis (review article). Insufficient as primary data for inclusion.

fMRI study administering a social interaction task (virtual ball-tossing/Cyberball) with a healthy control group (n=20) within adult participants; directly investigates neural processing of social-related stimuli and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI hemodynamic responses to child stimuli in neural regions associated with social cognition in human mothers. This fits social-related processing and involves adult human participants; no indication of being a review or excluding healthy adults. Sufficient information in abstract to include for full-text review.

Study involves fMRI of patients with mild traumatic brain injury during piano-based cognitive rehabilitation; no indication of social-related task or healthy adult participant group (17–65). Does not meet review focus on social processing in healthy adults.

Study used an fMRI social-approval task (social reward processing) and included a healthy control group (15 controls). It examines social-related processing in humans during fMRI and is not a review. Age range not specified but participants are adults; criteria met for inclusion.

fMRI task involved repeating words/pseudowords to study speech production and aging; no social task, interaction, or explicit social-communication manipulation is described. Mention of vocal imitation as socially relevant does not make the experimental paradigm a social-processing task.

This is a review article (Trends in Cognitive Sciences) about infant fMRI and cortical face-area development, not an original fMRI study of healthy adults (age 17–65) performing social tasks. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews and does not provide eligible adult fMRI data.

fMRI study examining gaze-direction effects on face processing—a social attention/communication task. Abstract reports neural responses in fusiform, amygdala, and intraparietal sulcus, consistent with social-related processing in humans. Participant details/ages not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample.

Narrative/theoretical review discussing mirror-touch synesthesia and fMRI evidence; does not report an original fMRI experiment conducted while participants performed a social-related task in healthy adults, so it fails the inclusion criterion requiring a functional MRI study.

Abstract reports neural responses in human posterior superior temporal sulcus to stimuli depicting social interactions between agents, addressing social perception. Likely an fMRI study of healthy adults relevant to social processing. Insufficient explicit methods in abstract is minimal but context and journal make inclusion appropriate for full-text review.

Study uses fMRI to examine prosodic speech (social communication), which fits social-related processing. However the abstract does not state whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included or provide participant ages. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criterion—include for full-text review.
fMRI study of social cognition (Theory of Mind) that includes a healthy control group. Task involves social intention processing. No exclusion criteria met; suitable for full-text review.

Participants are children (one high-functioning autistic child, one Asperger’s child, three normal children). Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65; this study does not meet the age criterion.

fMRI study with 30 healthy adult participants performing communicative (social) vs descriptive speech tasks in L1/L2. Examines neural correlates of social communication (theory of mind/action simulation) in healthy adults, so meets inclusion criteria and is not a review.

fMRI study using an empathy-for-pain (social/empathy) paradigm assessing perception/understanding of others; includes a healthy control group alongside autistic participants; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract indicates this is a review article summarizing psychopharmacological and fMRI research rather than reporting original fMRI experiments in participants. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Task-based fMRI in healthy male and female participants examining visual perception of social interactions (facing vs nonfacing body dyads), fitting 'Perception and Understanding of Others'. Not a review. Age not specified in abstract—include for full-text verification.

Abstract reports two independent fMRI experiments on emotional egocentricity bias (a social-cognition task) in human participants, with behavioral and rTMS follow-ups. This clearly meets the review criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of social processing (joint attention, face processing, theory-of-mind/action networks) that includes neurotypical (healthy) control participants. Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65 required), so full-text review needed to confirm age eligibility and other details.

fMRI study of audiovisual speech perception (a social communication task) with an age- and gender-matched healthy control group. Abstract lacks exact ages (17–65) but controls are adult; include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and details.

Study used structural MRI covariance analysis rather than task-based functional MRI; abstract does not describe an fMRI scan during a social task. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring a functional MRI social-task study.

fMRI study manipulating goal relevance during encoding and recognition of neutral faces; reports activation in social-processing region (superior temporal sulcus). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original empirical study, not a review. Meets criteria for fMRI social-processing in healthy adults.

Abstract describes imaging of ToM and empathy in schizophrenia patients but does not state whether fMRI during social tasks was used or whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to exclude—include for full-text review.

fMRI study where participants viewed and recognized actions (perception/understanding of others), a social cognition task. Abstract reports neural adaptation in pSTS, MT/MST, and EBA. Although ages not specified, the task and methods fit inclusion; include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and ages.

fMRI BOLD data were collected while participants performed a social cognition task (trustworthiness judgments of faces). The study includes a healthy control group alongside schizophrenia groups, addressing perception/understanding of others in adults. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study investigating social cognition (theory of mind, action understanding, mirror neuron system) with a healthy control group (n=18) performing social-related tasks. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of social interaction (social exclusion) in human participants addressing social processing. Participants described as male adolescents but ages not specified; unclear if they meet 17–65 adult criterion. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Human fMRI study investigating representation/understanding of actions (auditory mirror system), i.e., perception/understanding of others—fits social-related processing. Appears to use healthy adult participants and is not a review. Age not specified in abstract, but insufficient grounds for exclusion; include for full-text review.

Abstract reports dfMRI experimental results investigating face-to-face social interaction and BOLD responses implicating empathy/mentalization networks, suggesting an fMRI social task. However, participant demographics and explicit confirmation of a healthy adult sample (17–65) are not provided. Include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study used resting-state fMRI, not task-based fMRI performed during a social-related task. Although healthy controls were included and behavioural ToM tests were administered, the inclusion criterion requires fMRI during a social task, so it does not meet criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI investigation of self- and other-processing in schizophrenia (a social-related task) but does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. No exclusion criteria clearly met. Insufficient information to determine inclusion from abstract alone — include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy participants.

Abstract describes a review/perspective on social neuroscience rather than reporting an original fMRI study with human participants performing a social-related task. Does not meet the inclusion criteria for primary fMRI studies.

fMRI study with 22 healthy adult male participants performing social-related tasks (allocentric social hierarchy and social alliance judgments). Tasks probe perception/understanding of others, matching the review objective. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Study uses fMRI to examine executive control network hub architecture in autism during executive-demand tasks; the abstract does not describe any social-related task or social processing (e.g., affiliation, communication, self/other perception). Does not meet the review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports neural activity during social communication in healthy pairs but does not specify the imaging modality (fMRI) or participant ages. Because the abstract lacks critical information about use of functional MRI, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Original fMRI study using a social interaction task (reaction-time competition with opponents and provocation/punishment), investigating reactive aggression — a social process involving responses to others. Human participants (adults) underwent fMRI; not a review. Meets inclusion for social-related fMRI in healthy adults based on abstract.

Participants are described as 'youth' (children/adolescents) with a typically developing comparison group; no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is reported. Although this is an fMRI social-threat task, it fails the age criterion for inclusion in an adult-focused review.

fMRI study investigating perception of emotions and interactions in dynamic crowds—this is social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Not a review; likely involves healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria; sufficient info in abstract to include for full-text review.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing an affective creativity task (generating alternative appraisals for anger-evoking events), which taps emotion regulation and processes linked to social cognition (default-mode/social cognition hubs). Not a review. Abstract lacks explicit detail on interpersonal stimuli, so include for full-text review to confirm social-related processing.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Although social cognition was assessed behaviorally and healthy controls were included, the inclusion criterion requires fMRI during a social-related task, which is not met.

Study used simultaneous fMRI-PET while mothers (healthy adult participants) responded to their infants, probing neural responses and connectivity related to maternal bonding (affiliation/attachment). This is a social-related task in healthy adults and is not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI evidence of neural responses to MHC peptide-modified body odour and behavioral tests on recognition/‘self’ vs ‘non-self’ evaluation—this is social-related processing in healthy volunteers. Age range not specified; include for full-text review to confirm demographics/methods.

Abstract reports an fMRI study measuring neural representations of others’ mental states in male and female human participants during social cognition tasks (perception/understanding of others). It fits the review’s social-processing constructs, involves healthy adult participants (not described as a patient sample), and is not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study of social cognition (charitable giving probing empathy, perspective taking, and attention shifts). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study uses fMRI to investigate memory control and functional connectivity during a recognition task (mnemonic processes). It does not examine social-related processing (affiliation, communication, self/other perception), so it does not meet the review objective.

fMRI conducted while participants made social judgments (cooperator vs defector) learned through interactive Prisoner’s Dilemma — a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Appears to use healthy adult participants and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.
