fMRI study of emotion recognition from dynamic gait—falls squarely under social perception/understanding of others. Human subjects underwent fMRI; likely healthy adults but ages not reported in abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.
The study used positron emission tomography (PET), not functional MRI. The meta-analysis requires fMRI studies; therefore it does not meet the modality inclusion criterion.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rsFC) rather than an fMRI scan conducted while participants performed a social-related task. Although it examines peer influence and involves healthy emerging adults, it does not meet the requirement of a task-based social processing fMRI, so it should be excluded.

fMRI study of social rejection (Cyberball) in healthy participants; includes an adult participant group (16 adult females) and examines social-related processing (social evaluation, affect regulation). Not a review. Adult group likely within 17–65; if age uncertainty remains, full-text can confirm.

Abstract reports fMRI ‘imaging epigenetic’ study measuring neural activity during emotional face processing (social perception), which meets the review objective. Participant health and exact ages are not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample and task details.

Participants are children (middle childhood, ages 8–12); the meta-analysis requires at least one healthy adult group aged 17–65. Abstract gives no indication of adult participants, so it does not meet the age criterion.

Study uses fMRI during a social cognition task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes) and includes siblings (possible healthy participants), but participants are described as adolescents and ages are not reported. Because age eligibility (17–65) and presence of healthy adult group cannot be confirmed from the abstract, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

The study includes an fMRI facial emotion processing task (social-related processing) and a healthy control group (n=27). Age range is not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are within 17–65 and to extract relevant data.

Randomized, placebo-controlled fMRI study examining neural and behavioral responses during a social-interaction task (Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy adult males and females. Directly addresses social processing in healthy adults and is not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of cross-modal person recognition (voice-face priming) addressing perception/understanding of others, a social-related process. Human participants are implied; abstract lacks explicit age/health details. Include for full-text review to confirm sample are healthy adults (17–65) and meet criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study using parental stimuli (attachment/affiliation/social processing) and includes a healthy volunteer group. Ages of participants are not specified in the abstract, so full text is needed to confirm the 17–65 age criterion; otherwise it meets the review focus.

The study used resting-state fMRI with the social manipulation (critical remarks) presented before scanning rather than a social task performed during the fMRI. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task; this does not clearly meet that criterion despite healthy adult sample.

This is a meta-analysis (explicitly stated) of fMRI studies in schizophrenia patients. The protocol excludes systematic reviews/meta-analyses; the abstract does not report primary data from healthy adult participants meeting inclusion criteria.
This article is a systematic review and meta-analysis (not a primary fMRI study). Exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses' is clearly met.

fMRI study of social-related processing (implicit facial emotion task: fearful vs neutral faces — perception/understanding of others). Includes a healthy adult control group (24 matched controls). Not a review. Therefore meets inclusion criteria.

The study examines cognitive emotion regulation to positive/negative/neutral pictures, not social-related processing. It does not involve social stimuli or tasks (e.g., affiliation, communication, perception of others/self in social context). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI social task.

The article is explicitly a review and meta-analysis of behavioral and neuroimaging studies; it is not an original fMRI study of healthy adults performing social tasks. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Original fMRI study where participants viewed text messages believed to be from a friend vs a computer, probing social communication and social-context modulation. Healthy participants are implied and task is social-related. Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria for social processing in adults; include for full-text review.

Study uses resting-state fMRI (no social task); meta-analysis requires task-based fMRI during social-related processing. Although healthy control group present, absence of a social task means it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI in healthy nulliparous adult women (n=17) using infant cries and faces—social stimuli tapping affiliation/attachment, perception of others, and reward processing. Fits inclusion criteria (social-related task; healthy adults 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis.

Abstract does not report that participants performed a social-related task; study focuses on resting-state parcellation and task-related coactivation/meta-characterization. Although 'social cognition' is mentioned in functional labeling, it is unclear whether original fMRI involved a social task. Insufficient detail to exclude—include for full-text review to determine whether social-task fMRI in healthy adults was performed.

Study used magnetoencephalography (MEG), not functional MRI. The review requires fMRI data collected during a social-related task. Although participants are healthy adults and task is social, the imaging modality fails inclusion.

This publication is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies (a systematic review/meta-analysis), which meets the exclusion criterion. Additionally, it focuses on psychopathic populations rather than reporting primary fMRI data from healthy adult participants performing social tasks.

Task-based fMRI examines self-referential processing (a social-related construct: perception/understanding of self). Although participants include aMCI and controls, ages are not provided and may be >65; insufficient age information to rule out inclusion. Abstract therefore warrants full-text review to confirm participant ages and task details.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (theory of mind/belief processing) using a behavioral task (Sally-Anne type false-belief) in human participants. It is empirical (not a review) and appears to involve healthy adult participants, meeting the review’s inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract provides insufficient information: unclear whether an fMRI task of social processing was used (may be resting-state connectivity) and unclear if a healthy adult group (age 17–65) was included. Include for full-text review.

Study uses resting-state fMRI (no social task) and reports outcomes in individuals with autism; no evidence of a social-related task or a healthy adult (17–65) sample. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of supraliminal fearful face processing (social/emotional processing) that includes a healthy control group of adults matched on age and IQ. Task assesses perception/processing of others; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI data were collected during gesture planning and execution (social action/communication), which fits social-related processing. The study includes a healthy control group of adults (n=25). It is an original fMRI study, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

The abstract describes an fMRI study of social cognition (self-referential processing and perspective taking) with human adult participants and tasks targeting self/others. It is an empirical study (not a review) and directly addresses perception/understanding of self and others. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health status if needed.

The study uses resting-state connectivity, structural covariance, and meta-analytic connectivity modeling rather than a task-based fMRI of social processing. No evidence participants performed a social-related task during scanning, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion for task-based social fMRI.

Abstract describes fMRI connectivity in autism spectrum disorder and clinical severity; it does not report fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults nor mention a healthy 17–65 group. Focus is clinical ASD, not the review’s social-processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of perspective-taking (self/other evaluation), a social cognition task (Perception/Understanding of Self and Others). Includes a healthy control group of 24 typically developed adults (age: adults), and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports hyperscanning fMRI during joint attention, a social processing task. However, participant health status and ages (17–65) are not specified in the abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm sample consists of healthy adults within the eligible age range and meets other criteria.

fMRI study of cognitive empathy (social processing) that included a healthy control group (24 controls). Task assesses perception/understanding of others. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adult participants; abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

The study used fMRI to examine self-referential processing and perspective-taking (social-related constructs). The abstract focuses on ultra-high risk individuals but does not clearly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because inclusion criteria permit studies with clinical groups if a healthy group is present and the abstract is insufficient to determine this, include for full-text review.

Abstract describes an fMRI task involving perception of emotional facial expressions (a social-related process) which matches the review objective. However, the abstract does not state whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Include for full-text review to confirm presence and age range of healthy participants.

The study used task-based fMRI during social-related processing (emotion recognition and gaze integration). It includes a healthy younger participant group aged 17–27 (within the 17–65 inclusion range). It is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review.

fMRI was resting-state functional connectivity only, not a task-based fMRI during a social-related task. Although healthy controls and behavioral social cognition measures were included, the study does not meet the requirement of an fMRI scan conducted while participants performed a social-related task.
Study examines children and adolescents with autism spectrum disorder; no healthy adult (17–65) participant group is reported. Population and age range do not match the review’s inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI functional connectivity related to autistic traits in neurotypical adults but does not state that participants performed a social-related task. Insufficient information to confirm the key inclusion criterion (task-based social processing); include for full-text review to determine task details and participant ages.

fMRI study of fearful face-processing (social cognition) in adults; includes a matched healthy control group (adults) alongside HFA/AS group. Task is social-related (perception of others’ emotions). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports oxytocin modulation of processing of socially relevant cues in the human VTA, implying human neuroimaging of social stimuli. Participant health status and imaging modality not explicitly stated in abstract; insufficient information to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm fMRI and healthy adult sample.

Abstract reports fMRI investigation of facial emotion processing in individuals at clinical high risk for psychosis—this is a social-related task. The abstract does not clearly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm healthy participants, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm, and no measures of social behavior/processing were reported. Although healthy controls were included, it does not meet the requirement of a social-related task.

This is a resting-state fMRI study in adolescents with early-onset schizophrenia and healthy controls; it does not involve a task-based social processing paradigm in healthy adults (17–65). Therefore it does not meet the review’s requirement for fMRI during social-related tasks in healthy adults.

fulltext_screening_results.reason: Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (N=24, ages 19–36) and uses task fMRI of social processing, the reported results are primarily between-group contrasts and ROI analyses. The paper does not present a clear, unmasked whole-brain group-level task activation map or contrast explicitly identified as coming from the healthy/control group alone. Whole-brain figures and tables focus on group interactions and BPD>HC or HC>BPD contrasts; the amygdala result is an ROI finding. Because the review requires at least one healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked statistical map (reported as HC task effect or within-group contrast), this study does not meet that inclusion criterion.

While this is an fMRI study of social processing (Cyberball) in adult participants (mean age ~19.8) and reports whole-brain, group-level activation maps (EX–IN and SUP–EX), the reported whole-brain results are for the entire sample (46 participants), which includes 9 participants meeting criteria for social anxiety disorder. The paper does not present a clearly identified whole-brain group-level task activation map coming specifically from a healthy/control-only group. The review’s eligibility rules require that if clinical participants are included, results for the healthy group must be reported separately (or a whole-brain healthy/control map must be clearly identified). Because that criterion is not met, the study must be excluded.

While this is a task-based fMRI study of social interaction in healthy adults (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma; participants aged 18–22), the manuscript reports ROI-based activation and task-based ROI-to-ROI (gPPI) connectivity within a predefined modified social behavioral neural network. The paper does not present any group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy/control group; voxelwise results are only referenced as having been reported in prior publications using the same dataset. Because the review requires at least one unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map from the healthy group, this study fails the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=31 analyzed; ages ~21) using a social interaction task (Cyberball ball‑toss) probing social reward/affiliation. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., ball-toss [high‑frequency – normal‑frequency] > button‑press [high‑frequency – normal‑frequency]) with thresholding and cluster‑level FWE correction, and provides peak coordinates and cluster descriptions (ventral striatum, precuneus). It is not an ROI‑only, connectivity‑only, resting‑state, or patient‑only study. Whole‑brain healthy-group activation maps/contrasts are clearly described and reported, satisfying all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (understanding others’ regret) involving healthy adult participants (two samples of N=24, ages within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation analyses (SPM5; contrasts IP−IF and OP−OF; parametric and conjunction analyses; thresholding and reported activation foci/coordinates), not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, or clinical groups. Whole-brain results for the healthy/control group are clearly described in the text and figures/tables. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Uses task-based fMRI to investigate perception of social interactions (social communication / perception of others). (2) Sample = 21 healthy adults (ages 18–35) with results reported for the healthy group. (3) Whole-brain analyses were performed and reported (whole-brain beta maps, group-level t-tests, and whole-brain searchlight analyses are described), providing voxelwise task-evoked results for the healthy sample. The study is empirical and not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be included for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This study reports an fMRI task involving social touch (self- vs other-touch), addressing social-related processing (perception/understanding of self and others). It includes a healthy adult control group (NC; mean age 23.7 ± 3.6 years) analyzed and reported separately. Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activations for the control group are presented (self-touch and other-touch effects, FWE-corrected whole-brain results and coordinates are reported/illustrated). Although an ADHD clinical group is also studied, the healthy-control whole-brain task results are clearly reported, satisfying inclusion criteria. Therefore the paper qualifies for inclusion in the meta-analysis of task-evoked whole-brain fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This study used resting-state fMRI (10-min resting protocol) and graph-theory connectivity analyses rather than any task-based fMRI of social processing. Although healthy control participants are included, no group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from a healthy/control group are reported. Behavioral social-cognition measures were collected, but these were not linked to task-evoked fMRI activations. Therefore the study fails the requirement for a task-based fMRI whole-brain healthy-group activation and is excluded.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social communication (comprehension of speech acts Naming vs Requesting) in healthy adult participants (18 analyzed participants, age range 18–41). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses with voxelwise contrasts (e.g., Request > Naming) corrected for multiple comparisons (FDR p<0.05) and small-volume ROI analyses; whole-brain results are clearly described. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and participants fall within the 18–65 range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are met.

This is a conference abstract with insufficient methodological detail. Although the study concerns social processing (eye contact) and uses fMRI, the full text does not report participant characteristics (age range/sample size) or explicitly present at least one group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical map for a healthy adult group. The abstract describes derived networks qualitatively but provides no clear whole-brain results (maps or coordinate tables) attributable to a healthy/control group. Because it fails to meet the required whole-brain healthy-group reporting and lacks verifiable sample details, it does not satisfy all inclusion criteria.

This is a methods/tutorial paper describing intersubject correlation (ISC) methodology (review/tutorial), not an original empirical fMRI study reporting new whole-brain task-evoked results in a healthy adult sample. The full text provides conceptual framework, extensions, and practical considerations but does not report group-level voxelwise activation maps from healthy adults. Per exclusion criteria, non-empirical/methods-only papers without original fMRI data in healthy adults should be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (mentalising/theory-of-mind) in healthy adult participants (Experiment 2: N=17, mean age 22; Experiment 1/pilot samples also include adults, ages within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise analyses using SPM2 with random-effects second-level ANOVAs and whole-brain correction (threshold P<0.001, cluster k>38 yielding whole-brain P<0.05), and presents contrasts such as mentalising>factual and parametric modulation results. Results are reported as whole-brain maps/coordinates and described in text/tables/supplementary material. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adult group-level whole-brain task activations). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (mentalizing during an interactive Prisoner’s Dilemma), directly relevant to affiliation/attachment and theory-of-mind constructs. The sample comprises 164 healthy adult participants (within 18–65). The paper reports group-level task-evoked neural activations across the canonical mentalizing network (bilateral precuneus, cingulate, TPJ, IFG, amygdala, etc.), indicating whole-brain voxelwise effects for the healthy/control group (reported as task-associated activations and region-level results). No exclusion criteria are met: results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses, nor to between-group contrasts or non-adult samples. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and the study should be included in the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=26, mean age 26; all within 18–65) that uses a social-cognition task (third-party punishment/mentalizing about an offender) relevant to perception and understanding of others. The authors performed whole-brain, voxelwise GLM/random-effects analyses and report group-level activation maps and peak coordinates (e.g., R TPJ at x=50,y=-50,z=15; R anterior insula at x=30,y=14,z=12) with statistical thresholding (q(FDR)<0.05). Results for the healthy participant sample are reported directly (including between-group comparisons of libertarians vs determinists and main effects across the healthy sample). The paper thus meets inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task; healthy adult sample; whole-brain group-level task-evoked results) and does not violate exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not resting-state only, not non-empirical).

Meets all inclusion criteria. The study uses task-based fMRI to probe animacy perception—a social-related process (perception/understanding of others; animacy is a precursor to social cognition). Sample comprises healthy adults (N=111 recruited; imaging groups N=20 each, ages 19–36) within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (conjunction contrasts, whole-brain FWE-corrected results, reported peaks and clusters, and accompanying tables/figures), not limited to ROI-only results. Healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly described (e.g., moving vs. static dot; IPS, hMT+/V5, occipital clusters). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range samples) are violated. Therefore this empirical fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (mutual vs. averted gaze) in a dynamic social context, directly addressing social perception/understanding of others. The fMRI sample comprises healthy young adult participants (fMRI group: 8 right-handed healthy adults), satisfying the healthy adult sample criterion. The paper reports group-level voxelwise whole-brain analyses and t-statistic activation maps (group-averaged, displayed on a standard brain; voxelwise thresholding described), providing unmasked whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy group. Although ROI analyses are also used, whole-brain results are explicitly reported. No exclusion criteria apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This study uses task-based fMRI with the HCP social cognition (Animated Triangles/social motion) paradigm, directly addressing social-related processing. It includes a healthy adult control group (N=25) reported separately. The paper provides whole-brain, group-level task activation results for the healthy controls (voxelwise t-maps, peak MNI coordinates, FWE-corrected statistics), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Although a clinical (first-episode schizophrenia) group is also included, healthy-group results are explicitly reported. Participant ages are adults within the target range. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=20 scanned; mean age 25.7). The task probes social-emotional processing (guilt memories vs hypothetical social scenarios), clearly mapping onto social cognition / perception-understanding constructs. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., guilt memories vs neutral memories; guilt memories vs guilt hypotheticals) with whole-brain thresholding (p<0.001, cluster extent) and reports activated regions and coordinates; SPM8 second-level analyses are described. The study is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-healthy samples. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (evaluation/organization of political beliefs—a social-cognitive task involving self/other processing). The fMRI sample comprises healthy adults (N=26, ages 22–45). Group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxelwise analyses are reported (parametric effects with whole-brain thresholding and coordinates in tables/figures), and results are clearly described for the healthy/control group. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state, and reports within-group task-evoked activations suitable for inclusion in the meta-analysis of social processing in healthy adults.

Although this is an fMRI study of social-related processing (biological motion) that includes a healthy adult control group, it does not report a clear group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map for the healthy/control group. The paper relies on individual-level ROI localizers (STSp and MT), ROI-based event-related analyses, and reports ROI peak activations and Talairach coordinates. Whole-brain analyses described were directed at patients (searching for clusters) and no unmasked, group-level healthy-control whole-brain contrast or coordinate table of healthy-group task activations is provided. Thus it fails the requirement for healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked results and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of joint action with haptic social interaction (leading, following, mutual), addressing social-cognitive processes (perception/understanding of others, social communication, mentalizing). Sample: healthy adult participants (n=18 analyzed; mean age 40.4, range within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., partnered vs non-partnered; improvisation contrasts) with statistical thresholding and Talairach coordinates, not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

Although this fMRI study uses a healthy adult sample (n=36, ages 20–35) and examines processing of vocal emotional (socially relevant) stimuli, all reported analyses are ROI/parcellation-based functional connectivity and graph-theoretical metrics (Power-264 nodes, OMST filtering). The paper does not report any group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps (GLM activation maps) or coordinates of voxelwise task activations; results are presented as ROI/network-level statistics and connectivity differences. This violates the inclusion requirement for at least one whole-brain, voxelwise healthy-group task effect. Therefore it must be excluded.

Although this is an fMRI task study of social processes in healthy adult physicians (n=18) and the task/behavioral measures map onto social constructs (empathic concern/compassion), the reported neuroimaging results are from an a priori ROI-restricted analysis (5mm spheres) with FWE correction performed within those ROIs. The paper does not present an unmasked, whole‑brain group-level task-evoked statistical map (voxelwise whole‑brain results) for the healthy group. Because the review’s inclusion criteria require at least one group-level whole‑brain (voxelwise) task activation map, this study must be excluded despite meeting other criteria.

This is a single-case study of an adult patient with ASD and developmental prosopagnosia, comparing that patient to control subjects. The full text provided does not clearly report a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group; results are described as patient vs control differences and functional connectivity findings. Because the inclusion criteria require explicit healthy-group whole-brain task activation maps (e.g., within-group contrasts or main effects) and the provided information is consistent with between-group comparisons and connectivity/ROI-style analyses, I cannot confirm the necessary whole-brain healthy-group data. Therefore the study does not meet the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task activation reporting and must be excluded.

The study reports task-based fMRI in ‘normal subjects’ performing social-cognition tasks (attentional and attributional judgements relevant to self), which falls squarely under social-related processing (perception/understanding of self/others). Results describe localized activations across multiple brain regions with Brodmann areas (e.g., left inferior frontal gyrus BA44/47, caudate, cingulate BA24, precentral gyrus BA6, middle temporal gyrus BA39), indicating group-level voxelwise task-evoked activation maps rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. A healthy adult sample is explicitly reported and results are described for this group. No exclusion criteria are triggered (not ROI-only, not resting-state only, and reports unmasked healthy-group task effects). Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=37, ages 18–25) investigating imitation drive—a social cognitive process (perception/understanding of others and social communication). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task analyses (parametric modulation of BOLD by Urge during imitation) with statistical thresholds and identified coordinates/regions (right SMA, bilateral MCC) and includes tables/figures and supplementary results. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only (although PPI is also reported), and results for the healthy adult sample are reported separately. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusions.

This paper reports task-based fMRI of action observation and weight-discrimination (perception/understanding of others’ actions), which falls under 'Perception and Understanding of Others' (a social-related construct). Multiple experiments include healthy adult participants (n=79 across Experiments 1–3; separate healthy control group n=31 reported for the clinical comparison), with results for healthy groups reported separately from the SCA6 patients. The manuscript presents group-level, voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., ActionOBS–CtrlOBS; Sleeve/NoSleeve contrasts) and statistical maps/analyses (thresholds, conjunctions, ROI and whole-brain comparisons) clearly attributed to the healthy/control groups. Thus it meets the review’s fMRI, sample, and whole-brain evidence inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of narrative comprehension that explicitly probes social-related processing (mentalizing/Theory-of-Mind). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=18, ages 18–27). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task contrasts (Mentalizing vs Action; Action vs Mentalizing) with appropriate multiple-comparison correction and reported cluster coordinates/locations, not limited to ROI-only results. The task evokes social cognition (perception/understanding of others) during story listening. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social perception (directional head turns) in healthy adults (final sample within age range 22–38). The task is social-related (perception/understanding of others’ attention), and group-level voxelwise results are reported: both ROI-based and whole-brain (gray matter–masked) group analyses with MNI coordinates and FWE-corrected p-values are provided for univariate and MVPA effects (e.g., early visual cortex, STS peaks). Healthy-group results are reported separately and are not limited to ROIs only. No exclusion criteria (only ROI/ connectivity/ non-healthy groups) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study of action observation/execution in healthy adults (final N=12, mean age 26), directly addressing perception/understanding of others’ actions (inferring others’ applied force). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task analyses (SPM12 GLM, polynomial parametric modulation), whole-brain statistical maps, tables of coordinates, and conjunction/second-level results for the healthy sample. It is not ROI-only, not limited to connectivity/resting-state, and reports unmasked healthy-group task effects. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task; healthy adult sample; whole-brain group-level task results) and violates no exclusion criteria.

Although the study uses fMRI in healthy adults and examines effects of an implied social presence, it employs a resting-state design and reports network-level functional connectivity contrasts rather than any group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked activation maps from a social task. Inclusion criteria require at least one healthy-group whole-brain task activation map. The analyses focus on resting-state connectivity (node/network correlations) and contrasts between resting scans; no unmasked voxelwise task activation map is reported. Therefore it fails the ‘whole-brain task-evoked map’ inclusion requirement and meets the exclusion criterion for resting-state/connectivity-only studies.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (social sharing/affiliation) in healthy adult participants (female, ages 20–33). The paper reports group-level, within-subject task contrasts (e.g., shared_emo > unshared_emo) from the healthy sample and provides whole-brain voxelwise results: exploratory whole-brain corrected activations (left DLPFC and bilateral precuneus) are reported, along with ROI-corrected VS and OFC findings. Results are clearly from the healthy/control group (no exclusive clinical subgroup reporting). The study therefore meets: (1) use of task fMRI on a social-related construct, (2) healthy adult sample within 18–65, and (3) provision of group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps/clusters. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-only, or missing healthy-group whole-brain maps) are violated. Consequently, INCLUDE for the meta-analysis.

Although the study used task fMRI in healthy adults (N=20, ages 19–31) and investigated social-cognitive contrasts, the authors explicitly restricted their second-level/group analyses to a bilateral STS mask. Thus the reported group-level voxelwise statistical maps are region-restricted (STS) rather than unmasked whole-brain maps. The review’s inclusion criterion requires at least one group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map from the healthy/control group. Because the paper does not provide an unmasked whole-brain healthy-group activation map, it fails the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and should be excluded.

While the study uses fMRI in healthy adults (ages 18–45) and reports group-level whole-brain task activation maps (HA− > Neutral), its experimental task is general emotional (IAPS) image viewing focused on negative emotion processing and fronto-limbic connectivity. The primary construct is affective/emotion processing rather than social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, perception/understanding of others or self). Although some images contained people and the dmPFC is discussed in social-cognition terms, the task and hypotheses do not target social cognitive processes per se. Therefore the study does not address the review’s social-related task objective and should be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task-based fMRI assessing social-related processing (participants thought about 16 social interaction items); includes a healthy adult control group (17 age- and IQ-matched adults, ages within adult range); reports group-level whole-brain within-group task contrasts for the control group (Social interactions – fixation contrasts reported and described in text/figures, thresholded at p=0.001 uncorrected). Not limited to ROI or resting-state/seed-connectivity analyses. Although the study also includes a clinical autism group, the healthy control whole-brain task results are reported separately. Therefore the paper is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

Although the study uses fMRI with social tasks (Social Incentive Delay and Emotional Face Processing) and includes a healthy control group aged 50–60, it does not clearly report an unmasked, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map specifically for the healthy/control group. The paper primarily reports ROI-based results, whole-group (combined sample) activation maps, and between-group contrasts; whole-brain results referenced appear to be for the combined sample or group comparisons rather than a control-group within-group map clearly identified as coming from healthy participants. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one clearly identified healthy-group whole-brain task activation map, this study does not meet that criterion and should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study using a social interaction task (Taylor Aggression Paradigm) probing retaliation/aggression, clearly social-related processing. Sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=15 included; mean age 22.33), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects task activation analyses and provides voxelwise statistical maps/coordinates (thresholds and cluster corrections reported). Results are presented for the healthy/control sample (no restricted subgroup-only reports). The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not limited to connectivity or resting-state analyses, and therefore meets all inclusion criteria. Note: sample size is small but does not violate inclusion criteria.

The study uses fMRI during social-related tasks (self-reflection and other-reflection — constructs of Perception/Understanding of Self and Others). It includes a healthy adult control group (21 HCs) reported separately. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task effects for the healthy control group (main effects in HCs: VMPFC, DMPFC, ACC, PCC, precuneus, etc.), with thresholds and results summarized (including Supplementary Table S1), i.e., whole-brain voxelwise activations rather than ROI-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are met (not resting-state/seed-only, not ROI-only, includes healthy adult group). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=25, mean age 25.1) investigating social-related processing (learning about others’ preference similarity to self—affiliation/social cognition). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results (cluster-corrected activations, peak MNI coordinates, conjunction analyses) rather than only ROI or connectivity analyses. Healthy participants’ whole-brain task contrasts and parametric modulators are clearly described and reported. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state, participants are within 18–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although this fMRI study includes a healthy adult control group and probes a social-related process (irony comprehension—social communication/perception of others), the full text does not present an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The reported neuroimaging results focus on between-group contrasts (controls > schizophrenia and reverse) and combined/previously published control results; main effects are described for “study participants” without providing a standalone whole-brain healthy-group map (coordinate table or figure) in this paper. Because the review requires at least one clearly reported healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked statistical map, this manuscript does not meet the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=55, mean age 24.9) using a social-related task (erotic and fearful social scenes and faces). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (main effects and within-group contrasts) with whole-brain FWE-corrected results and ROI analyses; whole-brain contrasts and figures/tables are clearly described for the healthy/control group. Sample falls within 18–65 and results for the healthy group are presented (no clinical subgroup only reporting). No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (n=9, mean age 37) and uses fMRI during a social-related facial emotion processing task, the paper presents only between-group (VCFS vs control) comparisons. The full text does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map (e.g., main effect or within-group on>off contrast) clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group; results and Table 1 show between-group differences only. Per the review’s criteria, studies that report only between-group contrasts without an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy adult participants (ages 18–22). The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (GLM/FEAT) for task outcomes (CC and CD), including thresholding, cluster-wise results and tables/figures of significant clusters, not limited to ROI-only results. The sample comprises healthy adults and whole-brain task-evoked effects are clearly described for the healthy/control groups. The study is not resting-state or connectivity-only and presents original task activation data, so it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=18, mean age 26) that uses task-based fMRI to probe social-related processing: explicit categorization of laughter types (social communication/perception of others) and an implicit counting task. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxelwise analyses (e.g., CSL vs TIC, CAT vs COU) with cluster- and FWE-corrected thresholds and presents results in text/figures, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although connectivity (PPI) and ROI analyses are included, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for the healthy sample are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria apply, so the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task is an fMRI task involving observation of others’ actions with risk—relevant to social perception/understanding; sample comprises healthy adult participants aged 18–22 (within 18–65); group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (risk-taking vs safe) were computed and reported using SPM (maps, coordinates and figures are provided); the paper is empirical and not ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state only, and results for the healthy group are reported. No exclusion criteria are violated. The study therefore qualifies for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (ten healthy male participants, ages 23–28) using a social task (the ultimatum game) probing social decision-making. The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses: an offline whole-brain classification across subjects with voxelwise discriminative weight maps transformed into voxel space and permutation-derived p-values (discriminating volumes reported, p<0.05 uncorrected). Results are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control sample. The study is not ROI-only, nor connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 18–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI task study of empathy for pain, a social/other-focused process (perception/understanding of others). The sample includes healthy adult participants in the 20–30 age range (meets 18–65 criterion) and reports results separately by age group. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task activation maps/contrasts (e.g., pain>no pain and pain>baseline) with voxelwise statistics (FWE-corrected maps and tables of coordinates) for the healthy participants; NeuroVault and coordinate tables are provided. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity only. Although an older group (65–75) is included, the younger healthy adult subgroup is analyzed and reported separately, satisfying the age-range requirement. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This paper reports an fMRI study of interpersonal synchrony—a social/affiliation paradigm—meeting the review’s content domain. The manuscript describes behavioral and neuroimaging results across a total of 100 participants who served as referents (no indication of clinical or special populations), consistent with healthy adult samples. The abstract and main text state that the neuroimaging study demonstrated involvement of multiple canonical brain regions implicated in social and embodied cognition (e.g., vmPFC, IPL, ACC, premotor areas), which indicates group-level task-evoked activation results rather than only ROI or connectivity analyses. No evidence in the provided content suggests the study is resting-state only or non-empirical. Age range is not explicitly reported in the excerpt, so confidence is moderate (0.75), but the information provided supports inclusion under the criteria (social task, healthy adults, and reported whole-brain task activations).

The study’s participant sample comprises adolescents (ages 12–18) with mean ages ~14.6–15.1; there is no healthy adult (age 18–65) group or separately reported adult subgroup. Although the paper uses an fMRI social-emotion face-processing task and reports whole-brain, voxelwise control-group activation maps, it fails the review’s required sample criterion (at least one healthy adult group aged 18–65). Therefore it does not meet all inclusion criteria and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI task study of social/affiliative processing (maternal attachment and owner-dog bond) using a passive viewing paradigm clearly targeting affiliation/attachment. Sample consists of healthy adult women (ages 22–45). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise SPM8 analyses and multiple within-group contrasts (e.g., own child vs. fixation, own dog vs. fixation, own child vs. own dog, own vs. unfamiliar) with activation maps and MNI coordinates provided. Although significance was assessed with ROI-based small-volume correction, the analyses were conducted voxelwise across normalized whole-brain data and results for the healthy adult group are reported and illustrated, meeting the review’s requirement for group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps/coordinates. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI results, only connectivity/resting-state, non-adult sample) apply. Therefore the study should be included.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (attribute framing and self/other perspective-taking). Participants were healthy adults (ages 19–41); results are reported for the healthy sample. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., task vs control, positive minus negative frame, frame-inconsistent minus frame-consistent) with voxel coordinates and cluster thresholds, not limited to ROI-only analyses. The design and analyses are task-evoked (event-related fMRI) rather than resting-state or connectivity-only. No exclusion criteria apply, so the study meets all inclusion requirements for the meta-analysis.

This fMRI study used a social-cognitive task (affective Theory of Mind, emotion recognition, neutral face processing). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=18) reported separately. The paper reports group-level task activations for the healthy controls (e.g., bilateral STS and inferior prefrontal gyrus) and conducted whole-brain analyses (thresholds and supplementary whole-brain results are referenced), not ROI-only. Although ROI analyses were also performed, whole-brain task-evoked results for the healthy/control group are clearly described. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (perception of racial ingroup vs outgroup faces) in healthy adult participants (subjects identified as White or Black). The paper reports group-level BOLD differences in the amygdala to outgroup vs ingroup faces across all subjects and describes voxelwise effects that were subsequently examined with an ROI analysis, indicating that whole-brain task-evoked group results were obtained and used. The task is clearly social-cognitive, participants are healthy adults, and group-level activation to the task is reported. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only reporting, resting-state/connectivity-only, or non-healthy/adolescent/elderly-only sample) are met. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This is a task-based dual‑fMRI (hyperscanning) study of social interaction (cooperation vs competition), conducted in healthy adults (n=38; mean age 22.4). The analyses produce group-level whole-brain spatial components from gICA (voxelwise maps shown/used) and report task-related effects via back-reconstructed component time‑courses and group statistical tests (paired t-tests, ISC comparisons). The paper is not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and reports healthy-group whole‑brain results tied to task conditions. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria.

The provided full-text content is missing (shows only a website privacy/cookie notice) and does not report methods, participant characteristics, or results. Although the title indicates an fMRI study of self-knowledge (a social-related construct) and authors/journal/DOI are given, I cannot verify key inclusion criteria: (1) presence of at least one healthy adult group (age 18–65) with reported results separate from any clinical groups, and (2) reporting of group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps or coordinates. Because the necessary methodological and results details required to confirm whole-brain healthy-group task activation are absent from the supplied full text, the study cannot be confirmed as eligible and must be excluded. If the full article text (methods and results) is provided showing the required whole-brain healthy-group analyses, this decision should be revisited.

This is an fMRI pharmaco-fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=40, mean age 25.8) performing a social touch task manipulating perceived toucher sex. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level task-evoked activation maps and voxelwise contrasts (e.g., touch>close, Female TouchOXT>Female TouchPLC) with MNI coordinates and family-wise error-corrected results, clearly from the healthy/control sample. The task probes social-related processing (affective/social touch, affiliation/self-referential processing). Analyses include whole-brain and ROI results; whole-brain maps are reported, satisfying the requirement. Participants are within the 18–65 range and results are reported for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are violated (not an ROI-only, resting-state, or patient-only study). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (agency vs. communion) using a valence classification task in healthy adults (N=42, ages 18–25). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (agency vs. fixation, communion vs. fixation, conjunctions, and direct contrasts) with cluster correction (AlphaSim) and tables/figures of activations/coordinates. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group whole-brain task effects. All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study examines social-related face perception and emotion processing with fMRI in (presumably) healthy observers, the provided full-text summary does not report participant demographics/ages nor explicitly state that any group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy group are reported. The summary focuses on responses in specific regions (FFA, STS, amygdala), which could reflect ROI-based analyses. Because the inclusion criteria require explicit reporting of healthy adult samples (age 18–65) and at least one whole-brain group-level task map, and these elements are not clearly present in the provided information, the study must be excluded from the meta-analysis based on insufficient evidence that the whole-brain and sample criteria are met.

This fMRI study examines voice processing (socially relevant stimuli) and reports results for an age-matched healthy adult control group (n=8, mean age ~27). The paper provides group-level, whole-brain task activation analyses for controls (random-effects analysis, P < 0.001 corrected) demonstrating voice-selective STS activation, and these healthy-group effects are described separately from the autism group. The task is clearly social-related (voice perception/processing), and the study is empirical fMRI work in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/only connectivity, and includes a healthy adult whole-brain task map). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study's sample consists solely of children and adolescents (N=55; age range 8.1–16.5, M=13.34). The meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 18–65 or a separately reported healthy adult subgroup. No adult participants or adult subgroup analyses are reported. Although the study uses task-based fMRI with whole-brain analyses of social processing, the age criterion is not met, so it cannot be included.

This is an fMRI study of social-related decision-making (charitable donation/opposition) tapping constructs of altruism, affiliation/attachment, and moral social evaluation. Sample: 19 healthy adult participants (mean age 28.2), within 18–65. Analyses: group-level, random-effects, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts are reported (GLM contrasts, one-sample t tests; results reported with coordinates and cluster thresholds), not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results. The paper presents clear healthy-group task activation maps/contrasts (e.g., VTA–striatum, subgenual area, OFC, anterior PFC) and tables of coordinates. No exclusion criteria apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI in healthy adults investigating social processes.

This article is a narrative review/synthesis of the authors’ program of research rather than a primary empirical fMRI report. Although it describes and reproduces adapted figures from prior studies that include group-level activation maps in neurotypical participants, the paper itself does not present original methods, sample details, or new whole-brain voxelwise statistical maps as a primary empirical contribution. Per the exclusion criterion for non-empirical papers without original fMRI data in healthy adults, it should be excluded. (Relevant primary empirical fMRI studies cited within this review should be screened separately.)

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=23, ages 19–32) examining neural correlates of suspense during reading. The task involves social-cognitive processing (mentalizing/theory-of-mind about story characters), a construct within ‘Perception and Understanding of Others.’ The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (second-level random-effects GLM) with cluster-level FWE correction and lists peak coordinates and tables of activations (medial frontal cortex, TPJ, IFG, etc.), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although an amygdala ROI was also tested, whole-brain results are clearly reported for the healthy sample. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy adult sample within 18–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study title suggests a social/attachment fMRI task in adult mothers, but the provided full-text content contains only references and metadata with no methods, participant details, task description, or results. I cannot verify key inclusion requirements: (1) that at least one group of healthy adults (age 18–65) was tested and reported separately, and (2) that at least one group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group is reported. Additionally, the sample appears to be mothers of preterm infants (a potentially special clinical/high-risk group), and no separate healthy-control whole-brain results are available in the excerpt. Because the essential criterion of reporting healthy-group whole-brain task activation maps cannot be confirmed from the provided full text, the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (automatic perception of cooperative vs noncooperative behavior) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=19) reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts for the healthy controls (e.g., C+ > C–, FDR-corrected p < .05) with voxelwise results, coordinates, figures, and second-level random-effects analyses explicitly described for the control group. The design and results are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses and provide unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group activation maps. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI hyperscanning study of social interaction (interactive pattern game) in healthy adults (N=44; mean age 22.4, within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise GLM results (non-parametric permutation inference, thresholded t-maps) with tables of cluster coordinates and figures showing whole-brain maps for multiple task contrasts within the healthy sample. It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses and does not involve patient groups without separate healthy-group results. Thus it satisfies all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI evidence in healthy adults.

Although the study uses fMRI with a social-emotion task and includes a healthy adult control group (n=29) and reports control-group contrasts with coordinates, the reported activations for the healthy group are derived from analyses constrained to a priori ROIs (frontopolar, IFG, temporoparietal junction, temporal poles) and statistical thresholds are described as FDR/FWE corrected within ROI masks. The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain (voxelwise) group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group (nor report whole-brain-corrected healthy-group contrasts), which fails the inclusion requirement for whole-brain evidence. Therefore it meets the task and sample criteria but fails the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task-evoked results.

The paper is a proof-of-concept EEG–rt-fMRI neurofeedback/correlation study focused on the right posterior Superior Temporal Sulcus (pSTS). The abstract and metadata describe ROI-based extraction of fMRI activations and correlation analyses with EEG features; no group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps for a healthy adult group are reported or described. Participant/sample details are not provided in the abstract, and the study appears methodological/ROI-focused rather than reporting unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task activation results. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one group-level whole-brain task activation map from healthy adults.

This is an original, empirical task-fMRI study in healthy adults (N=28, age 30–50). The experiment includes a social-related manipulation (implicit social vs non-social pictures) and self-referential judgments—both relevant constructs (perception/understanding of self and others). Whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses are reported (SPM8; ANOVA, group contrasts, conjunctions) with thresholding and cluster extents; results are presented as statistical maps and coordinate tables/figures. The sample is within the 18–65 range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The study does not rely solely on ROIs, connectivity-only, or between-group contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy young adults using a social-attribution task (perception of human-like interactions), directly assessing social processing. The abstract reports group-level task activations in fusiform face area, amygdala, temporal pole, mPFC, and STS, consistent with whole-brain voxelwise results rather than ROI-only analyses. Participants are healthy adults (young adults within the 18–65 range). The study is not a review or connectivity/resting-state-only paper. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult group, and reported whole-brain task-evoked group activations).

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=21, mean age 24.6) using a social task probing observed eye-contact and gaze following (social perception/communication). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (random-effects one-sample t-tests) with reported contrasts, thresholding, and tables/figures of suprathreshold clusters and coordinates. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social interaction perception in healthy adult participants (Experiment 1: N=50, ages 19–34; Experiment 2: N=23, ages 18–30). The task probes perception/understanding of others (observed social interactions), satisfying the social-related construct. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., social interaction > independent actions) with FDR-corrected clusters and surface-based group analyses, clearly from the healthy/control sample. It is empirical fMRI work (not ROI-only, not resting-state), and reports whole-brain results; therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an event-related fMRI study (reanalysis of Schilbach et al., 2006 data) examining perception of socially relevant facial expressions—clearly a social-processing task (facial mimicry, social interaction). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=17, males, mean age ~25.9), within 18–65. Group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxelwise analyses are reported (FIR model in SPM5) with stereotactic MNI coordinates and thresholds (p=.001 uncorrected, extent ≥10 voxels); results and coordinates are presented for the healthy group (not limited to an ROI or subgroup). The paper reports task-evoked whole-brain activations (motor, cingulate, hippocampus, midbrain, precuneus). No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not a review). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

Although the study uses fMRI during a social (trust) task and includes a healthy adult control group (20 males, 18–50), the paper does not report an unmasked, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group alone. The reported whole-brain, voxel-wise results are exploratory between-group contrasts (control > patient) rather than within-group healthy participant activation maps. Within-group results are restricted to ROI analyses. This violates the inclusion criterion requiring at least one group-level, whole-brain healthy-group task effect, and meets the exclusion criterion for studies that report only between-group whole-brain contrasts without an accompanying unmasked healthy-group whole-brain task map.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (25 scanned participants, mean age ~22.6) that investigates social tie formation during a repeated public-good game — a social-related task (affiliation/attachment and perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (FSL FEAT GLM; cluster-wise FWE correction; MNI coordinates and statistical maps reported and described in the text and tables), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only results. Healthy-group results are presented clearly and separately. The sample falls within the 18–65 age range. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, not a non-empirical paper). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=20; mean age ~20.6) that investigates event simulation and explicitly addresses social-cognition constructs (theory of mind, trait inference) and uses stimuli that include social situations (~42% social). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses (second-level random-effects one-sample t-tests) with cluster-corrected thresholds (p<0.001 height, p<0.05 cluster) and coordinates for activation peaks (and additional reported uncorrected peaks). Tasks involved explicit/implicit situational understanding and future prediction, producing contrasts (e.g., Exp–Imp, Ftr–Exp) that identify canonical social brain regions (MPFC, TPJ, TP, PCC). All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

Although the study uses task fMRI with healthy adult controls and addresses social-affective processing, it does not report any group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. Analyses are based on predefined network nodes and sliding-window network cohesion indices (ROI/network-level connectivity) and comparisons of these NCI time series; no unmasked whole-brain healthy-group activation maps or voxelwise contrasts are presented. This falls under the exclusion criterion for studies reporting only ROI/network or connectivity analyses without whole-brain task activation results. Therefore it fails the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion.

This is a single-subject pilot fMRI study (one healthy 22-year-old female). Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy adult participants (age 18–65) with group-level whole-brain task-evoked results. Although whole-brain activations are reported, they are from a single subject rather than a healthy-group, group-level analysis. Therefore the study does not meet the sample and whole-brain group-level criteria and must be excluded.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (Theory of Mind and empathy) using a comic-strip task in a nonclinical sample. Participants: 76 healthy college students (age range 17–21, mean 19.3) — predominantly adults within the 18–65 range; screened for psychiatric disorders. The paper reports group-level whole-brain SPM activation maps (alpha RFT ≤ 0.05) and pooled-condition whole-brain analyses used in subsequent spotlight MSAA, fulfilling the whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked map requirement for the healthy group. The task and contrasts are clearly described and maps were used for analyses. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for inclusion in the review of social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Note: one or a few participants may be 17, but the sample is predominantly adult and results are reported at the group level for healthy participants.

The study used task-based fMRI of a social-related paradigm (peer-oriented social judgment assessing acceptance/rejection), meeting the construct of social reward/processing. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=20; mean age ~28) and reports within-group, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts for the control group (acceptance>control and rejection>control). Analyses were whole-brain (SPM8) with cluster-based correction and results for the healthy/control group are described in the text and figures. The paper is empirical, not ROI-only, resting-state, or connectivity-only, and reports unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task activations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (emotional perspective-taking and emotion attribution). Sample consists of 121–129 healthy adult participants (age 18–35). The authors report group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (emotion perspective-taking > shape-match; emotion attribution > gender-match) using FWE correction and provide cluster coordinates and statistical maps/analyses. Results are clearly reported for the healthy participant group and are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (n=16–17 analyzed per task, ages 21–46). Tasks probe attribution of emotions/perception of others (Explicit: Emotion vs Expression; Implicit: Face > Scramble) — clearly social-related processing. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task contrasts (Emotion>Expression conjunctions across targets; Face>Scramble; target-dependent whole-brain contrasts) with cluster-level FWE correction and ROI and whole-brain analyses described. Healthy adult results are reported separately and are primary. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, empirical fMRI data present). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cooperation (Prisoner’s Dilemma), a social-processing task. Sample: healthy adult participants (final N=18 imaging subjects; mean age ~21), within 18–65. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level task-evoked analyses (CC vs. other outcomes; context contrasts and interaction), with coordinates and cluster-level FWE correction described—i.e., unmasked, voxelwise whole-brain results for the healthy group. Although ROI analyses were also performed, whole-brain results are present. No exclusion criteria are met (not solely ROI, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and is empirical). Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=35, mean age 29) using a social-related task (memory for faces with emotional expressions — perception/understanding of others). The authors report group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses (ANCOVA) with voxelwise results (FDR-corrected), provide Talairach coordinates and cluster sizes for emotion and load contrasts, and report correlations between behavior and whole-brain-derived ROIs. All inclusion criteria are met (task is social, sample is healthy adults within 18–65, and whole-brain task-evoked maps are reported). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=12, ages 20–32) that directly probes social-related processing (learning facts about people vs buildings vs hammers) and interprets person-selective anterior temporal lobe responses as social cognition. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation analyses (conjunction analyses, thresholding and cluster-size correction across ROIs and whole-brain) and presents domain-specific and domain-general whole-brain results (figures and cluster tables described). Results are reported for the healthy/control sample (no separate patient-only reporting). The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and includes task-evoked activation maps meeting the review’s whole-brain requirement. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (final N=16, ages 18–29) using a task that explicitly examines perception/understanding of others (evaluating whether a child’s actions match an adult’s instructions). The paper reports group-level voxelwise whole-brain analyses (voxelwise ANOVAs with thresholds, reported peak coordinates and clusters in DLPFC, posterior STS, medial prefrontal and other regions) in addition to ROI analyses. Results are clearly presented for the healthy/control group. Thus all inclusion criteria are met (social-related fMRI task; healthy adult sample within 18–65; whole-brain, group-level task-evoked maps reported). No exclusion criteria apply.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (TD; mean age ~29.7) and used fMRI, the reported fMRI results are limited to an a priori amygdala ROI (corrected within-amygdala) and ERP findings. The paper emphasizes ROI-based amygdala contrasts and between-group comparisons; it does not present an unmasked, group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map (or whole-brain coordinate table/figure) clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Because the review requires at least one whole-brain healthy-group task-evoked map, this study fails the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

The study's participants are adolescents (scanned at age ~16–17; samples: CFP N=156 and PGS‑E N=119). The meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 18–65 or a separately reported healthy adult subgroup. No adult sample or adult subgroup is reported; all participants are under 18. Although the paper reports whole‑brain task-evoked fMRI maps for a social cognition/emotion introspection task, the age criterion is not met, so the study must be excluded.

This is an event-related task fMRI study of social interaction (SI) recognition using point-/stick-light displays—clearly a social-related process. The sample includes a healthy adult group (n=16, mean age 28.8 y, within 18–65) with results reported separately. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (SI > NM) for the adult group, with voxelwise statistics, cluster/FWE information, and regional activations described in the text/tables. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state only, and healthy adult whole-brain maps are reported). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=17, mean age 26). The task manipulated social vs. individual actions and gaze availability — a clear social-cognitive paradigm. Group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses are reported (second-level within-subjects ANOVA) with voxelwise results and coordinates (p<.001 uncorrected; maps/tables described), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from the healthy group. The sample falls within the 18–65 age range and results for the healthy participants are reported separately. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) are violated.

This is an empirical, task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining perception and anticipation of another person’s actions (anticipation/action observation), which maps onto the review construct 'Perception and Understanding of Others.' The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxelwise analyses (t-contrasts, FWE-corrected), with figures and tables of peak coordinates and ROI analyses derived from independent whole-brain contrasts. Samples include adult participants (recreational to international players) with results reported for healthy groups. The study is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy toward humans and animals) in healthy adult participants (n=60, ages 18–60). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (human negative > neutral; animal negative > neutral) with second-level random-effects analyses and coordinates with FWE-corrected thresholds and conjunction/within-group maps. Healthy groups’ whole-brain results are clearly reported separately (within-group and between-group contrasts). The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and participants fall within the 18–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (action understanding, mentalizing, mirror-neuron processes) in healthy adults (final N reported; ages 18–32). The design uses task-evoked fMRI with group-level, random-effects voxelwise contrasts and reports cluster coordinates and tables of activations (e.g., Table 1) for the healthy sample. Although primary analyses were restricted to an a priori mask, the manuscript notes whole-brain results and provides group-level voxelwise statistical maps/coordinates (including conjunctions and F-contrasts) for the healthy group; results are not limited to ROI, connectivity, or clinical-only contrasts. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and reported group-level voxelwise task activation maps).
