The study therefore satisfies all inclusion criteria and does not meet any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, reports healthy-group whole-brain activations).

This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (empathy/mentalising) in healthy adults (final sample n=34, ages 20–30). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., emotional > neutral) and voxelwise correlations (EA modulation, time-series correlations with intensity), analyzed with SPM12/FSL and TFCE FWE correction, with peak activations and cluster tables. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and healthy-group whole-brain results are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria are violated.

The healthy sample comprises adolescent males (age range 13–19); no healthy adult (18–65) subgroup is reported separately. Thus the study fails the sample inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy adult group. Although the study used task fMRI and reports whole-brain analyses (exploratory across groups), it does not clearly present an unmasked, whole-brain task activation map for the healthy adult group. Therefore it does not meet the review’s age-based inclusion criterion (and likely the healthy-group whole-brain reporting requirement).

This is an fMRI task study of social cognition (theory-of-mind: attribution of intentions, deception vs cooperation) in healthy adult participants (n=13, ages 22–38). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task activation analyses (exploratory whole-brain ToM vs non-ToM contrast with reported cluster peaks and coordinates) and subsequent contrasts between task conditions. Results for the healthy group are reported clearly (coordinates, contrasts, figures/tables). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 18–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study using a social-related task (imitate/observe emotional faces) in healthy adults (initial N=28; final imaging N=20; ages 18–55). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses: a task PLS and a GLM in SPM8 with voxelwise maps and bootstrap-thresholded voxel patterns (rendered on the brain and described in the text). Results are reported for the healthy/control sample (no patient-only or ROI-only restrictions). The methods and results clearly present whole-brain, voxelwise task activation patterns related to social cognitive processing, satisfying all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria.

The study reports an fMRI task probing social perception of others (dynamic pupillary signals), which maps to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. Sample: 14 healthy adult participants (mean age 22), meeting the age and healthy-sample requirement. Group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses are reported (main effect of viewing eyes reported at whole-brain corrected cluster threshold p<.05; second-level analyses of pupil-change effects and interactions reported with voxelwise thresholds and coordinate tables), so whole-brain task-evoked maps from the healthy group are available. The paper is empirical, not resting-state/seed-only, and reports task activation (not limited to ROI-only results). No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study uses task fMRI with healthy adult controls and addresses social-related processing (emotion word comprehension). However, the paper does not clearly report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group alone. Key whole-brain results are presented either pooled across all participants or as between-group (control > ASC) contrasts, and ROI analyses and within-group ROI statistics for controls are reported, but a clearly identified whole-brain healthy-group task effect (main effect or within-group voxelwise map) is not provided in the full text. Because the review requires at least one clearly reported healthy-group whole-brain task map, this study fails that criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (college students, ages 19–24) that uses a social-related task (self-face recognition — perception/understanding of self). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts and random-effects analyses (e.g., Morph 50% self vs friend; reported MPFC, PCC, precuneus clusters with MNI coordinates and corrected cluster-level thresholds), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps. The sample and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The study is empirical and not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study reports an fMRI experiment using a social-interaction task (virtual handshake; social rejection vs acceptance), addressing social processing constructs (mentalizing, perception of others). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=16, mean age 27.4) reported separately. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain within-group contrasts for the control group (refusal > acceptance: right pSTS and thalamus) with statistical thresholds and cluster correction described. It is not limited to ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses. Participants’ ages and sample meet the 18–65 range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Uses task-based fMRI probing social-related face perception/emotional/mentalizing processes (Thatcher Illusion, attention to eyes/mouth). (2) Includes a healthy adult control group (neurotypical adults, mean age ~25.8) with results reported separately. (3) Reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise within-group task contrasts for the healthy/control group (statistical maps and thresholds described for NT). No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adults within 18–65). Therefore it should be included.

This fMRI study examines social perception (gaze processing/theory-of-mind), using a task involving direct vs. averted gaze. It includes a healthy adult control group (initial n=25; adults) with group-level, within-group contrasts reported (controls: direct > averted gaze) derived from a second-level voxelwise GLM. Coordinates and P-values for group and within-group contrasts are presented (tables/figures), and voxelwise results are described (visualized at P<0.001 uncorrected and small-volume corrected ROIs). Although some ROI-based small-volume correction was used, the paper reports group-level, voxelwise task-evoked activation for the healthy/control group separately, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI-only analyses, only connectivity/resting-state, or no healthy adult data) apply. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

Although the study uses fMRI during a social task (empathy/sympathy) and reports group-level whole-brain activation maps, the sample is mixed-age (N=57, ages 7–40) and the authors do not report a separate healthy adult (18–65) group-level whole-brain task effect. Results are presented for the combined sample and age-correlations rather than an adult-only group. Because the meta-analysis requires at least one clearly reported healthy adult (18–65) group-level whole-brain task map (or a healthy adult subgroup analyzed/reported separately), this paper does not meet the sample criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult males (ages 18–35) using a social provocation task (modified Taylor Aggression Paradigm) that probes social-related processing (response to others, anger, social decision-making). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (high>low provocation; decision and feedback phases) with MNI coordinates and cluster-level FWE correction, clearly from the healthy/control sample (n=93 after exclusions). It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses and participants fall within the 18–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (recognition of communicative intentions from prosody) in healthy adult participants (n=22, mean age 27), satisfying the sample criterion (ages within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked voxelwise contrasts (CLEAR>AMBIGUOUS and AMBIGUOUS>CLEAR) with statistical thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, and presents activation maps and coordinates; thus whole-brain evidence is available. The study is not limited to ROI-only or resting-state/connectivity-only analyses (PPI is included but additional whole-brain activation maps are reported). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study uses task-based fMRI (Cyberball social exclusion) addressing social-related processing. It includes a healthy adult control group (HC; n=28) reported separately. The paper presents whole-brain, group-level task-evoked results for the healthy controls (main effect of condition: left anterior insula/inferior frontal gyrus) with voxelwise FWE correction and reported coordinates/figures. The task contrasts (ESE vs INC, ISE vs INC) and statistical maps are clearly described for HC. Not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Uses task-based fMRI during a social-related impression-formation task (perception/understanding of others, varying race and status). (2) Sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=60 males, mean age 23.8). (3) Reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (GLM contrasts used for PLS; whole-brain PLS results with voxelwise bootstrap ratios, cluster reporting, and figures), not limited to ROI or resting-state or seed connectivity. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore include.

Meets all inclusion criteria: empirical fMRI study of social processing (self vs other processing in romantic relationships). Sample comprises healthy adults aged 23–40 (within 18–65). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts are reported (e.g., self positive > neutral, other negative > neutral) with one-sample t-tests, ANOVA, and FWE correction; results presented as tables/figures and described in text. Not limited to ROI, resting-state, or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of healthy adult fMRI studies of social-related processing.

This is an fMRI task study of social interaction perception in healthy adults (n=27, ages ~24–26). The study used task-evoked BOLD fMRI with event-related design and reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects voxelwise analyses (contrasts, conjunctions, and interaction effects) with FWE-corrected thresholds and figures/tables of activations. Although ROIs were also used, whole-brain results are clearly reported for the healthy participant group. The sample is within the 18–65 age range and results for the healthy group are presented directly. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Multiple inclusion criteria are not met. Participants are adolescents (age 12–18), not healthy adults aged 18–65, so the sample is outside the required age range. The task is the Embedded Figures Task, a visual search/perceptual task, not a social-related paradigm (e.g., affiliation, social communication, perception/understanding of self/others). Although whole-brain group-level fMRI contrasts are reported, they pertain to adolescent case/sibling/control groups and not to a healthy adult group. Therefore the study does not provide a whole-brain task activation map from healthy adults and does not address social processing in adults.

While the study uses task fMRI of social processing (emotional face perception) and includes healthy adult participants (and an independent healthy replication sample), it does not report a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The primary whole-brain analyses were conducted on a combined sample (patients + controls) and the independent healthy replication used an anatomical ROI approach (fusiform ROI) rather than an unmasked whole-brain healthy-group contrast. Therefore it fails the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map and must be excluded.

This study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (samples aged 18–24). Tasks probe social-related constructs (self-related processing, mentalizing/social cognition) during article exposure. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked analyses (exploratory whole-brain searches, thresholded maps, and whole-brain tables/clusters with cluster and nonparametric FDR correction) clearly derived from the healthy participant samples. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, healthy adult group-level whole-brain maps reported).

The study does not meet key inclusion criteria: participants are male children/adolescents (not healthy adults 18–65), and the task is a non-social visual attention paradigm rather than a social-processing task. Although whole-brain task activation maps for a control group are reported, the review requires studies of social-related processing in healthy adults. No healthy adult subgroup is analyzed separately, and the primary task is non-social. Therefore the study must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (sighted n=14, mean age 32±13; congenitally blind n=8, mean age 44±16), addressing perception/understanding of others (mirror system responses to action sounds and motor pantomime). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., familiar action vs environmental sounds; motor pantomime vs rest) with cluster correction and coordinates/figures for sighted and blind groups separately. Results for healthy control (sighted) group are reported explicitly. Analyses are task-evoked activation maps (not only ROI, connectivity, or resting-state). All inclusion criteria are met; no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study in a healthy adult sample (n=51, mean age 22) using a social decision-making task where another person controls/restricts choices (social cognition: perception/understanding of others, reactance). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked analyses (paired t-tests for controlled > free) with cluster-level FWE correction and provides whole-brain results and coordinates. Neural connectivity and covariate analyses are supplementary but do not replace the primary whole-brain task contrasts. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state only, clinical-only, or non-empirical) apply.

This is an fMRI study using a social-related (attachment/affiliation) task: mothers viewed video vignettes of their own infant vs. stranger infant. Sample includes healthy adult participants (mothers aged 22–37; N=23 in imaging analyses after exclusions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps/contrasts (own infant > stranger infant) and tables/figures describing whole-brain GLM results and functional connectivity maps for the healthy mother group. Results for the healthy adult group are reported separately and not limited to a narrow subgroup. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state only, participants are within 18–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (ages reported within 18–65) investigating perception and recognition of faces (a social-related process: Perception/Understanding of Others). Group-level fMRI analyses were performed (mixed-effects FLAME) and data were registered to MNI space; an independent group-level localizer (n=83) was used to define ROIs, and voxelwise multivariate pattern analyses and representational similarity/regression analyses across visual field maps and ROIs are reported. Behavioral and neural results are reported for the healthy participant groups. The study is empirical, not a review, and reports whole-brain analytic procedures and group-level results (via group mixed-effects analyses and ROI/visual-field mappings derived from group contrasts), meeting the inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria.

Study uses task-based fMRI of a social-related manipulation (advice from an expert) during decision-making. Sample includes a healthy adult group (ages 18–45) distinct from adolescent groups. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise group-level statistical maps/contrasts (thresholded t-maps with cluster correction) and provides peak coordinates (e.g., DLPFC, vmPFC) and cluster results derived from second-level analyses. Although the paper focuses on developmental comparisons, healthy adult group results are reported and separable. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for task-based, whole-brain fMRI evidence in healthy adults for social-related processing.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=98, mean age 20.7) that uses social cognition tasks (judgments about self, friends, and strangers — constructs: perception/understanding of self and others; affiliation/closeness). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., self > Bush; friends > strangers; similar > dissimilar) with whole-brain maps and coordinates (thresholded p<0.001 uncorrected) and describes these healthy-group results in the text and figures. It therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult sample within 18–65, and whole-brain group-level activation maps) and violates none of the exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, not non-empirical).

This study includes a healthy adult sample (N=19, ages 22–31) and employs an fMRI task probing social-related constructs (direct self, direct other, and reflected self-evaluations—perception/understanding of self and others). The authors report group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (a 2×4×3 whole-brain repeated-measures ANOVA with AlphaSim cluster correction) and present significant whole-brain task effects and coordinates (including main effects and interaction clusters), with within-group analyses reported (adult and adolescent) and supplemental materials. The design is task-evoked (not resting-state), and whole-brain results for the healthy adult group are clearly described. Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults. Caveat: adult sample is modest in size, but this does not violate inclusion criteria.

While this is an fMRI study of social appraisal (trustworthiness) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=17), the paper does not clearly report a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map specifically for the healthy/control group. The whole-brain analyses described are reported across all participants or as between-group contrasts, and control-specific results are presented primarily as ROI analyses and summary statistics rather than an unmasked, voxelwise healthy-group map. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one explicitly reported healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked map (or equivalent coordinate table/figure clearly identified as from the healthy group), this study does not meet that criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI task study of social-related processing (negative vs positive social feedback) in healthy adult participants (within-subject sample of N=21 males, ages 21–39). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects task contrasts (negative social feedback > positive social feedback) with voxelwise and cluster-level correction and tables/figures of whole-brain activations (e.g., Table 2, Figures 2–3). Analyses are not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and results for the healthy group are clearly presented. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole‑brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=21 in the fMRI experiment; overall sample within 18–65). The experimental paradigm centers on social, self-related life events (interactive oral examinations) and examines retrieval of these socially-relevant episodes (pertains to perception/understanding of self and social interaction). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task activation results (e.g., increased activation in retrosplenial cortex, medial prefrontal cortex, hippocampus, temporal pole, left angular gyrus; Fig. 3B and Table S1) and presents voxelwise analyses with corrected thresholds. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults and provides whole-brain group-level activation maps/coordinates.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (eye gaze perception) in healthy adults (N=18, ages 18–30). The task is social (perception/understanding of others’ gaze), and analyses report group-level, whole-brain voxelwise results (second-level SPM-t maps, whole-brain FDR p<0.05) and coordinate tables showing effects in social attention regions. Results for the healthy/typical group are reported explicitly (including whole-brain correlations with AQ). The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses and includes clearly described whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy participants. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusions.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women, N=17, ages 19–29) examining social-related processing (perception of infant cries and faces—affiliation/attachment and perception of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., cries vs pink noise; happy/sad vs neutral faces) with fully described preprocessing, second-level random-effects analyses, cluster correction and thresholding, and figures/tables of whole-brain results. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 18–65 age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study is primarily a resting-state fMRI parcellation and MACM/coactivation meta-analytic study, not an original task-based fMRI investigation. Although it uses BrainMap meta-analytic coactivation and reports functional characterizations (including social cognition) via forward/reverse inference, it does not report any original whole-brain, group-level task-evoked activation maps from healthy adult participants. Inclusion criteria require primary fMRI task data with whole-brain healthy-group task effects. Sample (20 healthy adults, mean age 18.5) meets age criteria, but absence of task fMRI whole-brain results means it fails the key inclusion criterion, and thus should be excluded.

This fMRI study includes a healthy adult control group (n=25) and reports whole-brain, second-level random-effects task activation analyses for gesture planning and execution. The task probes social-communication relevant processes (pantomime/gesture planning and production), fitting the review’s social-related constructs. Within-group (healthy controls) whole-brain results are described (Analyses S2/S3, figure S2, table S2) and thresholding/cluster criteria are reported, so maps/coordinates for the healthy group are available. The study is task-based (not resting-state or seed-only) and not limited to ROI analyses. Participant ages are described as adult and matched to patients; no exclusion criteria (e.g., only connectivity or ROI-only reporting, non-adult sample) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (self-referential processing and perspective taking) in healthy adult participants. The task manipulates self vs. other judgments and perspective taking in a factorial design, and the paper reports group-level activation results (ventral/dorsal anterior MPFC, posterior dorsal MPFC, left dorsal MPFC) consistent with whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts. The constructs (Perception/Understanding of Self and Others) match the review scope. No evidence of ROI-only analyses, non-adult sample, or lack of healthy-group whole-brain results. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social self/other processing and includes a healthy adult control group (TD, n=24), the full text does not report an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group alone. The paper mainly presents between-group (ASD vs TD) contrasts, combined-group analyses (ASD+TD) to identify seeds, and ROI/functional-connectivity results (including within-group ROI statistics). Because the inclusion criterion requires at least one whole-brain task-evoked (voxelwise) map from the healthy/control group (not only between-group contrasts or ROI/connectivity analyses), this study fails that requirement and must be excluded.

Although the study uses task fMRI of social (cognitive empathy) processing and includes a healthy adult control group (n=24), the full-text presents only between-group whole-brain contrasts (controls vs. schizophrenia) and cluster results derived from these group differences. The paper does not report an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map or contrast explicitly attributed to the healthy/control group alone (e.g., a within-controls activation map or coordinates/figure clearly labeled as a healthy-group main effect). Per the review’s exclusion criteria, studies that report only between-group contrasts without an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect must be excluded.

This is an event-related fMRI study of social processing (implicit discrimination of emotional facial expressions), which directly targets social communication/perception. The paper includes a healthy adult control group (n=19, ages 18–51). Whole-brain voxelwise analyses are reported (SPM2), with group-level contrasts and cluster coordinates (FWE-corrected) described in the text and tables; the manuscript explicitly reports control-group activation patterns (e.g., frontal, insula, putamen activations for fearful and neutral faces) rather than only ROI results. The study therefore meets the fMRI social-task, healthy-adult sample, and whole-brain reporting criteria and does not fall under the exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and includes healthy adults 18–65).

execution_stats.search_query: ( ('functional MRI'[Title/Abstract] OR 'functional magnetic resonance imaging'[Title/Abstract] OR 'fMRI'[Title/Abstract] ) AND ( 'social communication'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social processing'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social interaction'[Title/Abstract] OR 'affiliation'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social attachment'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social cognition'[Title/Abstract] OR 'understanding others'[Title/Abstract] ) AND 'Humans'[MeSH])
